Got some comments and some questions:

Spundae: YES!  The beat in the Keith Herring (sp?) room was ON!  Bone 
shaking BASS and phat mixes.  Heard some Planet Rock (the song) getting 
mixed in, haven't heard that in quite a while.  Lots of rooms, lots of 
people but not too crowded, lots of great vibe.  Met a few people (wassup 
Tom, Sharon, Virginia!) and danced my butt off.  Nothing quite like driving 
home just as the 6am morning commute is starting up...hehe...  Wiped out the 
next day, but by 9pm I was ready to do it again!  That's the kind of venue 
that could make me want to do the do every night.

Now for the questions:  Who was on the turntables in the Keith Herring room at
1:30, 3:00, and 3:30?  I was too busy working the stage to check it out, but 
the people in the room were going nuts to some really phat beat.  I GOTTA KNOW!

S

Consider yourself energized...

Ok, how about this, a little humor.  I'd love to say I created this, but I 
didn't.  On the other hand, I've been thinking of using excerpts in my 
resume from now on:

---------
3A.  ESSAY IN ORDER FOR THE ADMISSIONS STAFF OF OUR COLLEGE
TO GET TO KNOW YOU, THE APPLICANT, BETTER, WE ASK THAT YOU
ANSWER THE FOLLOWING QUESTION:	ARE THERE ANY SIGNIFICANT
EXPERIENCES YOU HAVE HAD, OR ACCOMPLISHMENTS YOU HAVE
REALIZED, THAT HAVE HELPED TO DEFINE YOU AS A PERSON?

I am a dynamic figure, often seen scaling walls and crushing
ice.  I have been known to remodel train stations on my
lunch breaks, making them more efficient in the area of heat
retention.  I translate ethnic slurs for Cuban refugees, I
write award-winning operas, I manage time efficiently.
Occasionally, I tread water for three days in a row.

I woo women with my sensuous and godlike trombone playing, I
can pilot bicycles up severe inclines with unflagging speed,
and I cook Thirty-Minute Brownies in twenty minutes.  I am
an expert in stucco, a veteran in love, and an outlaw in
Peru.  Using only a hoe and a large glass of water, I once
single-handedly defended a small village in the Amazon Basin
from a horde of ferocious army ants.  I play bluegrass
cello, I was scouted by the Mets, I am the subject of
numerous documentaries.  When I'm bored, I build large
suspension bridges in my yard.

I enjoy urban hang gliding.  On Wednesdays, after school, I
repair electrical appliances free of charge.  I am an
abstract artist, a concrete analyst, and a ruthless bookie.
Critics worldwide swoon over my original line of corduroy
evening wear.  I don't perspire.  I am a private citizen,
yet I receive fan mail.  I have been caller number nine and
have won the weekend passes.  Last summer I toured New
Jersey with a traveling centrifugal-force demonstration.  I
bat .400.  My deft floral arrangements have earned me fame
in international botany circles.  Children trust me.

I can hurl tennis rackets at small moving objects with
deadly accuracy.  I once read Paradise Lost, Moby Dick, and
David Copperfield in one day and still had time to refurbish
an entire dining room that evening.  I know the exact
location of every food item in the supermarket.  I have
performed several covert operations for the CIA.  I sleep
once a week; when I do sleep, I sleep in a chair.  While on
vacation in Canada, I successfully negotiated with a group
of terrorists who had seized a small bakery.  The laws of
physics do not apply to me.

I balance, I weave, I dodge, I frolic, and my bills are all
paid.  On weekends, to let off steam, I participate in
full-contact origami.  Years ago I discovered the meaning of
life but forgot to write it down.  I have made extraordinary
four course meals using only a mouli and a toaster oven.  I
breed prizewinning clams.  I have won bullfights in San
Juan, cliff-diving competitions in Sri Lanka, and spelling
bees at the Kremlin.  I have played Hamlet, I have performed
open-heart surgery, and I have spoken with Elvis.

But I have not been to college.

Rick, I am so glad that you uphold the idea of making and sharing *vibe* rather 
than going out looking for it.  Sometimes, we all want to be nurtured and look 
for a good vibe party or group to hang with but ultimately, we all know we can 
tap into this energy on our own...we've just forgotten how to on a natural 
basis.  Music, dance, and raving plays an important role by overloading our 
physical senses allowing us to override our egos (or sense of self) and to 
reattune our spiritual self to the connective energy we all share.

I believe that as a group, if we are to progress in our beliefs of higher 
consciousness, after gaining awareness comes sharing and education of what we've
discovered.  Perhaps a group of sfravers might want to consider "juicing a jam" 
with me. I've done this with another dance group where we all attend a 
particular party once a month and converge with smiles, hugs, and tons of luvin'
energy.  This might also be a way for alot of us who haven't met to connect too!
 After doing this a few times, the community can grow in numbers and 
interactions outside of raves as people look forward to attending an event 
that's being juiced based on positive energy.

So if any of you want to join me in this endeavor, let me know and we can blast 
our luv phasers sometime in early February.

Oooo, just writing writing this makes me tingle knowing what positive energy we 
can share.  Hope you feel it too!

Hugs and warm smiles,
Diane

We have to make it ourselfs...by supporting parties in this area.  Many 
people need to feel it to really know it exists.  I think a f&f or crysalis

the treck from sf to attend a good party in a fresh location...and give some 
lessons in vibe.  Don't get me wrong...Sac's not all bad.  If you search, 
you can find the vibe....and I have at several Sac parties.  It usually just 
doesn't hit you in the face like some sf party experiences.

At 1:33 PM 1/16/96, SDream wrote:
>Got some comments and some questions:
>
>Spundae: YES!  The beat in the Keith Herring (sp?) room was ON!  Bone
>shaking BASS and phat mixes.  Heard some Planet Rock (the song) getting

>that could make me want to do the do every night.

>the people in the room were going nuts to some really phat beat.  I GOTTA KNOW!

That was my first Spundae. It was pretty crowded for a weekly club, and
especially a Sunday! The vibe was surprisingly good, too. I also saw a lot
of familiar faces.

I saw Carlos ripping it up in the basement around the same time Dimirti was
spinning upstairs.

The tiny Teknotika room was always packed and had a nice piece of art on
the wall that was in the juice bar room at Chrysalis the night before.

In the main room, the Keith Haring room, featuring their new "6-way digital
sound system" :-) was:

from 11:30pm - 1:00am EFX
from  1:00am - 2:30am Dimitry (Dee-Lite) (he played the Planet Rock song)

I got really tired, being out at Chrysalis all night the night before, so I
left around 2:00am. I don't know who came on after that for sure, but I got
the impression that either the 2:30-4:00 or 4:00-5:30 slot was going to be
Doc Martin. When I left at 2:00am I still hadn't seen Doc anywhere in the
building, so he may have played the closing set.

-w

B.S.  That's how it feels, sure, but you know that everything is fine.  
Look,  I love a lot of people.  I can say that without inhibition.  But I 
wouldn't marry them, y'know?  I love my friend Sean like a brother, but I 
wouldn't even have him as a roommate -- no offense Sean, if you happen 
across this...  

You could probably continue to love her, and she could always be a special 
friend, but move on.  There are so many really wonderful people around.  
Don't sweat it.

Know what I do?  I start taking my lady friends to lunch.  A different one 
every day.  Nothing expensive or anything, just someplace decent.  The 
female company is really nice, you can strengthen the friendship with the 
gesture, and they're always super supportive.  I can complain about the 
relationship, or I can just soak up a little pleasant conversation.  Makes 
me feel a lot better, and often they'll try to set me up with someone.  
Women are much better at match-making than men, IMHO.

Peas,

S


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jan 16 14:15:14 1996

From: darrele@netcom.com (Darrel Etter)
Message-Id: <199601162214.OAA09934@netcom22.netcom.com>
Subject: Tools of Freaky Chakra (for gearheads)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves)
Date: Tue, 16 Jan 1996 14:14:43 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3530      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


To fellow musicians and DJs with live sound asperations (sp). (I'm not
sure this info is wholy relevant to the list, but I'm sure there's a
few of you out there who, like me, live on this stuff.) :

I was very interested in seeing what gear Freaky Chakra used to do his
live techno performance. I like this live sound dance gig format. I'm
interested in doing it myself someday. So, I made a special effort of
looking down on top of Mr. Freaky during his performance. I think it
is especailly interesting to compare this guys gear usage to that of
Banco de Gaia. I wish that oportunity to see Eat Static didn't fall
through.

The stuff:

* Ensoniq SD-1 ( not SQ-1 ) synthisizer. This was his only
sequencer. I'm not familiar with Ensoniq on board sequencers, but I
wouldn't be suprised if they have special features to facilitate live
performance. He was all over this keyboard (the buttons, not the
keys)most of the performance.
* Roland TR-909
* Sequential Pro-One. I don't think he used this much. 
* Novation Bass-station Rack. Always going. 
* Ensoniq DP/4. I want one! This was the only effects box I saw, but
who needs any more.
* Emax II sampler. I believe he only used this for some vocal
samples. That's the only time I saw him go for the volume slider on
it.
* Ensoniq mirage sampler rack. Old gear. I doubt he used this much as
well.
* Roland JV-## rack. I think I remember seeing a single rack space
synth of this type in there.
* Mackie 1604 mixer. He had levels set from the beginning and didn't
touch them much from what I could tell. I think he always brought up
the levels on the individual instruments instead. Like I said before,
he was controlling everything from the SD-1 sequencer.
* Compressor/Limiters. Lots of this all the time. Probably on the
whole mix because there were only two channels, although he could have
been using them for bass and kick ( a guess).

Notes and Observations:

I only saw one time he actually played a part on the keyboard. It was
a rather weak melody. His fingers where shaking so much. 

Comparing to Banco de Gaia at the Trocadero, Mr. Banco was all
computer based sequencing, two synced Amiga/Atari(?) always running,
and ran stuff through a huge board. He was always on the board instead
of on the sequencers. He'd just start a new sequence every few pieces
and mix from the running sounds. He never touched a sound source.

Banco had a more complex sound, but also about 5 times the gear in
numbers, and 30 times in cost. I think Freaky had some dead spots
where things were not working correctly. Banco didn't. Of course the
style of music is a bit different.

Frankly, I liked Freaky's approach better. Let's not get overwhelmed
in overly produced, like the CD sound. Let's get those people
dancing. I'd rather see 5 Freaky Chakra's than one Banco de Gaia, and
considering the investment involved, that's what will happen. On a CD,
I like Banco de Gaia's sound better, and the music, but live, Banco
came off a bit stale. Freaky was a better live act, and I think that's
largely due to his use of gear, and maybe the vibe.

I barely remember seeing Orbital ( with UltraMarine and MeatBeatM)
years ago. Their setup and approach to the gear was sort of inbetween
Banco and Freaky. Although, I think they had much more
hands-on-the-instruments than either. They also had more actual
keyboards than either of these two, and everything was on big Ultimate
keyboard stands instead of in racks.

Anyway, I hope this was informative for someone. 

-Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

Subject: MaD rocked ass...
Date: Tue, 16 Jan 1996 14:19:55 -0800
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>

Precedence: bulk


I just wanted to let everyone know that MaD, as usual, was a fun, laid-back,
techno-heavy groovefest at the Bahia. Jon and Joe both turned in tight sets,
and Dave Cooper totally went insane (although I think people differed as to
whether this was a good or bad thing). He is a _super_ nice guy, too, being
very easy to talk to, totally down-to-earth and friendly. He can come back
here any time he wants, 'cuz I say so. :)

One of my favorite things about MaD is its social and friendly atmosphere.
Even though the space was (comfortably) crowded last night, everybody was
still chatty, open and relaxed. There was no spurious attitude to be
found. Monday nights have become a social touchstone for me, and I enjoy the
opportunity to sit around and talk to other raverfolk in a non-threatening
atmosphere.

I was especially excited to find out that Carl Craig is going to be playing
at MaD February 5th. I almost hesitate to mention it because it's going to
turn the place into a total zoo (or at least it will if there's any justice
in the world). In any case, y'all should definitely plan to check that out
-- Mr. Craig is a techno hero, having put out many classics over the past
few years: Paperclip People's "Throw", 69's "Jam The Box" and "Rushed",
BFC's "Chicken Soup", and many, many others. He's as precise as a surgeon
and has enough soul to rival James Brown. Check it out.

yrz,
ozy

ozymandias G desiderata      ogd@organic.com       Ravers Suck Our Sound
(415)284-6888     http://www.organic.com/Staff/ogd/       ::AOAIOXXYSZ::

> I'm totally into this idea.  I don't know if I can do it on a

Once I was used as an imported audience/fan. I was asked, along with
some friends to jump on a bus that was going down to LA to a show for
a band that was playing at a club in front of a bunch of record
industry big stiffs. There was a complementary party in the hills
afterwards. A weird scene, but if definitly did help the vibe and the
band.

My point is that the idea of "blitzing" a party to help out the vibe
is a good idea, even though this example is a bit different. Would be
fun too.

On Mon, 15 Jan 1996, Michael Standish wrote:

> quoth Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
> 
> >        Most parties search people at the door.  This always bothers me a
> >little bit, because it implies a lack of trust.  It implies that I cannot
> >be trusted not to bring weapons in which I would use to threaten the
> >health or safety of others.  I kind of feel like when I come dressed in
> >happy, fun clothing, with a smile on my face, it should be obvious to the
> >security that I don't need to be searched.  Search those scowling guys in
> >the bandanas over there, if you feel the need to search someone.
> 
>         Talk about a vibe killer for the people who do get searched. I sure
> wouldn't want to be the one who had to explain why they were being searched
> and not other people. What would I tell them? "Gee I'm sorry but I've just
> made a snap judgment based solely on how you look and it seems you're not
> wearing a rave approved, shit eating grin and that bandana is associated
> with gang members and people of color you know" If you feel like you're not
> trusted when everybody is being searched, think how you'd feel if you were
> the only one getting searched.
> 
>         There's also more to look for than just weapons. There's markers,
> spray paint, glass containers and nitrous tanks. Even the nicest raver can
> break a glass bottle and thus risk cutting someone's foot. I've worked
> parties where we didn't search people, and the space ended up so covered
> with tags that we could never get permission to use the space again. I've
> also worked F&F where we didn't search anybody and had no problems. It's a
> tough call, but for a party the size of the Gathering I would definitely
> search everyone.
> 
> 
I have one complaint about the searching at the Gathering.  If you were 
female, and you had one of the male guards search you, they didn't check 
for anything.  I had a whole backpack of stuff for the evening, although 
nothing I think would have been confiscated, and the male guard didn't 
even look at it.  However, my male friend following me in, got searched 
like crazy and got a couple things confiscated.  I don't think this is 
very fair, and once again judgments are being made as to how a person looks.

--kc

Really depressing news this weekend that I'm going blind. I'm having 
surgery under general anaesthetic Monday January 22nd.

I'll be away from the list and my email 1/22 thru 1/29.

I haven't met many of you in person simply because I haven't been out 
with all of my recent problems. Please send good vibes my way to help 
thru the surgery and recovery. I know that when this group pulls 
together magical things DO happen... I hope ya'll will extend that 
magic to help me out. I appreciate it a lot!

Thanks in advance to all the kind souls on this list!

Um, I don't think that is what Rick meant (Rick correct me if I am 
wrong).  I think getting a bunch of people together to go out is a great 
idea.  It is easier for me to enjoy myself and dance and lose it when I 
have a bunch of friends around me doing the same thing.  

When I lived in SoCal, there was (they are still there) this group of 
people that were always in the middle of the dancefloor just carefree 
boogeying and having a good time, smiling and laughing.  When they walked 
into a party or a club it always seemed as though the vibe of the whole 
room was elevated a notch.  I looked forward to seeing them.  (I actually 
saw a couple of them upstairs at Begin Again and it made my night.  You 
might have noticed a really tall redhead girl shaking her booty, if you 
were there.)  They were also the core group who put on the moontribe 
parties, which were the most amazing parties I have yet experienced, and 
I think that has to do with the great spirit of those people.  

So, Rick I'm with you.  I would love to be a part of something like 
that.  

Cheers****
Cami

I think that's a GREAT idea - to be more consciously committed to creating a
vibe at a party --

At the last Wicked, I met Keith, the tall British guy with blonde hair and fuzzy
red hat and overalls -- and he made such an impression on me -- he took it as
his mission that night to talk to everyone, introducing them, sharing his open
heart and sweet nature -- it was incredible to watch -- like a missionary of
spirit

As a result, I met several people I hope to see again, and had an awesome time,
because he connected me to his spirit - and I usually tend to be more of a loner
at parties --

Then I was so happy to see him at Chrysalis doing the same thing, and I've
decided that I want to more consciously take that same kind of role -- as if I
were hosting the party, opening up to help others have a good time makes you
have a good time too -- and having a good time is always my ultimate goal!

Nope, I don't think it would be phony - cause once we start our smiling happy
dancing vibe, it will feed itself -- yep, count me in PLEASE!

Leslie

To: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
From: ecto@citenet.net (ecto)
Subject: Re: vibe/networks :)
Cc: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

        Well one of the cool things about networks like the net or your
brain, is it's ability to synthesize seemingly dissimilar things: so that's
what i'm going to try:
        First, Starchild's idea of a phone network, and the subsequent
ideas of brunches, or vibe tribes is basically a phenomena that is sort of
pulling us all together in an odd sort of way. Even i'm feeling it here in
montreal, and it's making my chances for getting outta here go amazingly
smooth (or at least giving me the energy to see positively through
problems) :) But yep, it's a phenomena that's for sure, three separate
threads all pointing to one thing (or at least from my semi-myopic eyes ;)
        And then shawna posted something like this...

At 5:31 PM 1/15/96, Shawna McGourty wrote:
>Going alone to a party like this is no problem for me,
>because I know for a fact I'll totally be surrounded by family once I
>get there!  And boy was I!
        This is something i've noticed is really special about the rave
scene: comfort among 'strangers' which leads me to some things i thought
about 'networks' or 'complex systems':
================
Yep, i have been thinking much about how to survive and networks
are probably hte biggest source of strength that we have. Whether it be for
me and the net and doing graphics and HTML or simply the network of friends
and family or even just casual acquaintances that offer help, networks are
the way to go. And another thing that is drawing me to SF is the presence
of a network of ppl who have a certain level of consciousness about this
fact. When a network (like SFraves, or the rave scene, or SF in general) is
self-aware of its strength in diversity and *helping each other out*  it
becomes even MORE powerful and elevates itself to even HIGHER levels of
complexity and beauty :) This is why i think it'll be easier for me to make
a go of it in SF rather than say, New york city, because there are
individuals in the community that are aware of the fact that their strength
comes from their contacts and other people, NOT from a dog-eat dog, you or
me mentality.
=================
        Sorry about the semi-irrelevant personal stuff, but you get the hint :)
        I think that the stronger and more linked up a network is, the
faster it can achieve some sense of self-awareness, and complexity. And i
think that in a lot of ways SF is way ahead of other 'scenes' because the
people in the network are more open and communicative, allowing information
to flow faster, and also acting (in my limited experience) as a sort of
support net for the constituent parts.
        I wrote this first mostly just thinking about my place in the world
and how i'd like to be plopped into the middle of the SF network, but i
think that this may apply to everyone on the list for themselves. I'll give
anyone my phone number as soon as it's not long distance ;)
        Could you imagine if the 'rave scene' became self-aware of itself
as a network? and the power it (and i guess we :) ) could have? WOW! :)
        Or maybe i'm just an idealistic utopian type! who knows!
                much peace,
                        brad

Hi all ... after lurking on this list for months and months, I know it's 
about time for me to post something.
My name's Dan, I'm 26, and I moved to SF from Boston about 6 months ago. 
Luckily, I hooked up with this list pretty quickly and got to go to some of 
F-8's amazing outdoor summer parties ... I've been hooked on Trance ever 
since. Some friends and I went to Chrysalis last weekend, and had a great 
time ... I met Leslie (with the cool hat!), and a bunch of other people 
who's names I've already forgotten ... (I'm terrible w/ names until the 
3rd or 4th time ... sorry). I was wearing a shirt with a monkey on it, 
and a black bandana on my head ... maybe you saw me.

re: Joe's "Appreciate this!" ... I've lived all over the country, and 
have never seen anything that compares with the SF rave scene. We have 
the ideal climate for it here, and I'll never let myself take what we 
have here for granted.

peace,
Dan

BTW: Is anyone aware of anything happening on Saturday other than that $2 
house party? I have some friends coming in from out-of-town, and would 
like to hit the best party possible.

On Wed, 17 Jan 1996, Amy R Starkey wrote:

> 
> Isn't it weird, too, how many of us living outside of San Francisco visit 
> SF and afterward, feel a real yearning to be a part of that living 
> organism. SF has nearly become the "end all be all" of everything!  The 
> people who already live there may not see it as clearly as us outsiders 
> because they are immersed in it all the time.  Believe me, that energy is 
> *there*!
> 
> love,
> Amy


Many of us came from other parts of the country "to be here when it happens".
I now actually live well within the confines of The City (and it is a great
feeling !) For me I knew I had to move after the election of 1994 when 
prop 187
and a whole bunch of racist laws were put on the ballot here in california,
the ONLY county where they consistantly got less than 10% of the vote was
San Francisco, there is strength in numbers...

Believe me I love the Bay Area and rarely leave but you are correct in 
assuming that people who live here don't realize how good they really have
it until they move away.


					G

Subject: To Everybody!  An experiment...
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Hey all!

I'm going to try an experiment.  A while ago, there was some discussion 
about an IRC sfraves channel, and as far as I can see, nothing really 
came of it.  However, I am still interested in chatting with you all, 
so I figure I'll try this out.  Tomorrow, Thursday Jan. 18th, I am 
going to start up #sfraves at 8 pm, and see who shows!  Anybody 
interested in showing up & chatting live with other sfravers should 
stop by & check it out!  I have no idea if 1 person or 100 people will 
show, but that's why they call it an experiment!  Anybody who wants to, 
please stop by & say hi!

#sfraves
Thursday
January 18th
8 pm!


Love,
Shawna

p.s.  If somebody has already started an #sfraves-type of channel that 
now exists, & I just don't know about it, let me know!

>TOKYO - Kashima University has expelled four medical students for pelting
>other students with human brains.
>
>School officials say the three men and one woman were dissecting cadavers in
>the science laboratory when one of the males removed part of a cerebral
>cortex from a corpse's skull and threw it at one of the other medical
>students.
>
>Within minutes a "brain fight" had broken out.
>
>The students then reportedly opened the windows of the second-floor lab and
>began throwing the brains down on unwitting passersby on the street below.
>One girl was hit in the face and required treatment at the university's
>emergency room.
>
>School security officers say they're fairly certain that more people were
>involved in the brain-throwing but only four were witnessed.
>
>The expelled students said they didn't plan the brain fight. One of them
>said, "It just sort of happened." He blamed the odd behavior on the pressure
>of constant study and lack of sleep.
>
> "We just had to let off some steam," admitted Ayako Hanyu, 19. "I guess
>things got a little out of hand."
>
> But Dean Shiuro Tatsuno refuses to budge on his decision to expel the
>students.
>
> "We realize that our medical students are under pressure," said Dean
>Tatsuno.
>
> "But we expect our future doctors and nurses to conduct themselves like
>ladies and gentlemen at all times."
>

Raves produce a TAZ or Temporary Autonomous Zone, according to writer Hakim
Bay. But then there's the comedown, back to the real world. So how can we
build a Permanent Autonomous Zone, where we can live peaceful, productive
and mind-expanded lives. Well Island Group at http://wwww.island.org doesn't
have all the answers. We are a family of people who are trying to find them
together.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 18 02:41:06 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA11661; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 02:41:06 -0800
Received: from orion.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA11654; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 02:41:04 -0800
Received: (from star@localhost) by orion.sfsu.edu (8.7.1/8.7.1) id CAA08257; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 02:40:56 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 18 Jan 1996 02:40:55 -0800 (PST)
From: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: star@orion
To: Michael Standish <standish@c2.org>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re:Doing The Right Thing
In-Reply-To: <199601152100.NAA14964@infinity.c2.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960118002132.29799A-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The conversation to date:

> quoth Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
> 
(Michael, I like that "quoth Starchild" bit!)

> >        Most parties search people at the door.  This always bothers me a
> >little bit, because it implies a lack of trust.  It implies that I cannot
> >be trusted not to bring weapons in which I would use to threaten the
> >health or safety of others.  I kind of feel like when I come dressed in
> >happy, fun clothing, with a smile on my face, it should be obvious to the
> >security that I don't need to be searched.  Search those scowling guys in
> >the bandanas over there, if you feel the need to search someone.
> 
...and on Monday Jan. 15, Michael Standish <standish@c2.org> shared:

>         Talk about a vibe killer for the people who do get searched. I sure
> wouldn't want to be the one who had to explain why they were being searched
> and not other people. What would I tell them? "Gee I'm sorry but I've just
> made a snap judgment based solely on how you look and it seems you're not
> wearing a rave approved, shit eating grin and that bandana is associated
> with gang members and people of color you know" If you feel like you're not
> trusted when everybody is being searched, think how you'd feel if you were
> the only one getting searched.

	Well, when you put it that way, I wouldn't want to be the one to have 
to explain to some people why only they were being searched either.  Really 
I wasn't advocating this as a preferred solution, only saying that when I 
am being searched, this is my instinctive reaction.  I would like to 
think that searching only those who looked like potential troublemakers 
would encourage people to dress and act more friendly in order to avoid 
being searched, but I realize that unfortunately it is more likely 
that the result would be what Michael describes above than that the 
searchees would take the hint and adopt a less intimidating attitude.

>         There's also more to look for than just weapons. There's markers,
> spray paint, glass containers and nitrous tanks. Even the nicest raver can
> break a glass bottle and thus risk cutting someone's foot. I've worked
> parties where we didn't search people, and the space ended up so covered
> with tags that we could never get permission to use the space again. I've
> also worked F&F where we didn't search anybody and had no problems. It's a
> tough call, but for a party the size of the Gathering I would definitely
> search everyone.
> 
	You're right Michael, it is a tough call.  But after careful 
thought, I would have to say the best policy is to search no one.  Some 
of you are thinking yeah, right, you're living on another planet.  But 
when you think about it, it's all an expectations game.  I haven't been 
to the opera recently, but I don't think they search the crowds at the 
opera house.  Are opera-goers inherently less violent than ravers?  Does 
all the talk about love and community in our scene really stack up to no 
more than a facade for a violence-prone group of people who must be 
searched when gathered en masse?  
	I don't believe this is true.  I think some simple tactics on the 
part of promoters can reduce the risk of violence on the part of 
partygoers to almost nothing without the need to search people.  
	First, promote your party carefully.  Select images for your 
fliers and a message for your voicemail that are unlikely to attract 
negative elements.  Ideally, the sole or predominate means of promotion 
should be on a personal level.  When you are personally invited, by phone 
or in person, to attend a party by one of the people putting it on, I 
think you are more likely to want to avoid creating trouble at the event, 
besides being more likely to attend in the first place.
	Also, I don't know about the rest of you, but I can't think of 
anyone I know, and this includes people of all different races, who I 
feel would be a security risk at a party.  This says to me that either 
people who do not know any ravers are showing up at raves, or some ravers 
are choosing their friends a bit indiscriminately.  Personally I cannot 
see associating with the kind of person who would bring a weapon to a 
rave with *any* possibility of using it aggressively.  If this is just 
me, please let me know.
	Second, treat people with love and respect.  If despite your best 
efforts, you end up with a crowd in line at your event that looks like 
they could pose a problem, greet everybody with a hug and a smile at the 
door, ask them to treat the space and their fellow party-goers with love 
and respect, and with this in mind whether there is anything they would 
like to leave at the door and pick up later.  Don't hire brutish security 
people who are only too ready to push people around or pick a fight.  The 
presence of police barricades, and paraphenalia like walkie-talkies 
and security jackets associated with large scale concerts and such create 
the perception that the promoters are expecting trouble, and 
paradoxically make it more likely that their expectations will be met.
	Finally, as far as bottles and that sort of thing, I think they 
are an acceptable risk.  If one breaks, clean it up.  You can't present a 
totally safe environment, nor should you try.  For one thing it would 
mean keeping all the lights on continually so that no one would 
accidentally trip and fall or injure someone else with an elbow or such.
Just my two dollars and twenty-two cents...   ;)

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

	I think the only DJ's who don't have huge ego's are Laurent Garnier and
Superstar DJ Keoki...yup..you can just waltz right on up and give 'em a biggggg
hoooooge hug.  Pretty humble guyz...down to earth...subtle..*blink blink*....
Is the sarcasm thick enough yet? 8)
	I've met a lot of really REALLY cool people who spin (ie. DJ's), but
only a couple of bigger names that were/are really nice.  Some people have the
ego's to begin with, and the popularity only makes it bigger.  Generally, a dj
that is true to the people and him/herself does it for the love of the music and
the love of the ritual of dance...it's hard to have an over-inflated ID without
the help of others putting one on a pedestal.

besides.......

I'm the best!!!!  EVERYONE ELSE WORSHIPS ME!!!!!  I AM DJ GOD!!!!!  *YARRRR*

heh heh...ok...j/k!   =P

Sabin Cloud
AKA

My computer tells me that on Tue, 16 Jan 1996, Diane shared:

>      
> Rick, I am so glad that you uphold the idea of making and sharing *vibe* rather 
> than going out looking for it.  Sometimes, we all want to be nurtured and look 
> for a good vibe party or group to hang with but ultimately, we all know we can 
> tap into this energy on our own...we've just forgotten how to on a natural 
> basis.  Music, dance, and raving plays an important role by overloading our 
> physical senses allowing us to override our egos (or sense of self) and to 
> reattune our spiritual self to the connective energy we all share.
> 
> I believe that as a group, if we are to progress in our beliefs of higher 
> consciousness, after gaining awareness comes sharing and education of what we've
> discovered.  Perhaps a group of sfravers might want to consider "juicing a jam" 
> with me. I've done this with another dance group where we all attend a 
> particular party once a month and converge with smiles, hugs, and tons of luvin'
> energy.  This might also be a way for alot of us who haven't met to connect too!
>  After doing this a few times, the community can grow in numbers and 
> interactions outside of raves as people look forward to attending an event 
> that's being juiced based on positive energy.
> 
> So if any of you want to join me in this endeavor, let me know and we can blast 
> our luv phasers sometime in early February.

Dear Family,

	Back in 1992 around the time I first started going to parties I 
remember meeting some ravers who were part of something called the San 
Jose Posse, a group that sounded like it might have had (has?) something 
like this in mind... Anybody hear of them or know if they're still around?
	This has been another of those little "How to make a better 
scene?" thoughts floating around at the back of my brain, and big hugzz 
to Diane & Rick for reviving it.
	I thought before about the idea of everyone wearing something 
distinctive, such as bright colored raingear... was never quite sure if 
such a move would bring people closer together or create new divisions.  
Any thoughts?

My computer tells me that on Wed, 17 Jan 1996, Sasa shared:

> What is the Caberet License?  BTW, which permits are required to make
> a perty legal?
> 
>   v
> SASA

Good fucking question!  I hope someone who knows the ins and outs of the 
permit and licensing process will post a lengthy response to this.  It's 
the kind of information that could surely do us all a world of good if we 
spread it around and pool our knowledge.

As far as my personal knowledge, the word is spelled "cabaret", and the 
American Heritage Dictionary offers this:

 (kab1-rE2) n.
1. A restaurant or nightclub providing short programs of live entertainment.
2. The floor show presented by such a restaurant or nightclub.

Maybe someone would also be interested in contacting Da Mayor's office 
and finding out what his policy on granting permits/licenses will be?  
This might give us a good clue as to whether his administration will live 
up to the expectations of some of the more optimistic among us (myself 
regrettably not included in said company)...

				<<< Starchild >>>

Dear Bruce,

	Glad to see you on this list!  Didn't know you were a 
subscriber... 
	For those of you who haven't heard of Bruce, he is the author of 
a neat book called "Extasy: The MDMA Story."  I've seen him at a couple 
events, including the first Orb party at the Warfield, and enjoyed 
pointing him out to people as "the guy who wrote the book on E".  :)
	I haven't yet had a chance to read Hakim Bey's (correct spelling) 
book on Temporary Autonomous Zones, not even sure if that's the exact 
title, but I was fortunate enough to stumble across a spoken word tape of 
his entitled simply T.A.Z. at Streetlight Records on Market Street for 
$2.50, and it's got some wonderful philosophic stuff on it.  He's truly 
an original thinker, and a very cogent one, imho.
	This concept of a Permanent Autonomous Zone excites me very much...
Libertarian computer programmer Eric Klein of Las Vegas Nevada has 
something like this in mind I believe.  He has plans for the construction 
of a new country in the Carribean, in the form of a man-made floating 
city in international waters off the coast of Panama.  Eric has raised 
money and marketed t-shirts & other paraphenalia to pay for the 
construction of a scale model which last I heard was going to be going on 
display in Las Vegas.  The cost of building this new country called 
Oceania is huge, in the billions, and for this reason many have given his 
"Atlantis Project" little chance of success, but what he wants to do is 
truly inspirational.  In Oceania, you would be free to do whatever you 
wanted as long as you didn't harm anyone else, the only exception being 
the export of prohibited substances to countries banning such substances, 
to avoid bringing the wrath of the U.S. and others down upon the new 
nation.  Anyone would be free to move there and buy, rent, or build 
space, if I remember correctly.
	Eric can be contacted at the email address listed in the header 
of this message.

Yours In Liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

I was just wondering if anyone would be interested in doing something like
this. Have a Huge picnic at a park, perhaps Vasona in Los Gatos (great park)
or maybe at a beach. At a park we might have to bring a boom box with
everyone favorite mix tape or CD. At a beach we might get away with a sound
system. I have a BBQ that is as long as a bed of a pickup, which has plenty
of room for everyone food, ribs, chicken, steak, hamburger, hot dogs, veggie
stuff. If everyone brought something we could have a really good time. It a
good chance to meet everyone outside of a rave. That way we can sit and talk
or do what ever. If this sounds like a good Idea, I can check out what it
take and all the rules to reserve a picnic area at Vasona. They have BBQ pits
there too. If everyone wants to have it at a beach. With a little help from a
couple people we can take my big BBS onto the beach. I think this would be a
good oppurtunity(ms) to meet one another that we don't know and see familiar
faces as well. A great chance to get closer to one another and have a really
good time. So what does everyone think? Let me know.
 
Tim (knucklehead)

Subject: RE:Cabaret Licenses

Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I posted the original question. My understanding of Cabaret Licences is they
are issued to businesses such as nightclubs and allow them to operate more
freely than bars---they can admit minors (I believe) as well as remain open
after 2am. I believe you would not need one to do a one-time event in a 
wharehouse.

***Important*** We may have a few very small opportunities to enhance our
situation with the new Brown administration BUT we have to be careful and
intelligent. We need to inform ourselves of the history behind the shutdown
of raves in SF. We have to police ourselves (promoters and party-goers) and
we need to work together.

From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: More on Searching etc.
Message-ID: <960118174341_71165.755_GHL95-2@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I agree that searching people is really a problem -- I notice that certain
locations bring out a rougher crowd, and frankly I feel a little relieved to
know that some sort of quick search for weapons is done at the door.  

On the other hand, it can really go too far.  At the Gathering, I was so
thoroughly searched it fully ruined my night.  I mean, I was frisked top to
bottom, pockets emptied, and she even opened up my WALLET and CIGARETTE PACK and
BOX OF MINTS and confiscated my simple herbal stuff.  Now, I'm not some scary
person.  I'm an older smiling woman, in line by herself, and I was wearing a big
funny red hat with Christmas stuff on it, and a green and white jumpsuit --
obviously a free spirit and in no imaginable way someone who would inspire
suspicion by a security guard.

As a result of feeling violated that way, I really did NOT have a good time at
the Gathering, sorry to say.

I do notice that security is often tougher in neighborhoods where the locals are
a little rougher than the usual ravers might be.  Do I want gangs with weapons
at parties?  Of course not.  Maybe we could have signs at the entry point
specifying what's being searched for - e.g. "Searching for Weapons and Alcohol"
- and then ask people to take what they don't want confiscated back to their
cars -- and do the searching in a non-agressive, non-militaristic way?  It would
be nice not to do it at all, but we have to be realistic.






From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 18 10:02:21 1996

BEGIN QUOTE FROM Starchild:
->
->
->	You're right Michael, it is a tough call.  But after careful 
->thought, I would have to say the best policy is to search no one.  Some 
->of you are thinking yeah, right, you're living on another planet.  But 
->when you think about it, it's all an expectations game.  I haven't been 
->to the opera recently, but I don't think they search the crowds at the 
->opera house.  Are opera-goers inherently less violent than ravers?  Does 
->all the talk about love and community in our scene really stack up to no 
->more than a facade for a violence-prone group of people who must be 
->searched when gathered en masse?  


Sorry to bust your bubble, but one group in particular is none to common
at opera houses and are all too common at raves - those who deal in
illegal drugs.  Lot's of black-market money often means personal protection
devices, such as weapons.

At 11:53 PM 1/17/96, Bruce Ehrlich - Mindmedia wrote:
>Raves produce a TAZ or Temporary Autonomous Zone, according to writer Hakim
>Bay. But then there's the comedown, back to the real world. So how can we
>build a Permanent Autonomous Zone, where we can live peaceful, productive
>and mind-expanded lives. Well Island Group at http://wwww.island.org doesn't
>have all the answers. We are a family of people who are trying to find them
>together.

        This has been a recurrant thought with me too: how does one
implement something as ephemeral and beautiful as a rave (which i view
mostly as a state of conditions which is a context for the creation of a
new state of mind) into something permanent and practical?
        From Bey's "PAZ" handout (a cheap and ugly 1 page photocopied thing
with handwriting worse than mine on the 'cover' saying "PAZ: the permanent
autonomous zone." Gotta love it!).
        "TAZ-theory tries to concern itself with existing or emergin
situations rather than pure utopianism.  All over the world people are
leaving or "disappearing" themselves from the Grid of Alienation and
seeking ways to restore human contact [but _we_ already know this, don't
we? -B]. An interesting example of this on the level of "urban folk
culture" can be found in the proliferation of hobby networks and
conferences. [like, oh, SFraves & raves in general :) -B]."
        He goes on to ask "What about a poetique (a "way of making") and a
politique (a "way of living together") for the "Permanent" TAZ or ("PAZ")?
What about the actual relation between temporariness and permanence? And
how can the PAZ renew and refresh itself periodically with the "festival"
aspect of the TAZ?"

        Hmm..good question! Isn't one of the beauties of raving the fact
that it doesn't happen all the time? Beauty (for me at least) is often
something that is very sponaneous, ephemeral and completely beyond
language.  Perhaps there _isn't_ necessarily a split between the Temporary
nature of the TAZ and the Permanent nature of the PAZ, probably to see them
as mutually exclusive would be to fall into the mind-trap of Cartesian
dichotomies that has screwed the west up so much. Rather see the two as two
aspects of the same whole :)
        For me, right now, i can create somethign of a PAZ within my own
life, by simply realizing a few crucial but small things: one is that i
have an influence on my environment, another is that i know what it feels
like to have higher states of consciousness than an 'average day' and i
know that those states are tied in with 'the big picture' and that
increases my sense of self (that is, self as part of a larger whole, not my
ego or anything!:) and self-confidence. So, to make small TAZ's all the
time is some sort of reach for a PAZ. And, for me, that means smiling at
random people when i walk down the street.  In the situation that i'm in
it's very uncommon and when i do it, it probably snaps people out of their
usual frame of mind for a second (a temporary second) and they will often
look away immediately, but for a second we had human contanct and i _know_
that they're walking away and *thinking differently* even in a subtle way.
Whether they're thinking i'm baked out of my mind, or whatever, it doesn't
matter just so long as there's that little tweek going on somewhere. :) I
know you DO think differently, your thoughts go onto a completely different
tangent when this happens to you because it's happened to me many a time.
        Anyways, that technique of shocking people (in a nice way!) into
different ways of thinking is small but it relies on something that the
surrealists and dadaists knew: we all begin to expect things and when
things are subtley altered, it can flip 'reality' upside down for a second.
        So, that's some ideas for ya, i'll shaddup now :)
                peace,
                        brad

ps-->a lot of hakim bey's writings on the web can be accessed through my
'links' page if you want to read more. He/She/They (hakim bey is a
pseudonym) is/are one of my fave writers and there is a lot of stuff that
hakim bey has written that has really influenced my way of thinking :) My
URL is below!

At 5:14 AM 1/18/96, Starchild wrote:
>In Oceania, you would be free to do whatever you
>wanted as long as you didn't harm anyone else, the only exception being
>the export of prohibited substances to countries banning such substances,
>to avoid bringing the wrath of the U.S. and others down upon the new
>nation.  Anyone would be free to move there and buy, rent, or build
>space, if I remember correctly.

        I think that this is not as 'out there' as it may seem. I've been
reading about complex systems and 'hive minds' and other things in a really
cool book called "out of control" by Kevin Kelly (exec. editor of wired)
and one of the things that it sparked in me is this thought:
        If ppl just did what they were DRAWN to do, what they FELT they
should do intuitively rather than what is expected of them by the demands
of our present economic/social structure we'd end up with a really diverse
and complex system of social interaction. Like, if you didn't follow the
whole "get married @ this age, take on this kind of profession depending on
your social/racial/gender/whatever background" scheme you would end up with
total diversity and the system itself would be self-regulating i think.
Like, if all were closely networked (like..umm..on the net? :) there would
be an awareness of "we need more accountants (just for example!)" and so
that drive to be an accountant would be spawned in someone. Any system will
oscillate between chaos and order (or yin and yang or whatever) so that
whenever there would be an overabundance of something the 'hive mind' of
those in the system would recursively feed back the info to the
constituents which would affect thier "Draws" to certain ways of life. Of
course, this wouldn't be a utopia for everyone, there will still be those
within who confuse their draw from the whole network with the draw for
thier ego's need to feed on others by controlling them but hey, nothing's
perfect...yet! ;) haha
        peace,
                brad

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Oceania Project
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This message is in response to the "Permanent Autonomous Zone" thread that 
mentioned the Atlantis project.  If you don't feel this is rave related, 
please skip this message, but the Atlantis project proposes an extremely 
drug-legal, non-intrusive form of government where raving would probably be 
a way of life, so I thought I'd open up some discussion.

Y'know, I've got to tell you, I got on that page and checked it out.  It'll 
never work.  For those of you that haven't seen it yet, it goes something 
like this:  The Atlantis Project seeks to build a floating city somewhere in 
the Carribean. The major industries would be tourism and biotech.  There are 
no drug laws, no government regulation of business and trade with the 
exception of restricted exports on illegal products, and no taxation.  
Expansion and development of "land" resources would be privately financed.

This guy, Eric Klein, somehow thinks that the law enforcement, emergency 
services, the military, sanitation, communication, health care, welfare, 
executive, judicial, and legislative bodies of government, etc., etc., will 
somehow just exist without any visible means of support.  There is no 
taxation of *any* kind.  None.  According to the "constitution", the only 
source of revenue for the government will be via court fees.  That's it.  Do 
you know how many law suits it would take just to handle environmentally 
safe sanitation?  People would have to regularly sue each other just to have 
emergency services like firefighters and paramedics in place.

About the Oceania constitution:  this mail reader wouldn't handle the size 
of the rebuttal this document requires.  It's a joke, IMHO.  There's a 
business proposal.  Same.  Still, the basic premise, of building your own 
nation, is a fun one.

Check it out:  http://www.oceania.org

S

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 18 13:32:38 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA06370; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 13:32:38 -0800

Received: from ehill.vip.best.com (ehill.vip.best.com [205.149.180.37]) by mailx.best.com (950911.SGI.8.6.12.PATCH825/8.6.5) with SMTP id VAA06558; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 21:34:45 GMT
Date: Thu, 18 Jan 1996 21:34:45 GMT
Message-Id: <199601182134.VAA06558@mailx.best.com>
X-Sender: ehill@best.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Eric Hill <ehill@best.com>
Subject: Re: Vibe Spread, Family Size[was: Re: Synthetic Review] 
Cc: nphilip@netcom.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 04:28 AM 1/18/96 -0800, you wrote:
>
>Dear Family,
>
>	Back in 1992 around the time I first started going to parties I 
>remember meeting some ravers who were part of something called the San 
>Jose Posse, a group that sounded like it might have had (has?) something 
>like this in mind... Anybody hear of them or know if they're still around?

Some of us are!

I don't know who you might have met, or at what point, but the San Jose
Posse was just the group of ravers (5 or 10 when the name crystallized) who
lived in San Jose and went to the parties in the city. Since it was the
early days of the SF scene, there wasn't much going on anywhere: Brand new
Wicked every Fri, Brand new Come-Unity every Weds., eventually Toon Town
every Sat., Candlestick FMRs. So when Alan or Quart-Knee or Malachy or
whomever would see the pack of our southbay faces approaching the door that
they didn't see the rest of the week or during the day, we would hear "San
Jose Posse!" ring into the alley. Christmas '91 we all got "San Jose Posse"
medallions (any SF'ers have an "Earth Posse" one still?).

A point I'd like to make is that there was no purpose to all of this except
to go where we could hear the best fucking music we could find (can I get a
witness for 339 Jessie Wickeds?). We felt like outsiders already since we
were the only ones who weren't Brits and we had to travel from the clueless
city we lived in to find acceptable music. So we would go, squrm through our
various ID problems, find a good place to hear the speakers and regroup in
the morning. I can't really remember how much anybody else in those rooms
was going off, we didn't care what anyone else was doing, whether they be
snorting lines in the bathroom or sitting like a wall flower, we were there
with the music in our ears. Nothing else mattered, we did it for ourselves.
I can't say how infectious this was for other people, but from the way I
read how many people look to others for a "vibe," I imagine we helped the
party, since we got our clues from the speakers with DJs fucking ripping it
up on the other end of the wire.

Rob Campbell
Tammy Price
Gene Kim
Micha Collins
Mike Carrico
Charmaine Jacques
Nick Philip
Eric Hill




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 18 13:37:44 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA06747; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 13:37:44 -0800

On Thu, 18 Jan 1996 cloud@cats.ucsc.edu wrote:

What is wrong with Laurent Garnier, I have never heard that he had a huge 
ego, please elaborate.  Judging someone or saying they have a big ego on 
the account of hersay or just briefly meeting them is pretty harsh.  I know
 I wouldn't like to be judged by someone just on the basis of seeing them 
for 3 minutes or something.  Peoples actions can often be 
misintrepreted.  Keoki is another story, anyone who call themselves a 
"Superstar" does not belong in the Underground Rave scence.  What makes a dj 
different from anyone else,  that is like saying people who fish for 
Tuna have big egos.  I could see how an beginnig fisherman could get 
annoying to a guy like Mr Starkist, if he sat there and didn't fish 
staring at Mr Starkist and bugging him about 
what kind of net he uses, what the biggest fish he has ever caught is, 
how long has he been fishing, and how long his pole is.

derek

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 18 15:36:39 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA16113; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 15:36:39 -0800

Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu (uclink.berkeley.edu [128.32.155.3]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.6.12/8.6.12) with ESMTP id PAA10022; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 15:36:34 -0800

From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Raving History (was Re: Vibe Spread, Family Size) 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: ehill@best.com
In-Reply-To: <199601182134.VAA06558@mailx.best.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9601181449.C28475-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey All,
	Eric's post about the San Jose Posse got me thinking about
something I have wanted to ask about for awhile, SF rave history.  Since
the timing seems to be right I thought I'd ask people to share what they
know.  I know quite a few people have been on this list for awhile and
know a lot, and I'd love to hear about it (and I'm sure others would,
too:).  When I first got on this list, people were doing their bios which
inherently contained sf rave history. Since then, I've been meaning to ask
for more.  This has already been touched on before, I'm sure, but maybe
the timing is right again, considering the vibe and interest the list has
been generating as of late.  I've checked out the sfraves homepage when I
can, and I think there's a little on there, but I don't have frequent
access to the world wide web to do more indepth "research."  So, I'd love
to hear/read people's contributions about sfrave history, and I imagine
others would, too. 

I'll start it off with my little contribution:  When I was a freshman at
UC Berkeley in 1991, the first friend I met was Brian Behlendorf.  He was
from L.A., I was from the suburbs of Lake Tahoe:] (very rural:), so I had
never heard of raves, nor even drugs like E.  He came up here right after
the peak in the So-Cal rave scene and was always looking for parties in
the Bay Area.  They existed, but I guess they were quite fragmented, and I
never went with him because I was in study-mode in those days.  I remember
him going with a bunch of friends and they always had a great time.  I
remember Brian was very nostalgic about the L.A. scene and sought to
create it up here.  I remember how into music he was, he had more CD's
than I had ever seen in my life!  He made me a mixed tape, not of techno,
but other cool music, that was quite different from the heavy metal I
had:) Anyway, to make this short, I remember when he started to put
together sfraves and even when he had the "rave-nic," I think in Tilden
Park.  We lost touch when he left school, but last year when I got into
raving, and then found this list, it was great to see how much he had done
for the scene.  I remember when he started the list, and it is 
wonderful to see how his contributions have melded things here in 
the Bay Area.  Hats off to Brian--I always knew he'd do what he
wanted! 

Waiting to hear more history,
kc

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 18 15:39:26 1996

In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960118002132.29799A-100000@orion>

On Thu, 18 Jan 1996, Starchild wrote:

> 
> The conversation to date:
> 
> > quoth Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
> > 
> (Michael, I like that "quoth Starchild" bit!)
> 
> > >        Most parties search people at the door.  This always bothers me a
> > >little bit, because it implies a lack of trust.  It implies that I cannot
> > >be trusted not to bring weapons in which I would use to threaten the
> > >health or safety of others.  I kind of feel like when I come dressed in
> > >happy, fun clothing, with a smile on my face, it should be obvious to the
> > >security that I don't need to be searched.  Search those scowling guys in
> > >the bandanas over there, if you feel the need to search someone.
> > 
> ...and on Monday Jan. 15, Michael Standish <standish@c2.org> shared:
> 
> >         Talk about a vibe killer for the people who do get searched. I sure
> > wouldn't want to be the one who had to explain why they were being searched
> > and not other people. What would I tell them? "Gee I'm sorry but I've just
> > made a snap judgment based solely on how you look and it seems you're not
> > wearing a rave approved, shit eating grin and that bandana is associated
> > with gang members and people of color you know" If you feel like you're not
> > trusted when everybody is being searched, think how you'd feel if you were
> > the only one getting searched.
> 
> 	Well, when you put it that way, I wouldn't want to be the one to have 
> to explain to some people why only they were being searched either.  Really 
> I wasn't advocating this as a preferred solution, only saying that when I 
> am being searched, this is my instinctive reaction.  I would like to 
> think that searching only those who looked like potential troublemakers 
> would encourage people to dress and act more friendly in order to avoid 
> being searched,

John Wayne Gasey was a childrens clown by profession. :>

Derek





 but I realize that unfortunately it is more likely 
> that the result would be what Michael describes above than that the 
> searchees would take the hint and adopt a less intimidating attitude.
> 
> >         There's also more to look for than just weapons. There's markers,
> > spray paint, glass containers and nitrous tanks. Even the nicest raver can
> > break a glass bottle and thus risk cutting someone's foot. I've worked
> > parties where we didn't search people, and the space ended up so covered
> > with tags that we could never get permission to use the space again. I've
> > also worked F&F where we didn't search anybody and had no problems. It's a
> > tough call, but for a party the size of the Gathering I would definitely
> > search everyone.
> > 
> 	You're right Michael, it is a tough call.  But after careful 
> thought, I would have to say the best policy is to search no one.  Some 
> of you are thinking yeah, right, you're living on another planet.  But 
> when you think about it, it's all an expectations game.  I haven't been 
> to the opera recently, but I don't think they search the crowds at the 
> opera house.  Are opera-goers inherently less violent than ravers?  Does 
> all the talk about love and community in our scene really stack up to no 
> more than a facade for a violence-prone group of people who must be 
> searched when gathered en masse?  
> 	I don't believe this is true.  I think some simple tactics on the 
> part of promoters can reduce the risk of violence on the part of 
> partygoers to almost nothing without the need to search people.  
> 	First, promote your party carefully.  Select images for your 
> fliers and a message for your voicemail that are unlikely to attract 
> negative elements.  Ideally, the sole or predominate means of promotion 
> should be on a personal level.  When you are personally invited, by phone 
> or in person, to attend a party by one of the people putting it on, I 
> think you are more likely to want to avoid creating trouble at the event, 
> besides being more likely to attend in the first place.
> 	Also, I don't know about the rest of you, but I can't think of 
> anyone I know, and this includes people of all different races, who I 
> feel would be a security risk at a party.  This says to me that either 
> people who do not know any ravers are showing up at raves, or some ravers 
> are choosing their friends a bit indiscriminately.  Personally I cannot 
> see associating with the kind of person who would bring a weapon to a 
> rave with *any* possibility of using it aggressively.  If this is just 
> me, please let me know.
> 	Second, treat people with love and respect.  If despite your best 
> efforts, you end up with a crowd in line at your event that looks like 
> they could pose a problem, greet everybody with a hug and a smile at the 
> door, ask them to treat the space and their fellow party-goers with love 
> and respect, and with this in mind whether there is anything they would 
> like to leave at the door and pick up later.  Don't hire brutish security 
> people who are only too ready to push people around or pick a fight.  The 
> presence of police barricades, and paraphenalia like walkie-talkies 
> and security jackets associated with large scale concerts and such create 
> the perception that the promoters are expecting trouble, and 
> paradoxically make it more likely that their expectations will be met.
> 	Finally, as far as bottles and that sort of thing, I think they 
> are an acceptable risk.  If one breaks, clean it up.  You can't present a 
> totally safe environment, nor should you try.  For one thing it would 
> mean keeping all the lights on continually so that no one would 
> accidentally trip and fall or injure someone else with an elbow or such.
> Just my two dollars and twenty-two cents...   ;)
> 
> Much love,
> 				<<< Starchild >>>
> 
> 
>

I went to the Top both nights last weekend, bringing back memories of 
91-92.  Both nights were pretty good - nice crowd, new music, and
low cover charge ;).  Friday was more hiphop/triphop (while I was there),
though you may hear some house sometime, and Saturday was everybody's
favorite, jungle.  Overall, it's pretty casual, and I didn't miss the
stress of long lines, heavy security, bust potential and the large investment
prevalent in the big parties.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Hi everybody :)
 I am not anywhere near the sf area, Im up in here in west coast Canada, 
and I love to see whats going on with your guys most escellent party 
scene. Im comin down in a few months too, so i wanna stay 'up' on whats 
going down :)
 Anyway, Ive been following this DJ's have big ego's thing and just wanted 
to throw in my .02 worth.
 Ive been playing music for quite a while, but only recently begain 
playing infront of crowds again. A few parties later I have friends, 
aquaintances, and ppl Ive never met come to me and practically tell me 
they love me because of my set (ok so we have some good trEats hErE too 
:). I love to play music, and every set is a learning experience, but this 
is incredibly humbling. I literally blush and thank ppl to death for 
coming to me after, it rrreally means a lot to me to know that they 'got 
off' to MY MUSIC :) The other day someone told a friend of mine they 
thought I had a fat head because of my dj'ing and this rrrally et me off. 
I am the least egotistical person on the planet..and I had to find out why 
he said this. My only explanation, that it was a hard night...no monitor, 
barely hear the cue, and after my set i was exhausted. My head was done 
in, in morE ways than onE. He came to me...said he enjoyed...talked for a 
bit..and I just smiled at him...didn't say a word. Ok so there were some 
outside circumstances that were involved, but it made me unhappy to think 
that he thought I was fat-headed. I literally fu*&ing love ppl telling me 
they had a great time. Its half the fun of being a dj...

cont...sorry my mailer is whacky...






    for dj's, musicians, artists, web-mistress'/masters and net-surfers

opinion...Ive read a lot about Keoki being a twat, but Ive never met

whack, but I dunno.

what we all appreciate, is being known (doesnt everyone?), but most of 
all, go and tell the dj. As a matter of fact do that first. We may be out 
of sorts, but believe me a person playing music does not a dj make. The dj 
is just like you and me. we like attention, we like having friends, we 
like a smile. If I could be friends with all the ppl i play for, Id be the 
happiest man on the planet.
We also deal with alot of dinks...and sometimes you might have been right 
after one of them. You know how insulting it is..to be told your bunk? Its 
a personal thing..and it hurts.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 18 17:39:15 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA24906; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 17:39:15 -0800
Received: from ix10.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA24899; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 17:39:11 -0800
Received: from  by ix10.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id RAA23279; Thu, 18 Jan 1996 17:38:36 -0800
Date: Thu, 18 Jan 1996 17:38:36 -0800
Message-Id: <199601190138.RAA23279@ix10.ix.netcom.com>
From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: More info on The Experiment
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

I've been getting a lot of questions from people about how to use the 
IRC.  So, I decided to post this for those who are both interested in 
doing it but don't know how to use the IRC.  I'm kinda fumbling my way 
thru this myself, so please try it ahead of time so you can talk by 8 
pm!  These instructions are for people (I assume most of you are like 
this) who just use plain ol Unix accounts, with plain session 
terminals:

At the Unix prompt, type irc & hit enter.  This should get you into the 
IRC where from there you can enter a specific channel.
Once you're in, type "/join #sfraves" & hit enter.  This should put you 
into our sfraves channel, hopefully!  At that point, assuming you've 
made it thus far, anything you type normally & hit enter after will 
appear as dialogue on the screens of everybody else who's on that 
channel. Thus conversations can be carried on real time!  Commands you 
want to issue should be preceded by the "/" sign, i.e. if you want to 
change your nick to something else, type "/nick Shawna (or whatever)" 
and your nick will appear to everybody else as Shawna from then on.

I emailed a less detailed description to someone privately earlier, & 
they mailed me back saying it worked, so hopefully it will work for you 
guys too!

Hope to see you at 8 pm!

Love,
Shawna

hello..well, this posting was more to NE-raves.. it happened to bounce to SF, but, here we go:
 
>	I'm really curious about the scene in Brazil.  I lived in Bolivia for a 
>long time and visited Brazil including Rio.  It was an interesting city.  
>I was just wondering what the scene was like since I didn't think Rio was 
>necessarily "rave" oriented?  What's your story?  Are you familiar to the 
>U.S. scene? 

Until October, i was living in the US and working as a lawyer in DC. Sounds strange right??? yes.. I used to live in DC working on my master's degree in law. i am a lawyer here in Brazil, but I only did not stay in the U.S. because i did not pass the califormia bar. My specialization is Copyright, Trademarks and New media law

My interest in SF is because i have a cousin who lives there, and I used to go visit him sometimes. I love SF, and definitely i would have tried to find a job there..that's why i took the calif.bar instead of NY. I am also trying to get into Stanford, so, it would be good to at least have an idea to what goes around teh bay area.

Rio is not rave related at all..Raves are not popular or really well-known. Also, they are definitely not easy to find too. The rave crowd is a mix of gay people, technoheads, fashion victims and junkies. Unfortunately, many people tend to associate raves here only with "gay and lesbian parties". That's so wrong!! and that's why we are throwing the Qua-Qua events: parties not directed to the gay public, but solely to who's into music and vibe.

 
>	Your posts just came out of the blue on our San Francisco mailing 
>list and I was wondering what ties you had to our scene?
>	I was also wondering if your mixtape is available and what kind  
>of music you included.

My mixtape ia avaliable. the current one is more like Trancey stuff.. It doesn't cost anything, except that whoever is interested should send me a tape for teh copy. E-mail me personally and I can provide everyone with the address... The current tape is good, imHO, but i just hope i had time to do a newer one. I am stuck in a lawyer job that takes my whole day.


>	Thanks,
>		Kirsten
>
>$*$*$*$*$ 2 LINES REFORMATTED BY POPPER AT ax.apc.org $*$*$*$*$

You're welcome :) DIRCEU

One more thing:

My IRC is windows based, so I can immediately see an entire list of 
who's on the channel, but for those of you who are using strict Unix, 
once you get into #sfraves, type "/who #sfraves" to display a list of 
people who are already there.  Then you'll know who you're dealing 
with.  It'll probably take a bit to figure out who everybody is behind 
the nicks!

actually the idea of this kind of zone was started at least 2 years ago 
by aaron wynett, and jen parker, some of the many people behind - you 
guessed it - spaz - or 'semi permanent autonomous zone. for a while they 
lived in a warehouse south of market and called it the TAZ warehouse. the 
semi-permanent part evolved later. spaz then got twisted around to be an 
anacronym for just about anything those letters stood for... but that is 
all the story on this subject i know, in case y'all are interested!!!

kevin
:)

someone play 20 gigs a month, but gosh,

Dear Robert,

	Thanks for your thoughts...

My computer tells me that on Thu, 18 Jan 1996, Robert Smith shared:

> BEGIN QUOTE FROM Starchild:
> ->
> ->
> ->	You're right Michael, it is a tough call.  But after careful 
> ->thought, I would have to say the best policy is to search no one.  Some 
> ->of you are thinking yeah, right, you're living on another planet.  But 
> ->when you think about it, it's all an expectations game.  I haven't been 
> ->to the opera recently, but I don't think they search the crowds at the 
> ->opera house.  Are opera-goers inherently less violent than ravers?  Does 
> ->all the talk about love and community in our scene really stack up to no 
> ->more than a facade for a violence-prone group of people who must be 
> ->searched when gathered en masse?  
> 
> 
> Sorry to bust your bubble, but one group in particular is none to common
> at opera houses and are all too common at raves - those who deal in
> illegal drugs.  Lot's of black-market money often means personal protection
> devices, such as weapons.

	This is true, and suggests to me two possible solutions (besides 
the obvious do-nothing option and the ways to decrease the likelihood 
of violence at parties I outlined in the message you quote from above):
	(1) Try to remove the drugs from our scene, or
	(2) Try to remove the violence by getting them legalized, or at least 
		decriminalized.

	I opt for the latter.
