On Thu, 18 Jan 1996, Derek Oliver wrote:

> On Thu, 18 Jan 1996, Starchild wrote:
> 
> > 
> > The conversation to date:
> > 
> > > quoth Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
> > > 
> > (Michael, I like that "quoth Starchild" bit!)
> > 
> > > >        Most parties search people at the door.  This always bothers me a
> > > >little bit, because it implies a lack of trust.  It implies that I cannot
> > > >be trusted not to bring weapons in which I would use to threaten the
> > > >health or safety of others.  I kind of feel like when I come dressed in
> > > >happy, fun clothing, with a smile on my face, it should be obvious to the
> > > >security that I don't need to be searched.  Search those scowling guys in
> > > >the bandanas over there, if you feel the need to search someone.
> > > 
> > ...and on Monday Jan. 15, Michael Standish <standish@c2.org> shared:
> > 
> > >         Talk about a vibe killer for the people who do get searched. I sure
> > > wouldn't want to be the one who had to explain why they were being searched
> > > and not other people. What would I tell them? "Gee I'm sorry but I've just
> > > made a snap judgment based solely on how you look and it seems you're not
> > > wearing a rave approved, shit eating grin and that bandana is associated
> > > with gang members and people of color you know" If you feel like you're not
> > > trusted when everybody is being searched, think how you'd feel if you were
> > > the only one getting searched.
> > 
> > 	Well, when you put it that way, I wouldn't want to be the one to have 
> > to explain to some people why only they were being searched either.  Really 
> > I wasn't advocating this as a preferred solution, only saying that when I 
> > am being searched, this is my instinctive reaction.  I would like to 
> > think that searching only those who looked like potential troublemakers 
> > would encourage people to dress and act more friendly in order to avoid 
> > being searched,
> 

 John Wayne Gacey was a childrens clown by profession. ;)

Derek


> 
>  but I realize that unfortunately it is more likely 
> > that the result would be what Michael describes above than that the 
> > searchees would take the hint and adopt a less intimidating attitude.
> > 
> > >         There's also more to look for than just weapons. There's markers,
> > > spray paint, glass containers and nitrous tanks. Even the nicest raver can
> > > break a glass bottle and thus risk cutting someone's foot. I've worked
> > > parties where we didn't search people, and the space ended up so covered
> > > with tags that we could never get permission to use the space again. I've
> > > also worked F&F where we didn't search anybody and had no problems. It's a
> > > tough call, but for a party the size of the Gathering I would definitely
> > > search everyone.
> > > 
> > 	You're right Michael, it is a tough call.  But after careful 
> > thought, I would have to say the best policy is to search no one.  Some 
> > of you are thinking yeah, right, you're living on another planet.  But 
> > when you think about it, it's all an expectations game.  I haven't been 
> > to the opera recently, but I don't think they search the crowds at the 
> > opera house.  Are opera-goers inherently less violent than ravers?  Does 
> > all the talk about love and community in our scene really stack up to no 
> > more than a facade for a violence-prone group of people who must be 
> > searched when gathered en masse?  
> > 	I don't believe this is true.  I think some simple tactics on the 
> > part of promoters can reduce the risk of violence on the part of 
> > partygoers to almost nothing without the need to search people.  
> > 	First, promote your party carefully.  Select images for your 
> > fliers and a message for your voicemail that are unlikely to attract 
> > negative elements.  Ideally, the sole or predominate means of promotion 
> > should be on a personal level.  When you are personally invited, by phone 
> > or in person, to attend a party by one of the people putting it on, I 
> > think you are more likely to want to avoid creating trouble at the event, 
> > besides being more likely to attend in the first place.
> > 	Also, I don't know about the rest of you, but I can't think of 
> > anyone I know, and this includes people of all different races, who I 
> > feel would be a security risk at a party.  This says to me that either 
> > people who do not know any ravers are showing up at raves, or some ravers 
> > are choosing their friends a bit indiscriminately.  Personally I cannot 
> > see associating with the kind of person who would bring a weapon to a 
> > rave with *any* possibility of using it aggressively.  If this is just 
> > me, please let me know.
> > 	Second, treat people with love and respect.  If despite your best 
> > efforts, you end up with a crowd in line at your event that looks like 
> > they could pose a problem, greet everybody with a hug and a smile at the 
> > door, ask them to treat the space and their fellow party-goers with love 
> > and respect, and with this in mind whether there is anything they would 
> > like to leave at the door and pick up later.  Don't hire brutish security 
> > people who are only too ready to push people around or pick a fight.  The 
> > presence of police barricades, and paraphenalia like walkie-talkies 
> > and security jackets associated with large scale concerts and such create 
> > the perception that the promoters are expecting trouble, and 
> > paradoxically make it more likely that their expectations will be met.
> > 	Finally, as far as bottles and that sort of thing, I think they 
> > are an acceptable risk.  If one breaks, clean it up.  You can't present a 
> > totally safe environment, nor should you try.  For one thing it would 
> > mean keeping all the lights on continually so that no one would 
> > accidentally trip and fall or injure someone else with an elbow or such.
> > Just my two dollars and twenty-two cents...   ;)
> > 
> > Much love,
> > 				<<< Starchild >>>
> > 
> > 
> > 
> 
>

Thanks to all of you who showed up last night on #sfraves, albeit 
unsuccessfully!  I'm actually kinda glad to hear that there was 
something wrong with people's IRC clients, rather than think that all 
of you popped on and didn't speak a word to me!  As I had said before, 
I was having my own troubles, my own ISP sucks big time & suddenly (of 
course!) decided to get completely flaky on me right around our 
scheduled time!  It would kick me off & not let me back on, or the lag 
was so great that no one ever heard what I was saying.  Very annoying.  
Anyway, I will definitely want to try this again, when my isp settles 
down a bit (I think  it's having a tantrum right now), I'll post a time 
in the future.  Hope more of you are able to show!

Love,
Shawna

> 	I opt for the latter.

shawna: 

i think you guys should do this again!  im a irc fiend and would like to
chat with other people on EFnet.  vrave is good, but it lacks the chaos of
being one of 3000+ channels in the great ether cloud of the Inet (+ the
commands are unknown to me).  what i suggest we all do is to all log in to
the same host (provided they are not banning any particular isp: ours is
banned on a few of them).  .....a better thing is to go to the
lesser used underNET.  it is less prone to net-splits and lags. the 
server address is sanjose.ca.us.undernet.org, or for short "/server 
dal.net 7000" .... if not that method, then EFnet: 

irc2.ais.net 6680 (or 6650)
irc.ais.net 6680 (or 6650)
irc.colorado.edu
irc.neosoft.com
irc.mcs.net (netcom is banned)
irc.epix.com
irc.mit.edu
irc-2.mit.edu

anyhow, we can change servers to defeat lag time.  there are effective 
solutions to any problems that one may encounter..
 
so let us know when you do this again... it would be interesting & fun!

ciao!
mrfrog

before sfr started i was on a shoegazer/manchester music list, which 
occaisionally would have info about sf parties, this was back at the time when 
half the fun and all the work was just to find out about a party......so 
anyhow one day i remember a guy named vitamin B suggested that we take all the 
rave talk onto a devoted list sfraves!!! i think the first party i heard about 
on sfraves, though it might have been the previous list, was the now infamous 
Woopie Ball!!! the rest is history  :) 
 
----> 
	aaron 
---->

X-Orcl-Application: Mime-Version:  1.0

Hey All,
	Eric's post about the San Jose Posse got me thinking about
something I have wanted to ask about for awhile, SF rave history.  Since
the timing seems to be right I thought I'd ask people to share what they
know.  I know quite a few people have been on this list for awhile and
know a lot, and I'd love to hear about it (and I'm sure others would,
too:).  When I first got on this list, people were doing their bios which
inherently contained sf rave history. Since then, I've been meaning to ask
for more.  This has already been touched on before, I'm sure, but maybe
the timing is right again, considering the vibe and interest the list has
been generating as of late.  I've checked out the sfraves homepage when I
can, and I think there's a little on there, but I don't have frequent
access to the world wide web to do more indepth "research."  So, I'd love
to hear/read people's contributions about sfrave history, and I imagine
others would, too. 

I'll start it off with my little contribution:  When I was a freshman at
UC Berkeley in 1991, the first friend I met was Brian Behlendorf.  He was
from L.A., I was from the suburbs of Lake Tahoe:] (very rural:), so I had
never heard of raves, nor even drugs like E.  He came up here right after
the peak in the So-Cal rave scene and was always looking for parties in
the Bay Area.  They existed, but I guess they were quite fragmented, and I
never went with him because I was in study-mode in those days.  I remember
him going with a bunch of friends and they always had a great time.  I
remember Brian was very nostalgic about the L.A. scene and sought to
create it up here.  I remember how into music he was, he had more CD's
than I had ever seen in my life!  He made me a mixed tape, not of techno,
but other cool music, that was quite different from the heavy metal I
had:) Anyway, to make this short, I remember when he started to put
together sfraves and even when he had the "rave-nic," I think in Tilden
Park.  We lost touch when he left school, but last year when I got into
raving, and then found this list, it was great to see how much he had done
for the scene.  I remember when he started the list, and it is 
wonderful to see how his contributions have melded things here in 
the Bay Area.  Hats off to Brian--I always knew he'd do what he
wanted! 

Waiting to hear more history,
kc


--Boundary-2857422-0-0--

trying to eradicate.

I went to the Top both nights last weekend, bringing back memories of 
91-92.  Both nights were pretty good - nice crowd, new music, and
low cover charge ;).  Friday was more hiphop/triphop (while I was there),
though you may hear some house sometime, and Saturday was everybody's
favorite, jungle.  Overall, it's pretty casual, and I didn't miss the
stress of long lines, heavy security, bust potential and the large investment
prevalent in the big parties.

   Roots - Garth, Jeno & guests in the basement of 1015 Folsom and The
   Black Diamond - Felix the Dogge, Thomas + guests - in the lounge.
   10-4. 415.512.5713 415.675.5660
   
   cosmic lounge - space jazz, galactic grooves, jungle. DJs Caspar,
   Paul, Seth + special guests. cafe mars, 798 Brannan @ 7th. 10pm-2am.
   No cover.
   
   
   Reunion - Danny, Naz Cafe & guests. 21+, 9pm-, free. The Fulton Bar,
   1243 Fulton Mall, Fresno. 209.488.5332
   
   Europa - ambient + experimental industrial. DJs from House of Usher &
   Winter Gone By. $5, 21+, 9pm-3am. 540 Howard St - rear entrance, SF.
   415.789.7359

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.

       SF. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

	hey kids!

	this'll sound silly, but i filter my mail like crazy,
	and it seems like (i am still checking) sfraves mail
	gets deposited into my work mailbox instead of my
	sfraves mailbox if sfraves' address is in the Cc: line
	instead of the To: line.

	kind of silly, i know, but i do pretty much delete all
	sfr mail in my work box immediately, usually without
	reading it.

Hey kids,

	After two months of searching, I *finally* snagged the latest 
Autechre album, Tri Repetae.  I think it's a genius album, their best to 
date.  Highly recommended.
	I also recommend that everyone go and see City of the Lost 
Children.  This film has the most amazing set designs and imagery since 
Brazil.  The story's good, too.  It's in French, tho, but I think that 
adds to the mystique.  Go and see it.  It's super.

	Take care.  And thanks to everyone who answered my post about the 
mixing boards!
 
		jon "Le Beouf"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 19 14:13:46 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA04503; Fri, 19 Jan 1996 14:13:46 -0800
Received: from alpha.xerox.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id OAA04497; Fri, 19 Jan 1996 14:13:41 -0800
Received: from godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com ([13.242.128.10]) by alpha.xerox.com with SMTP id <53218(11)>; Fri, 19 Jan 1996 14:12:43 PST
Received: from beluga.adoc.xerox.com ([13.242.128.26]) by godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com with SMTP id <4647>; Fri, 19 Jan 1996 14:12:33 -0800
Received: from cc:Mail SMTPLINK 2.1 by beluga.adoc.xerox.com
	id AA822089794; Fri, 19 Jan 96 14:16:07 PST
Date: Fri, 19 Jan 1996 14:16:07 PST
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9600198220.AA822089794@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Herbal Energy Boosters
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     After getting the dreaded ravers cold last year, I've gone on a bit of 
     a health kick for '96.  The past few weeks I sampled several different 
     types of herbal energy boosters and thought I'd share what I 
     experienced:
     
     _Fungalore_ from Shamanic Tonics in Santa Cruz puts out a blend of 
     fungi and herbs that sells for ~$13 per bottle of 16 tablets.  The 
     dosage is 4 tablets and we used it as an alternative for Herbal E.  
     They caution you to not take more than 16 tablets in a 24 hour period. 
      Among the things it contains is Ginseng, Kola acuminata, ginseng, 
     Ephedra sinica and Ganoderma.  I don't know how it's distributed 
     because a friend gave it to me but it's very pleasant and I didn't 
     throw up, have stomach pains, or have any nasty bowel movements, etc.
     
     I took Fungalore (4 tabs initially and then 2 more several hours 
     later) in conjunction with DMAE, B5, PC55 (Twin Labs Phen... Choline 
     mix), and of course, C.  At the same time, I also took _UPtime_ which 
     has Chinese green tea, kola nut, ginseng, papaya enzyme and lots of 
     other herbal stuff.  You can check them out and even request samples 
     of UPtime to be sent to you on the web (http://www.up-time.com).  
     
     I don't have the exact dosages of all the stuff but the effects were 
     very nice.  Increased energy, clearness of the mind (to bring me to a 
     trance state), calmness, and perhaps because of the people I was with, 
     a good state of connectedness.  The sensations were so subtle that at 
     one point, I just realized that I felt incredibly light and content 
     and realized what contributed to it.  With everything that I took, I 
     felt that it lasted a good 6 hours or at least until I went to sleep.  
     Since I normally don't have much caffeine in my diet, I experienced 
     some difficulty falling asleep but when I woke up, I was still quite 
     energized and in a very centered state of mind.
     
     Two other times I tried Fungalore, once by itself and based on my 
     setting, all I felt was a light energy buzz (speediness) and a clear, 
     centered state of being but another time a friend and I went to Roots 
     and had an incredible time.  It was similiar to the first time I took 
     it w/o all the additive vitamins & minerals.  The best part was that I 
     was able to just go to sleep around 5am, wake up in 1-1/2 hours to go 
     to work and continued feeling very clear headed and energized.  
     
     Another product I've tried is _Energyrise_ from Earthrise in Petaluma 
     (http://www.earthrise.com/spirulina) (~$10-12 per 120 caplets).  The 
     benefits of this product for me is that there is no use of caffeine.  
     They suggest 3-6 caplets to be taken between meals as needed.  Along 
     w/the typical multivitamins included in it, they add Ma Huang, 
     Spirulina, Bee Pollen, Don Quai, Ginseng, & Zinc.  I've taken three 
     pills per dose and after about an hour I feel pretty good.  Again, I 
     get an increase in energy, a sense of centeredness or peace, and clear 
     headedness (or ability of stay focused).  I like it alot and aside 
     from the effects of spirulina, I feel no other side effects.
     
     So that's my brief review on these products.  I really haven't 
     explored nutrition and vitamins as much as I want to but now am more 
     motivated :)  I should also mention that all of these should not be 
     taken if you are taking an MAO inhibitor or any othe prescription 
     drug.  
     
     Have a great weekend!
     
     Love,
     Diane

The people that were doing liquid are friends of mine.  Liquid was name of
the club they...well pretty much he (dj Rig-a-Tony from Sacramento) started.
I'm not sure if there were others involved, but I know they were using
Rig-a-Tony's sound and he would have dj'd there every Friday.  It only ended
up happening for one night because there was some issue of insurance that
got raised.  It was going to cost alot more for the insurance or something
so it got cancelled.  It's lame, cuz there's nothing to do in Sac on
Fridays, and Liquid was free.

Jonathan wrote: 

>BTW, I've never been to a party thrown by these fellas.  Are they of good 
>repute?

I think so, but then again, Rig-a-Tony is a friend of mine.  And if it
wasn't for him I would probably still hate vinyl and house music.  He really
enlightened me when we were roommates.  Now I'm a superstar dj with a big
ego like all the rest of them.....just kidding:)  

See you all in the ambient room at Groove Trip One Year Anneversary.  I
think this one's gonna be a doozy.

Rick (C-Lab)

At 12:43 PM 1/18/96 EST, Leslie Ayres wrote:
>I agree that searching people is really a problem -- I notice that certain
>locations bring out a rougher crowd, and frankly I feel a little relieved to
>know that some sort of quick search for weapons is done at the door.  
>
>On the other hand, it can really go too far.  At the Gathering, I was so
>thoroughly searched it fully ruined my night.  I mean, I was frisked top to
>bottom, pockets emptied, and she even opened up my WALLET and CIGARETTE PACK and
>BOX OF MINTS and confiscated my simple herbal stuff. 

word to you....

I remember that once, while I was still living in DC, i was searched in a Rave and they took away from me:

- 4 pens (I mean, normal pens.. not taggers)
- 1 pencil
- a rubber band


And I was coming straight from the law school to the event, so I was in need of all that..the guy just told me that I could hurt someone with those things.. I still can not see how.

Sometimes, the bouncers are not friendly at all... I hate bouncers, anyway.. i just hope we could all go to events and bring whatever we wanted to, and be responsible enough not to bring anything harmful to everyone.

At 08:15 PM 1/18/96 -0800, Jonathan Santos wrote:
>>>       I think the only DJ's who don't have huge ego's are Laurent Garnier and
>>> Superstar DJ Keoki...yup..you can just waltz right on up and give 'em a
>>>biggggg
>>> hoooooge hug.  Pretty humble guyz...down to earth...subtle..*blink blink*....
>>> Is the sarcasm thick enough yet? 8)
>
>You guys should realize that if you were as famous as Laurent Garnier or
>Keoki, you would constantly be hasseled by people when you go out.   Too many people are just
>quick to judge...
>

The point i was really trying to make was the DJ's in the real life, everyday living. Not while they are on action.

I happened to meet almost all the DJ's that i personally know in situations other than actually on a club. As a DJ myself, and as sometimes I was spinning before them, I happened to have a chance of meeting some way before the event was going.. In some cases, i even had to help teh promoter while setting up the deals, etc..

this thread happened to come to my head because i have this friend, who now is becoming a well-known Dj, so he now forgets all his former friends, and just want to be around the "spotlight personalities", "newspaeper columnists", etc.. I always tried to open his eyes that this DJ life is not only "fame" and no fortune at all, but, when you don't want to listen..... 

I guess I met a lot of nice people. But, while I was living in the East Coast, I met quite a few fat-heads and idiot DJs..ppl which are heralded all over, and are such jerks that, in one case, If he comes to spin around my country, I'd be the first to go after him..but,to, at least, beat him up.

I guess, at the end, we are just dealing with ppl..some are nice, some are not. You just want to be around teh nice ones.

On Fri, 19 Jan 1996, Dirceu Pereira wrote:

> I remember that once, while I was still living in DC, i was searched in a Rave and they took away from me:
> 
> - 4 pens (I mean, normal pens.. not taggers)
> - 1 pencil
> - a rubber band


I went to a party in Portland a few months back where the security  
confiscated from me an Odwalla(fruit drink), some Herbal Stimulants, a 
ball of twine, some bagels, and I think a couple of other odds and 
ends.  Fortunatly,they had a check in system so that you could get it 
all back at the end of the night.  Some friends had to take off their  
wallet chains and any studded or chain belts, under the excuse that they  
could be used as weapons, I think.  I don't mind being searched too 
much, I'd much rather keep guns and spray cans and such outside the  
venues, but this was a bit absurd.

As a side note, at the very same party, some guy wacked out on way too 
many drugs(I assume) literally attacked the turntables and Jon Williams 
by leaping onto the decks and smashing one of the needles, not to mention 
a few records.  I guess we should be glad he wasn't armed.


patrick

On Thu, 18 Jan 1996, solo wrote:

>  But if you have a good time dancing or whatEver it is you do, pleas just 
> go and tell your friends, tell your loved ones, tell your parents :) its 
> what we all appreciate, is being known (doesnt everyone?), but most of 
> all, go and tell the dj. As a matter of fact do that first. We may be out 
> of sorts, but believe me a person playing music does not a dj make. The dj 
> is just like you and me. we like attention, we like having friends, we 
> like a smile. If I could be friends with all the ppl i play for, Id be the 
> happiest man on the planet.

	While some djs really like to be told that their set was like, I
know a few who get all the reward they need from just being part of the
energy that is produced when everyone dances their asses off - dj puts on
record, the crowd dances a bit, dj puts on next record, plays with the mix
for a minute or two, a couple people yell and howl, dj smiles cuz
something is happening and puts on next record and the energy just pushes
you to play with it and the more you play the more people howl and stomp
and dance and the more you are pushed to spin and play and the better your
record choice is cuz its become much more than just a dj playing and
people dancing, and I don't mean conceptually. I been on both ends of that
connection and it can be really hard to have someone come up with a
certain look in their eyes and tell you they really liked your music, the
way you spun or whatever and then stand there with this vibe coming off of
them which makes you feel like you should know everything right about
then. A dj is just another person, some do it cuz they like the energy, 
they like playing with music and somehow, other people found out that 
they like playing with music and those other people like the way the 
first plays with it and then someone with a sound system finds out... And 
to those people I think the fame thing is scary. To some, pushing out 
some attitude to everyone is a way of keeping away the people who forget 
that you are just another person. Although I think most everyone would 
agree that this isn't the best way of a dj protecting oneself from 
those uncomfortable situations, I think it is much better than going 
along with the game that I must be a god because people will look at me 
that way (which in fact, seems more like a wall of attitude to hide 
behind because that person actually knows they are not much different 
from the next person). In the end, a dj is just a person who is not much 
differrent than anyone else (except they have gotten to see life from 
just one more perpestive), and they will most likely however they 
may seem is more a reaction to however they are approached. If someone 
googles at a dj and then expects the dj to react as if they were being 
treated like any other person, that person had better not complain that 
the dj didn't treat him or her like they a person - did s/he treat the dj 
like a person? Does any friendship come out of one person being 
idealized? I think I am starting to get off my point...

dave

I feel I should testify here:  My life was ruined by belly button lint.

It all started when someone I thought was my friend offered me some.  I'd 
heard of it, but I didn't know much about it, and since this person seemed 
really cool, I tried it.  At first, it was easy.  I'd have a little after 
work, or on the weekends.  Pretty soon though, I was finding myself sneaking 
into the mens' room at work to dig out a little belly button lint.  I was 
staying up 'til all hours of the night digging at my belly button!  One day 
one of my co-workers caught me trying to dig some lint out of her belly 
button.  Of course I lost my job.  I couldn't make the payments on my car 
and my house.  I lost everything...

Thank goodness there's Belly Button Lint Anonymous (BBLA).  With their help 
and the love of family and friends, I managed to kick the belly button lint 
habit, and now I'm putting my life back together...<sniff>...I've been lint 
free for over a year now.  I wish I'd never started...<sob>...

Belly Button Lint -- just say no!

>BY YOUR COMMAND;
>
>        Hmmm, would your please share with us all, your experiences,
>regarding the use of belly button lint as a psycoactive substance = >!!!!!!
>
>Thank Goddess it's FRIDAY!!!!!!
>

>>medicines are just as medically potent as belly button lint or old socks.

To: SFRaves <SFRaves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Clockwork Tortoise (a quick FAQ)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

To anybody out there wondering what Clockwork Tortoise Inc is all about;

We are a group of ravers that run our own video game development company. We do 
design, art and programming for SEGA's game machines. Partying and working go 
hand in hand for us. Raves, the music and the subculture are our inspiration and 
our life.

As for myself, I come from Dublin,Ireland. I've followed the rave scene ever 
since I left Dublin, starting in Manchester,England moving on to LA (where I 
started CTI) and now SF our new home.

So why Clockwork Tortoise? ....well we were kinda stoned at the time and my 
memory is a little cloudy. We didn't want a jerk-off name with "Interactive" or 
"Multimedia" in the title. But personally it is my tribute to the inventor of the 
first clockwork tortoise... I mean somebody out there said "I'm going to make 
this tortoise thing that you can wind up and walks accross your table!" and they 
did - wonderful!
    
SeeYa... Jobbeee 

-- 
   Me: John O'Brien                   Email: cti@earthlink.net
    @: Clockwork Tortoise Inc.        Voice: 415-399-1429
Where: 211 Sutter Street, Suite 401     Fax: 415-399-0158
  Why: San Francisco, CA 94108

On Fri, 19 Jan 1996, SDream wrote:

> Blkadder wrote:
> 
> >Well there are really two seperate IRC's. The main one, and the undernet. 
> 
> The "undernet"?  Is that like "Underdog", a net that gets super powers by 
> taking a pill?  Or like "underwear", something you generally don't flash in 
> public?  Enlighten me please, what's an "undernet"?

It is a less-populated, less-lagged IRC network. 


> >Perhaps we can agree on a common server to connect to such 
> >as irc.colorado.edu, or irc.sdsc.edu which will simplify matters greatly.
> 
> More enlightenment, please: How would one connect to another server?  Is 
> there a setting in IRC for this?
> 
Yup. In IRC type something like:
/server irc.sdsc.edu

And that will connect you to the specified server.

If Shawna and other people are interested in trying something like 
this again, I will volunteer to help people figure out a) if they can 
use/have the software for IRC and b) how to use it. 

                                              Black Adder

ReSent-From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
ReSent-Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.960120110700.18924B@taz.hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Thu Jan 18,  2:59pm
>If ppl just did what they were DRAWN to do, what they FELT they
>should do intuitively rather than what is expected of them by the demands
>of our present economic/social structure we'd end up with a really diverse
>and complex system of social interaction.

YES!!!!

This reminded me of a wonderful quote by Howard Thurman:

"Don't ask yourself what the world needs.  Ask yourself what makes you come
alive, and go do that, because what the world needs is people who have come
alive."

When I have actively lived with this sentiment in mind, wonderful people,
things, ideas and jobs have come my way.  Also, in times that are difficult or
challenging, this idea of "going through growing pains in order to become more
alive" is rather comforting and have inspired me to keep going/growing.  In
light of the recent posts requesting "good vibes", I thought this might be
helpful to people.

warmly




-- 
Anne Petrie                                                   
Third Wave Solutions, Inc.            
E-mail: anne@source.net
(805)565-0277
Remember, if you breathe and persist anything is possible.

If this isn't just too funny -- I just had to forward it to y'all...

--- begin forwarded text

From: rustic@plainfield.bypass.com
Date: Sat, 20 Jan 96 15:09:52 PST
Subject: aphex twin dream
To: ambient@hyperreal.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-ambient@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

goddammit i had strange dream this night...
i don't know whether it was caused by a book i was reading
on mind control in scientology and all that weird sci-fi shit
they teach, or an email i was finishing to someone about music...
but i went to sleep at 5am really exhausted... and maybe the
combination of the two subjects resulted in this...

...well, i dreamt that i went to aphex twin's apartment (kinda like the
apartment i used to live in NYC) and we were talking about electronic
music, and about composing it and stuff... and we got into a argument,
because he just wouldn't tell me how he modulated the frequency cutoff
on his on his equipment.  see, he didn't use MIDI control numbers  to
control the parameters... he used some homemade mystical gadget thing
that looked like a old dirty toaster and he wouldn't tell me what the
hell it is and how it works..!!!.
..and so we started arguing, and i just *had* to know...
i kept saying, 'what's the big deal?! why can't just tell me what you
use?!'
..and then the whole room started filling with a pink foam...
and then the dream switched into something else...
strange huh?

..this was my third aphex dream by the way...

(see, *this* is what you get when you listen to too much ambient-
 you get strange dreams, ...you go tell a shrink...and then he locks you
 up in some nut-house...)

from
a rustic
-<J>
'bafbuabfi'
<G>

                ...b l a c k  n o i s e  g e n e r a t o r...

--- end forwarded text

To: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
From: ecto@magnet.ca (ecto)
Subject: Re: (NON-RAVE) Living vs. Thriving/Synchronicity
Cc: anne petrie <anne@isis.source.net>, SFRAVES@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 5:01 PM 1/20/96, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>On Thu, 18 Jan 1996, anne petrie wrote:
>
>> On Thu Jan 18,  2:59pm
>> >If ppl just did what they were DRAWN to do, what they FELT they
>> >should do intuitively rather than what is expected of them by the demands
>> >of our present economic/social structure we'd end up with a really diverse
>> >and complex system of social interaction.
>
>=> yes this is key. hard though. as one draws away from what is expected
>of them toward their intuition, anxiety ensues. less responsibility with
>the former. strength necessary and belief in you self for the latter.

        Totally! What i have found, though, is that when you do choose to
'wander off the beaten path' of what is expected of you, or is the most
'logical/rational' thing to do in a given situation, you find that there
will be strange little indicators that will re-assure you that you're
'doing the right thing.'  I read a bit of this book on Synchronicity
written by...arg, can't remember right now, but it had a quote from Joseph
Campbell that echoed anne's quote from Howard Thurman:

>> This reminded me of a wonderful quote by Howard Thurman:
>>
>> "Don't ask yourself what the world needs.  Ask yourself what makes you come
>> alive, and go do that, because what the world needs is people who have come
>> alive."
        The Joseph Campbell quote basically said the same thing: when
you're in touch with what you want to be intuitively, even if it seems off
the wall for you, and you set your mind to achieving it, you find that
there are 'helping hands' that seemingly come out of nowhere to push you
along.
        A lot of times i skeptically wonder if synchronicity is real, or
whether my own desire to believe in it is what makes me percieve events as
synchronous but in the past couple days i've had some coincidences that
were just TOO weird to be explained, and have also driven home both
Campbell and Thurman's point.

>> When I have actively lived with this sentiment in mind, wonderful people,
>> things, ideas and jobs have come my way.  Also, in times that are
>>difficult or
>> challenging, this idea of "going through growing pains in order to
>>become more
>> alive" is rather comforting and have inspired me to keep going/growing.  In
>> light of the recent posts requesting "good vibes", I thought this might be
>> helpful to people.
        Believe me, it has, and thanks anne :) In the past week i've had a
lot of things happen which have been really tough (getting layed off from
my job and having a lot of my 'plans' for the future rearranged on a daily
if not hourly basis ;) but reading stuff like this, along with having a few
really strange synchronous events has helped me stay 'not so stressed out'
:)
        Akk, sorry this was completely non-rave related!
        peace,
                brad

hi y'all...

for me, this kind of stuff IS rave related because this is part of rave 
culture, for me.  weird synchronous stuff always happens at raves for me 
along with other types of "experiences" like coincidentally meeting 
someone that you wanted to meet or wanting to meet you (right, wayne? :) 
and all that stuff...so, like i said, for me this is part of rave 
culture.  i'd like to get feedback from you guys on this topic.

love,

bren, aka, shakti

On Sun, 21 Jan 1996, ecto wrote:

> At 5:01 PM 1/20/96, Kevin Keiper wrote:
> >On Thu, 18 Jan 1996, anne petrie wrote:
> >
> >> On Thu Jan 18,  2:59pm
> >> >If ppl just did what they were DRAWN to do, what they FELT they
> >> >should do intuitively rather than what is expected of them by the demands
> >> >of our present economic/social structure we'd end up with a really diverse
> >> >and complex system of social interaction.
> >
> >=> yes this is key. hard though. as one draws away from what is expected
> >of them toward their intuition, anxiety ensues. less responsibility with
> >the former. strength necessary and belief in you self for the latter.
> 
>         Totally! What i have found, though, is that when you do choose to
> 'wander off the beaten path' of what is expected of you, or is the most
> 'logical/rational' thing to do in a given situation, you find that there
> will be strange little indicators that will re-assure you that you're
> 'doing the right thing.'  I read a bit of this book on Synchronicity
> written by...arg, can't remember right now, but it had a quote from Joseph
> Campbell that echoed anne's quote from Howard Thurman:
> 
> >> This reminded me of a wonderful quote by Howard Thurman:
> >>
> >> "Don't ask yourself what the world needs.  Ask yourself what makes you come
> >> alive, and go do that, because what the world needs is people who have come
> >> alive."
>         The Joseph Campbell quote basically said the same thing: when
> you're in touch with what you want to be intuitively, even if it seems off
> the wall for you, and you set your mind to achieving it, you find that
> there are 'helping hands' that seemingly come out of nowhere to push you
> along.
>         A lot of times i skeptically wonder if synchronicity is real, or
> whether my own desire to believe in it is what makes me percieve events as
> synchronous but in the past couple days i've had some coincidences that
> were just TOO weird to be explained, and have also driven home both
> Campbell and Thurman's point.
> 
> >> When I have actively lived with this sentiment in mind, wonderful people,
> >> things, ideas and jobs have come my way.  Also, in times that are
> >>difficult or
> >> challenging, this idea of "going through growing pains in order to
> >>become more
> >> alive" is rather comforting and have inspired me to keep going/growing.  In
> >> light of the recent posts requesting "good vibes", I thought this might be
> >> helpful to people.
>         Believe me, it has, and thanks anne :) In the past week i've had a
> lot of things happen which have been really tough (getting layed off from
> my job and having a lot of my 'plans' for the future rearranged on a daily
> if not hourly basis ;) but reading stuff like this, along with having a few
> really strange synchronous events has helped me stay 'not so stressed out'
> :)
>         Akk, sorry this was completely non-rave related!
>         peace,
>                 brad

Hey Brenda!

I'm inclined to agree with you.  I've been going thru a lot of changes 
lately, that relate to this thread, in the past few weeks, and I do 
attribute a part of that to raving!  At Chrysalis I had a very 
spiritual time, and it's changed me somehow, and that's stuck with me.  
So raves, among certain other occurrences in my life as of late, have 
definitely played a part in this.  But after all, isn't that really the 
point of raving?  Peace, Love, Unity, Respect, good vibes, good energy, 
evolution, etc?  I find myself surrounded by unconditional love & 
people who feel like I do.  All these are things everybody says are a 
part of raving, so I guess there should be no surprise when I actually 
find myself experiencing these things!  So yes, it is definitely rave 
related in my book!

Love,
Shawna

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        Well it was truly a weekend of the Good, The Bad, & the Ugly. I went
to Overdose on Friday @ the Acme Warehouse, it was a great Ghetto Rave if ya
like those things. The Gansta Vibe was strong; with plenty of crank & crack
to smoke. No one seemed to dance for very long, I guess the crack/crank just
kills any good vibe.

        I kind a felt like I was in a rave at San Quentin, couldn't tell the
security from the thugs. I stayed through Tracy & Mar's sets and then left
for the less hostile ground of 1015 Folsum. I noticed not one DJ seemed to
hang around for very long after their sets. It was really hard to see a
place like the Acme Gallery, where we've put so much effort into making the
space environmentally really nice & comfortable be totally devoid of
decoration, less the graffiti.

        Needless to say I didn't have a very good time, put it was there
first party, a $15 party ta boot. Lets hope they either make something
unique for themselves as far as putting a rave together goes and/or take a
little direction from the rest of us, and follow suit.

        As for Saturday night, hats off once again to C^3 Warehouse for
having a space that runs a close second to the greatest place in SF to throw
a party, old Cyberlab HQ on Bryant Street. Thanks also for keeping it core,
and not going for the greed.

        This place is just soooo cool, from the vagina doorway to the well
done day glow decorations everywhere, to the beautiful people that produced
a overwhelming love vibe, to the DJ's who spun da Trance, & to all those who
make da music like SF's very own Peter from Kode IV, true devotion to the art.



31 seconds & we're going for auto-sequence start...........................
see ya's in space......4321.........darknes^2 out>>>>>>>>____........

My computer tells me that on Fri, 19 Jan 1996, Eric shared:

> >On Fri, 19 Jan 1996, Starchild wrote:
> >> 
> >> 	This is true, and suggests to me two possible solutions (besides 
> >> the obvious do-nothing option and the ways to decrease the likelihood 
> >> of violence at parties I outlined in the message you quote from above):
> >> 	(1) Try to remove the drugs from our scene, or
> >> 	(2) Try to remove the violence by getting them legalized, or at least 
> >> 		decriminalized.
> >> 
> >> 	I opt for the latter.
> >
> >                   I agree and go with option #2:).
> 
> I assume you both are willing to not do drugs until they are legalized,
> since you would be tacitly supporting the very same side effects you are
> trying to eradicate.
> 
> I agree that #2 is the better option, it sure works for alcohol!
> 
> eh

	That's a big assumption there, Eric... :)  Interesting dilemna 
though, I'd never really considered it that way.
	Frankly, I think curtailing my use would be sending the wrong 
message to the authorities:  It would contribute to the mistaken idea 
that the War On Drugs is working, thereby encouraging them to perpetuate 
it, with the resulting continuation of the violence.  
	After due consideration, my decision is that I will continue to 
break the law.  It is not for nothing that Dr. Martin Luther King said 
unjust laws deserve to be broken.

Yours in liberty,

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        Fred, you use to run DOS/Text based BBS Sytems, how bout some help.
Well anyway dis is what I know about Gallacticomm after happially useing
them for over 5 years? The service; Liberty BBS is a Gallacticom/Major BBS.

        What is a Gallacticomm? The company Gallacticom was a BBS Management
Software Developer. The company was started in Flordia by a kid when he was
going to highschool. Gallacticom is the name of the software, and if I'm not
mistaken some propriitary hardware as well. I believe that any BBS running
the software was refered to as either as a Gallacticom or Major BBS.

        The software allowed the sysop to run a multi-line BBS system that
offered unique chat features to it's users. Along with alternative chat/mail
networks like chatlink, worldlink, ....etc enabled many Major Net BBS's to
communicate through out the world with each other. Worldlink mail can take
up to 3 days to reach a destination, compared to the Internets minutes. But
it was a WAN that was available to the general public before the interent
was, I believe anyway.

        To answer your question you will proablly have to pay pennies for
this service, but it will cost you. You actually may be able to find it for
free, but Gallacticom software was kind a expensive so I doubt it.

> On Sun, 21 Jan 1996, ecto wrote:
> 
> > At 5:01 PM 1/20/96, Kevin Keiper wrote:
> > >On Thu, 18 Jan 1996, anne petrie wrote:
> > >
> > >> On Thu Jan 18,  2:59pm
> > >> >If ppl just did what they were DRAWN to do, what they FELT they
> > >> >should do intuitively rather than what is expected of them by the demands
> > >> >of our present economic/social structure we'd end up with a really diverse
> > >> >and complex system of social interaction.
> > >
> > >=> yes this is key. hard though. as one draws away from what is expected
> > >of them toward their intuition, anxiety ensues. less responsibility with
> > >the former. strength necessary and belief in you self for the latter.
> > 
> >         Totally! What i have found, though, is that when you do choose to
> > 'wander off the beaten path' of what is expected of you, or is the most
> > 'logical/rational' thing to do in a given situation, you find that there
> > will be strange little indicators that will re-assure you that you're
> > 'doing the right thing.'  I read a bit of this book on Synchronicity
> > written by...arg, can't remember right now, but it had a quote from Joseph
> > Campbell that echoed anne's quote from Howard Thurman:
> > 
> > >> This reminded me of a wonderful quote by Howard Thurman:
> > >>
> > >> "Don't ask yourself what the world needs.  Ask yourself what makes you come
> > >> alive, and go do that, because what the world needs is people who have come
> > >> alive."
> >         The Joseph Campbell quote basically said the same thing: when
> > you're in touch with what you want to be intuitively, even if it seems off
> > the wall for you, and you set your mind to achieving it, you find that
> > there are 'helping hands' that seemingly come out of nowhere to push you
> > along.
> >         A lot of times i skeptically wonder if synchronicity is real, or
> > whether my own desire to believe in it is what makes me percieve events as
> > synchronous but in the past couple days i've had some coincidences that
> > were just TOO weird to be explained, and have also driven home both
> > Campbell and Thurman's point.
> > 
> > >> When I have actively lived with this sentiment in mind, wonderful people,
> > >> things, ideas and jobs have come my way.  Also, in times that are
> > >>difficult or
> > >> challenging, this idea of "going through growing pains in order to
> > >>become more
> > >> alive" is rather comforting and have inspired me to keep going/growing.  In
> > >> light of the recent posts requesting "good vibes", I thought this might be
> > >> helpful to people.
> >         Believe me, it has, and thanks anne :) In the past week i've had a
> > lot of things happen which have been really tough (getting layed off from
> > my job and having a lot of my 'plans' for the future rearranged on a daily
> > if not hourly basis ;) but reading stuff like this, along with having a few
> > really strange synchronous events has helped me stay 'not so stressed out'
> > :)
> >         Akk, sorry this was completely non-rave related!
> >         peace,
> >                 brad



sorry to lengthen an already long post, but im sure there are some who 
would be interested in the entire line:

anyway, i think fear is really the factor impeding the flow of 
intuition. fear is really self-created, and i heard this really cool 
title of a book actually, called 'love is letting go of fear' this is SO 
true!!! the whole syncronistic phenomenon is interesting as well, 'cause 
somtimes i think that the universe is acting out energies(remember you 
cannot create or destroy energy, just change it... did einstein say 
this?) through us, and we notice this in the form of syncronistic events. 
and if we let our fear choke off this natural flow, then we feel more 
anxiety and more fear, but then again the fact that one is choking off 
the flow of natural syncronistic energy is ok, it is all good, and this 
is part of the syncronistic energy in the first place?!?!?!? just a large 
circle of energy, all boiling down to love. weird huh? does any of this 
make sense?

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        I thought anyone interested in upgrading to that 28.8kbps would find
it interesting, and it's true, well at least the technical part. The first
part is scarey, but I hope you find it both amusing and informative.


Digital Communications  - By Hank Volpe
The Myth of 28.8 kbps Communication

A scene sure to be repeated in every computer-enhanced, politically-
correct household on holidays, anniversaries, or birthdays; The loving
and devoted life-companion, knowing that their significant other 
wishes a modem of higher speed, spends long hours browsing 
catalogs, shopping at computer stores, watching home shopping
channels, looking for the 28.8 kbps "screamer" that will satisfy 
(although real satisfaction can only come through one's self). A 
purchase is made, and on the appointed day,  the "gift" (offered by an 
equal as an equal, never as one gaining favor with the other)  is 
unwrapped from its recycled newspaper cover. The other, knowing 
that they have been given a cherished gift, thank their life-companion 
in a kind, human and non-sexist way.  The day closes, finding our 
mutually-bonded individuals basking in self-assured reaffirmation, one 
with their lives, nature, and their computer. 

What could possibly shatter this terribly 90's, terribly correct peace 
and contentment? An un-named person wishing to enter the 
relationship? Nay, for that possibility has already been discussed, 
planned, and documented in pre-nuptial agreements. Perhaps one life-
companion has received a promotion? Nay too, for we have learned 
that accomplishments in the world are transitory at best. No, this 
relationship, this politically-correct myth, is shattered by the shattering
of another myth... the myth of 28.8 kbps communication. After the 
modem is configured and setup, the tension, frustration and agony 
erupt along typical "role-playing" lines. The household returns to a less 
enlightened time, when men were men and women were women, and
modems were "beasties" that never worked right.  

Myths play an important part in our lives. They shape our thoughts and 
our actions. When our myths change, our culture changes too. Unlike 
lifestyle, myths have no place in the computer world, yet we deal with 
myths spawned by inflated promises in advertising every day.  Think 
of some of the myths you know of such as;  a 66 mhz computer is 
twice as fast as a 33,  or 16 megs of memory is more than you will 
ever need. Its now time to add another busted myth to this group; the 
myth that V.34 will support 28.8 kbps and even 33.6 kbps!  The fact is, 
given our present telephone system, any connect speed above 19.2 
kbps is iffy at best!  Granted, some modem manufacturers do a better 
job of implementing V.34 than others, but still even the best modems 
have consistent problems connecting above 21.6 kbps.



Our current phone system is a network. The local exchange funnels 
connections from home and offices  to other locations both inside and 
outside of the local exchange. Connections between exchanges are 
done via microwaves, fiber, digital, or carrier (modulated) services.
Usually, within an exchange, telephone calls are clear and relatively 
noise-free. Interconnecting the network  introduces "impairments" that 
hamper high speed communications.  The following is a list of these 
impairments;

Bandwidth
--------------
Static or scratchy voice calls are very annoying.  As a function of 
frequency, static is higher than most voice communications, so the 
phone company installs roll-off filters to suppress noise higher than 
human voice frequencies. These filters limit the "bandwidth" or 
maximum frequency response of the telephone line.  Bandwidth is 
very important to high speed communication.  At 28.8kbps, 3200 
symbols per second must be sent.  These are modulated (turned into
audio tones) so that they can be transmitted on the telephone line.
The lowest tone is 229 hz, the highest is 3429 hz, for a total bandwidth
of 3200 hz.  The higher the bps rate, more symbols (character and
error correcting information)  are transmitted.   Below is a simple table
showing these relationships;

BPS            Frequencies     Bandwidth
---------     -------------   ------------
21.6 kbps      400-2880 hz      2400 hz
24.0 kbps      274-3018 hz      2744 hz
26.4 kbps      300-3300 hz      3000 hz
28.8 kbps      229-3429 hz      3200 hz
Phone          700-3000 hz      2300 hz

Problem #1; the average telephone line's bandwidth is limited to
between 700 hz and 3000 hz, for a total bandwidth of 2300 hz. V.34
equalization ( a trick to boost bandwidth) does extend the bandwidth
some, but it also brings up noise as well. This noise can contribute to
disconnects and garbled data. Therefore, V.34 will "fallback" to a
slower speed until it thinks it finds a connection speed that works.
Notice that 21.6 kbps is so close to what is considered normal phone
bandwidth that it is sure to work most of the time.



Digital Speech Compression
------------------------------------
With the explosion of modems, cellular phones, and fax machines, the
phone company is simply running out of circuits to interconnect local
area exchanges. Additional microwave frequencies are scarce
because the current microwave band is at capacity. The long-term
answer, fiber, is costly and takes time to install. As a result, some
phone companies have started using digital speech compression .
Just like compressed files, compressed speech takes less time to
transmit. Several phone callers can be time-multiplexed or frequency
multiplexed to share the same telephone circuit. This effectively
increases the capacity of the existing telephone network.

Problem #2; such compression effectively limits bandwidth to the point
where connections at 14.4 kbps become iffy as well.  Although this
used to be strictly a "rural" problem, such compression is now
becoming a "big-city" problem as well. If you have problems getting
connections above 9600 bps, or if 14.4 kbps is the absolute highest
speed  at which you can connect, you may be a victim of digital
speech compression.


Wall Jacks
--------------
High speed connections require clean physical interconnections
between your modem and your telephone. Wall jacks and telephone
chord connectors are made of copper or other metals and are subject
to corrosion and loss of spring tension because of age.  Try plugging
your modem into another wall outlet in the house. If that works,
replace your wall outlet.

If problems persist, clean the RJ-11 jack (the connector at both ends
of your telephone chord) with a rubber eraser. The eraser removes
corrosion very nicely on copper. Make sure you air-blow out any left-
over eraser particles before you re-install the telephone cable. If this
works, invest in another phone cable.

Finally, most modems are designed to loop the telephone line through
the modem and to a voice instrument. Remove the telephone
instrument and see if the problem goes away. Some inexpensive
modems have poor isolation between the load of the modem and the
load of the telephone instrument, and this can cause high-speed
problems as well.


Calling-Out Problems
---------------------------
If you're having problems connecting with a certain BBS on a certain
exchange, try another BBS on another exchange. The interconnect
from your local exchange may pass through many other exchanges,
some of which may have problems interconnecting to still other
exchanges. Isolating the problem to a certain part of town won't make
things any better, but you'll know the problem isn't in your house wiring
or your modem. This also works for long-distance calls as well. Some
area codes are notorious for bad connections, while others work well.
Also, depending on your long distance provider, you may experience
problems only with long distance and nothing else. Early on, I had a
similar problem with one provider and switched to another, which
solved my problem.

Configuration Problems
------------------------------
Finally, we get to the point where you most likely started which is;
blaming your modem. Sad to say, that some modem manufacturers do
a poor job of implementing the V.34 standard. To figure out your
problem, start at the basics. First of all, if you are connecting at
speeds below 21.6 kbps and you are sure its not your telephone line,
double check the following;

1) Is the DTE rate (rate between modem and computer) locked and
set to a speed of at least 38.4 kbps. "Locking" is a technique used by
high speed modems. The rate of exchange between modem and
computer stays at a fixed speed regardless of the speed the telephone
connection between modems. You need a DTE speed greater than
your highest connect speed to have good throughput, and with some
modems, if the DTE rate is lower than the connect speed, the modem
will fallback to a lower speed.

2) Are you using an error-free protocol?  Not to be confused with file
transfer protocols, error-free protocols insure good connections at high
speed. V.42bis should be your choice in nearly every case, however,
some manufacturers have done a poor job of implementing V.42 bis.
The symptom of this problem is that you will have a good connection,
eventually leading to one of these problems; keyboard freezing,
dropping off of file transfer speed until the system locks up,  or failure
to connect at any speed above 4800 bps.

If you experience these problems, check your modem manual and
switch to MNP protocol. MNP-4 or MNP-5  will still work effectively
with most high speed transmissions.  If this happens to you on a
particular BBS, then you know that system has a bad V.42bis
implementation. If it happens to you no matter where you call, then
contact your modem manufacturer and see if they have an upgrade of
the ROM code used in your modem.  You should also be aware that a
few modem manufacturers will not admit to such a problem right away.
It took several months of pressuring for one manufacturer to admit
they had this bug and for them to issue ROM corrections.

3) Do you fail to connect at all? V.34 modems will switch down to a
minimum speed of 4800 bps. If the BBS you are calling uses a slower
speed than this, you will never connect. In this case, you will need to
instruct your modem to callout using V.32 instead (this is usually done
with the &N switch in most modems).

On some systems, you will also fail to connect if you fail to establish a
V.42 or MNP connection. In this case, the BBS computer will usually
disconnect you. In this case, just call back. Sometimes modems fail to
properly establish V.42 or MNP connections because of line
conditions.

Conventional Wisdom
----------------------------
You can't help feeling a little frustrated when you first get a 28.8kbps
modem. But before you lash out at your modem, yourself, or your "life-
companion", take a moment to analyze what is going on. Realize that
28.8kbps connections on our current telephone system is a myth. The
only reliable way to get continuous 28.8kbps or higher connections is
with an ISDN line and an ISDN modem.  ISDN is more expensive than
normal telephone service, heavily "tarriffed" in some areas, and not
available in others.

Finally, I want to shatter another myth which is; the faster the
telephone connection, the faster the file transfer. Wrong! A properly
configured modem at 21.6 kbps will transfer a compressed file only a
few hundred characters per second slower than a 28.8kbps
connection. Data compression yields less transmit information at any
speed. True, a typical compressed download at 21.6 kbps yields about
2300 cps, while a typical 28.8 kbps compressed download is about
3300 cps, but most connections of 24.0 kbps or 26.4 kbps are in the
2600-2800 cps range.  Its not worth complaining for 300-500 cps. You
can loose that just simply by writing data to your disk drive or when a
BBS briefly interrupts your transfer during a multitasking session.
Furthermore, if you are using a slower computer or a non-buffered
uart, your top 28.8kbps compressed download speed will rarely get
above 2900 cps, making the download "gap" even more narrow.

Now....go out and hug your life-long companion and thank them for the
wonderful gift! Realize that your life is now better since you realize that
28.8kbps connections are an ideal, a perfect system for a perfect
world. A myth to guide you, and nothing more.

If you have a question regarding Digital Communications, just drop me
a line.You can reach me via Internet at either ; hank.volpe@ghawk.com  or
modem.doctor@ghawk.com. You can also reach me on my BBS, the Modem Doctor
BBS at 410-256-3631. Finally, there's the US Postal service, and our address
is PO Box 43214, Baltimore MD, 21236.

"Fear is the mind-killer..." -Litany Against Fear, Frank Herbert

Fear is a good thing, if acted upon -- it keeps us from doing 
stupid things.  However, fear not acted on becomes worry, which
is a useless emotion.  If something worries me, I should either
do something about it or quit worrying.

And I will add a "Yep" to the chorus of people talking about 
synchronicity.  When doing the right thing, each step along the way
feels right, as it approaches a desired goal.  This doesn't mean 
everything becomes really easy, just satisfying.  True, this 
is a tautology, but it's easy to forget in the blitz of consumer
culture designed to make you fulfill someone else's desires
instead of your own.

Why else would we ship out to chilly beaches in the middle of 
nowhere with no facilities and lug a bunch of equipment around
just to dance?  It's the right thing.  There are countless 
reasons advanced by others as to why we should do the wrong thing, 
and it's very easy to rationalize that "that's the way the world
works" or "you're being naive and idealistic" or "cool people don't
do that anymore" or flat-out "you can't do that".  Pshaw!

// g

States, thankfully we didn't bring the rain or SNOW back with us! It went
really well for us there, thanks to all of you that were there,(you know
who you are!) and made us feel really welcome. There looks to be some hot
releases in the next few weeks, so read on and and as always - PLAY IT
LOUD!
Lysa Carlson

"Starchild" (among others) recently typed:
>> >>
>> >> 	...[There seems] to me two possible solutions (besides 
>> >> the obvious do-nothing option and the ways to decrease the likelihood 
>> >> of violence at parties I outlined in the message you quote from above):
>> >> 	(1) Try to remove the drugs from our scene, or
>> >> 	(2) Try to remove the violence by getting them legalized, or at least 
>> >> 		decriminalized.
>> >> 
>> >> 	I opt for the latter.
>> >
>> >                   I agree and go with option #2:).
>> 
>> I assume you both are willing to not do drugs until they are legalized,
>> since you would be tacitly supporting the very same side effects you are
>> trying to eradicate.
>> 
>> eh
>
>	That's a big assumption there, Eric... :)  Interesting dilemna 
>though, I'd never really considered it that way.
>	Frankly, I think curtailing my use would be sending the wrong 
>message to the authorities:  It would contribute to the mistaken idea 
>that the War On Drugs is working, thereby encouraging them to perpetuate 
>it, with the resulting continuation of the violence.  
>	After due consideration, my decision is that I will continue to 
>break the law.  It is not for nothing that Dr. Martin Luther King said 
>unjust laws deserve to be broken.

I wonder how many other drug-legalists view the War on Drugs as a matter of
pride, that letting the prohibitionists think they're "winning" is worse
than any possible good that might arise from that situation? Anyone out
there care to comment?

I'm just looking for ways of changing that don't involve cool people getting
shot. And hey, just because they *deserve* to be broken, doesn't mean they
*must* be broken. I think there can be other ways.

eh

At 6:39 PM 1/22/96, Reagan Reid wrote:

>               Yes!! MAD at the Bahia Cabina in the city at 1600
>Market(at Franklin) St. Dj's Ethan,Joe Rice,Jon Santos and guest.
>                I think it is $1 before 11 and $3 after:)


A slight clarification ....

Resident DJs for MAD are: Joe Rice, Alex, Jon Santos and Ethan...

2 of whom play each week with one varying guest who usually plays the
middle slot.

Up-to-date, night-specific line-ups can be found at:

  http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/Events.html

It is $1 before 11, $3 after, is open to anyone 18 and over w/ ID and runs
from 10pm - 2:00 every Monday night at the Bahia Cabana in S.F. at the
corners of Market and Franklin streets.

Last night was just insanely *MAD*, excellent sets from Jon, James Dee, and
Alex  =)

Many thanks to everyone for the continued support, can't tell you how much
we appreciate it!

take it easy
ethan


----------------------------( ethan miller )----------------------------
------------------( http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/ )------------------

Hi there, I was in Honolulu last week, and found monday night at the
Jungle was really good, the crowd and club was small, mixed age group, the
Dj's were friendly and played some great tunes, they even played some
tracks I was curious about, good video as well, he's sending me a copy. I
can't remember their names, but can find out if anyone is interested. It
was free entry and the music reached dizzy heights around 1am, some great
pumping techno, the kind that builds to a crescendo and has everyone
screaming with joy. The club stays open till 4pm and after 1am the crowd
builds.  
I went to the Groove but it was very disappointing it played
mainly industrial,and old Depeche Mode songs (Retro time warp!!! blahhh)
with the odd dance (techo or house) track, the flyer was very deceiving.
One thing though, there was herbal ecstacy and smart drinks, plus a bar. 
Matt (Techno man)

Hey

The following is a bit of a sob story, so those of you who don't want 
to read it should stop here! 


I'm in sort of a dilemma here.  Somehow I feel the urge to ask for a 
little help, maybe it will do some good.  I just got a call from my 
ex-boyfriend, and he doesn't appear to be doing well.  We broke up a 
few months ago, and I thought he was ok with it, but he seems to be 
really depressed, and it actually kind of scares me, from the way he 
talks.  Things like "It's killing me, you've given me the death 
sentence" and "I'm gonna be this way for the rest of my life" and "I 
hope you have a good life".  I don't know what to make of this, I hope 
I'm making a bigger deal out of it than it really is, but I can't help 
worrying about it.  This is someone I loved very much, but 
circumstances beyond my control changed the outcome of the 
relationship.  I am no longer someone who can help him in any way, and 
I feel guilty about that, but I tried for 3 years to change that way of 
thinking in him, and it never did any good, he was not willing to 
change.  I know that I cannot do anything for him now, and I have no 
real way to tell him this.  I must sit silently by and watch him 
continue downwards, with my hands tied behind my back.  The real thing 
I'm worried about is obviously suicide.  We had a close friend in the 
past who was confronted with the same problem my ex is, and resolved it 
in that most selfish of methods.  My ex idolized this person, because 
he was sort of a father-figure when his own was lacking, and I fear he 
may decide that a similar course of action would be suitable for him.  
Now comes the help!  I don't know if this would do any good for him, 
but maybe we could all send him some good energy, he is in such 
desperate need of it and doesn't even realize it, it's about the only 
thing I can think of to do for him.  Maybe it'll hit him & he'll have a 
change of heart without realizing why, & he'll drag himself out of the 
pit he's dug himself into.  I would very much apreciate it! 

My love and thanks to you all!

Shawna

 Hello All 
 I don't post very much and am a lurker if there ever was one, but I felt the
need to say something about the recent posts about synths and the TB-303.
There great. To all the people who say that synths and music gear are "not
rave realated" need to get a clue.  I would rather read 100 posts about music
gear and the 303 than one about how someone got some bunk 'E'. It seems to me
that alot of people don't know what raving is really about. It's the MUSIC.
Without that there would be no D.j.'s, no dancing, no raves, just a bunch of
people sitting around high, and I thought they called that a crackhouse. 
  I just wanted to say that I think that synths, dj equiptment, and music
gear are more a part of raving than drugs, fashion, and politics which seem
to be constantly talked about on SFRaves.  
   If this seemed like a flame, I'm sorry, that wasn't my intention, it just
seems like people forget what this is supposed to be all about and that could
be the end. Thats how I feel when I read post upon post about bad drugs and
who's ruining OUR scene with their attitudes and dance style.     ENOUGH...
        
                    music is life is love...
                           Sean

Shawna your friend might be in some need of some professional help, 
possibly hospitolization.
To assess his level of suicidality it can be very helpful to ask some 
direct questions about it.  If you don't feel comfortable doing that, I 
suggest you get a professional to do it if you can.
It's immportant to know if he has any specific plans, a means(a gun, lots 
of drugs to o.d. on...)
How long has he been thinking about it, does he have a timetable if he 
does have a plan.

Some realistic implications that pose a serious threat:
1. Mood- does he seem depressed (sounds like he does), loss of appetite, 
loss of energy, sleep disturbance, dirty, fatigued.
2.Is he isolated,not much of a support system, impulsive, 
3.Does he or is he drinking alcohol or such like related drugs.  These 
can reduce inhibition and increase impulsivity.
4. Does he have any history of past attempts.

If these fit, I would suggest professional help asap.  If he is at a 
point where he seems very determined and you want to save him, you can 
call the police to have him hospitolized.

sorry for getting off of rave related info and not taking this private.  
Thought some of this info might be of some help to others some day (hope 
not). 

peter

BY YOUR COMMAND;

At 02:26 PM 1/23/96 -0800, you wrote:

>Say there, Senor Darkness, perhaps you can educate a bright, if easily 
>distracted, young man.  What exactly is "goa trance"?  How would it differ 
>from regular garden variety trance?

        I need some help here guys, so how bout it. Anyway dis is what I
know about Goa Trance.

        Goa Trance, like Cyber Trance, Heavy Trance, ...etc is a style
within the genre of Techno. Goa Trance differs from Trance because & most
basically it is usually from a place in India called Goa, though it can be
from and anywhere in the world. There is some really happenin French Goa,
that's rocks. It is usually above 140bpm, and is impossible not to move you
body to.

        I like t because I have a very active mind, also most hypomanic, and
a fantastic imagenation that I usually keep to myself. Whether ON or not it
takes me on a journey, gives my day or night dreams a musical backdrop, or
score for them. I just really dig it.
Also it like most Trance, is possibly more pshycoactive than House or other
form of Techno, at least for me anyway.

        That's about all I can articulate myself with reagrd to GOA Trance,
so come on Trance Heads speak you mind, and bring some awareness to this House.





31 seconds & we're going for auto-sequence start...........................
see ya's in space......4321.........darknes^2 out>>>>>>>>____........

On Wed, 24 Jan 1996 LEFTESEAN@aol.com wrote:

> It seems to me
> that alot of people don't know what raving is really about. It's the MUSIC.

	While I agree that a few lines about the equipment thtat make 
electronic music is more prepinent to this list than drug talk, I take 
offense at being told what a rave 'is about'. Raves are a lot of things 
to a lot of people - for some it is the music, for some it is the people, 
for some it is the general odd atmosphere that you can find ain only a 
few other places, for some it is the huge combination. If music is the 
only thing thing you like about raving, why do you go out? Why not 
befriend a Dj and lounge around their house while they practice?

dave

>At 02:26 PM 1/23/96 -0800, you wrote:
>
>>Say there, Senor Darkness, perhaps you can educate a bright, if easily 
>>distracted, young man.  What exactly is "goa trance"?  How would it 
differ 
>>from regular garden variety trance?

        IMO.  "goa" trance is the "cheesy" or "unintelligent" side of 
trance.  Trance without passion.  It's the only trance that isn't trance 
inducing!  I believe it only earned a reputation as being "goa" because 
record companies tried SO hard.  WHY?  Maybe because it is totally easy 
to mass produce.  
        I think goa is the opposite of underground.  The difference is in 
the artist's intentions when they create the piece of music.  If it was 
intended to trance them out, it will end up being more underground.  If 
it was intended to sell records it will end up being more "goa"ey.  
        It is hard to tell the difference at first, or distinguish what 
is actually cheesy about it at all...  But it is NOT a product of the 
underground.  When I and my friends go shopping for music, it has turned 
into searching for the things that are the LEAST goa-ie.  

        as we like to say...  

        goa-way

        Hope that helped.  =)

        ::hugs::

        BTW.  there is absoulutely gorgeous -blow your mind- trance out 
there...

        !love!  e

       |  CDJ LMNT                     |                         
       |  Aural Pilot                  |         /|   
_______|  HTTP://nixon.ind.net/~lmnt/  |_______|/ |__________________

A few suggestions:

I have the Rising High Trance Injection 2CD set, which I'm very pleased
with: it isn't very "goa," but it's good stuff, similar to Moonshine's
Psychotrance 1 (another good one) except it's not mixed. Moonshine also has
a Psychotrance 2 which IMHO isn't nearly as good as #1. Also, look for the
Blue Room Released Vol. 1 CD: sounds very, very Goa. has a good Juno
Reactor song.
Another good CD is Southern Fried House from sm:)e. There's a little bit of
house on it (mostly from the Mighty Dub Kats) but it sounds like mostly
ambient/trance, despite the name.

-mikey.

So I'm sure everyone watched President Clinton's State of
the Union address yesterday, where he outlined to congress
and the American people his vision for the future of the
country.  I thought things got interesting at the end when
he was talking about working together, finding common
ground, etc.  He signalled to Al Gore, who pressed a 
button, and all of a sudden music started playing.  Most
people looked a little confused, but a few started dancing
and pretty soon the entire place was on it's feet cheering
and shouting as the strobes kicked in; the highlight  for me
came when Senator Alfonse D'Amato and Hillary hugged each other...
And then I woke up.

Lee

>E-Mail: lmcagaylob@aol.com  (Laurie McBride, LIFE Executive Director)
