>ACTION ALERT   ACTION ALERT    ACTION ALERT    ACTION ALERT    ACTION ALERT
>
>AB 1982 (Pete Knight) ON A FAST TRACK . . . . . .
>
>308.5  A MARRIAGE CONTRACTED OUTSIDE THIS STATE BETWEEN INDIVIDUALS OF THE
>SAME GENDER IS NOT VALID IN THIS STATE.
>
>Wednesday, January 24, 1996:  The California State Assembly Judicialy
>Committee will vote on AB 1982 (Knight):  a bill to block recognition of
>our marriages in California.  The bill will likely pass, and go to the
>Assembly Floor for a vote NEXT WEEK.  Within two weeks the bill will be in
>the State Senate.  If we are to have any chance of stopping this bill, we
>need to act ***NOW*** . . .
>
>WE NEED ***YOU*** TO WRITE YOUR LEGISLATORS TODAY!!!
>This is the biggest threat to our civil dignity and our equality that we
>have faced in California.  We must respond as never before.  It must be
>clear that we will mobilize to fight this or any other attack.  Don't know
>your legislators??  Call the Registrar of Voters (in your phone book in the
>County Government listings).
>
>Senator Lockyer, as the Democratic leader of the State Senate, NEEDS to
>know that this is your number one issue.  Send him copies of the letters to
>your legislators.  We must have Lockyer's support if we are to stop AB 1982
>before it becomes law . . .
>
>Send those copies to Senate Pro Tem Bill Lockyer, State Capitol,
>Sacramento, CA  95814  (FAX 916/323-2234)
>
>EVERY ASSEMBLYMEMBER AND SENATOR NEEDS LETTERS -- FROM THE MOST LIBERAL TO
>THE MOST CONSERVATIVE.  OVER THE NEXT 2 MONTHS THEY WILL BE VOTING ON OUR
>LIVES -- DON'T LET ANY OF THEM CAST THAT VOTE WITHOUT HEARING FROM  *YOU*,
>THEIR CONSTITUTENT!
>
>SOME SUGGESTED POINTS FOR YOUR LETTERS:
>
>*  We are families:  some with children some without.  All families deserve
>legal recognition.
>
>*  We should be able to decide who we want to marry, not the State.
>
>*  California currently recognizes all marriages legally performed
>elsewhere.  Changing the law hurts married couples and their families, and
>would lead to confusion in the business world.  If you're married in one
>state, you should be married in all of them.
>
>*Marriage law should never be based on prejudice, as it was against people
>of color and interracial marriages until just a few decades ago.
>
>OTHER ACTION ITEMS:
>E-MAIL "FAMILY" LIST:  Become a Contact Point for LIFE's E-Mail Action
>Tree.  We'll e-mail action items to you and them you send them on to

>can help. . .  To subscribe send a message to:  lmcagaylob@aol.com

>        IMO.  "goa" trance is the "cheesy" or "unintelligent" side of 
>trance.  Trance without passion.  It's the only trance that isn't trance 
>inducing!  I believe it only earned a reputation as being "goa" because 
>record companies tried SO hard.  WHY?  Maybe because it is totally easy 
>to mass produce.  
>        I think goa is the opposite of underground.  The difference is in 
>the artist's intentions when they create the piece of music.  If it was 
>intended to trance them out, it will end up being more underground.  If 
>it was intended to sell records it will end up being more "goa"ey.  
>        It is hard to tell the difference at first, or distinguish what 
>is actually cheesy about it at all...  But it is NOT a product of the 
>underground.  When I and my friends go shopping for music, it has turned 
>into searching for the things that are the LEAST goa-ie.

Message-Id: <v02130500ad2c12cb8224@[206.5.32.54]>
Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nathan_moser@manual3.com (Nathan Moser)
Subject: Re: Synth's WHY NON RAVE!!
Date: Wed, 24 Jan 1996 17:54:39 +0000
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>It seems to me
>that alot of people don't know what raving is really about. It's the MUSIC.
>Without that there would be no D.j.'s, no dancing, no raves, just a bunch of
>people sitting around high, and I thought they called that a crackhouse.
>  I just wanted to say that I think that synths, dj equiptment, and music
>gear are more a part of raving than drugs, fashion, and politics which seem
>to be constantly talked about on SFRaves.
>                    music is life is love...
>                           Sean

I remember arguing this point a few months back with one of this list's
more volatile posters. He said   that it was the people that made raves
interesting, while I said it was the music that brought the interesting
people there in the first place. A couple months after that exchange, I was
at a party talking to a guy on the dance floor. It was a cool conversation,
though not too deep given the volume and the physical movement. When one of
my favorite tracks (a Union Jack tune) was mixed in, I shouted something
like, "wow! Isn't this music amazing!?" The guy said, "yeah, I guess so...
I really come to these things for the people..." At first I was kind of
disdainful, but then I started questioning why I thought my experience was
any more valid or profound just because I appreciated the music more than
he did. Who's to say that electroacoustic vibrations supercede those given
off by interesting people?

Mind you, I still generally follow my favorite music whereever it may go,
and I inevitably find my favorite raver people there dancing to it. Still,
the majority of my friends - certainly those not into the rave scene - do
not share my fixation with trance and techno. It doesn't lessen my
friendships, it just means we tend to talk about other things.

I've come to the opinion that good raves are symbiotic interactions of
music, people, vibe, DJs, visuals, and even the space it's located in.
There's no one centrally important element. As such, I think that's a
pretty good analogy for everyday life itself.

take care!
-nate

Hey Ed,

>From what your description of Goa trance (psychedelic trance) it seems that
you probaly haven't *really* listened to it.

To me it is the most powerful underground movement in the world 
Look what is happening in Israel right now, their government is
putting pressure on the indian government to stop the parties in goa,
because all the israelis are going there after their tour in the army and
are totally flipping out. Their all going back to 
Israel and having joint parties with the palastenians - imagine that. What
years of negotiations has not accomplished a music
so powerful has. And it is not only Israel it is happening all
over the world. ]

A lot of people say you need to be on drugs to apreciate goa trance. All you
really need is a open mind and really listen with your heart and then you
will see that the music is very organic in nature, that the melodies are
always evolving, and are not just looped samples. 

In by your definition of underound you are stating that goa isnt 
underground because it has a mass apeal and unification of various sounds so
that people from all over the world can dance together as one, then yes,
mabye it is commercial. My personal belief is to make the underground
culture the norm in society and 
the commercialist, bankers, tree cutters etc. the outcasts.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

In a message dated 96-01-24 01:31:22 EST, you write:

<< Things like "It's killing me, you've given me the death 
sentence" and "I'm gonna be this way for the rest of my life" and "I 
hope you have a good life".  I don't know what to make of this, I hope 
I'm making a bigger deal out of it than it really is, but I can't help 
worrying about it.  This is someone I loved very much, but  >>

I can relate with this kind of talk, but sometimes it is just to make you
feel guilty.  When my X said stuff like that, it made me feel really bad and
made me want to fall back and give it another chance, if they sound so
desperate you think they might change. So watch out this could possibly be
his motives.   In my case, I fell back into the relationship 1 too many times
(3 years)  and finaley I came to my senses and realized changes were not
going to happen.  It is very hard when you love that certain someone very
much, but know you need to get out because your not happy.  I would watch for
signs that others have given you but try to keep your distance, if he knows
he is getting your attention the more he will keep scarying you with his
threats.  It is just human nature I think for a lot of guys to react this way
to break ups.  Sorry guys!!!

Pam

        I just wanted to add a few non-rave (well, ok, raving _is_
partially about being happy to be alive but anyways..) thoughts on the
suicide/depression thing.
        First is that Seasonal Affective Disorder may be a problem lately,
it's hellish being in montreal where i walk around smiling on overcast
snowy days to see everyone bummed out! Remember to get lots of full
spectrum sunlight if you have a feeling this is you :)
        Also, generally speaking, what i've learned about depression (after
being through it for most of my life is that the crucial thing about
depression is _knowing_ what it is like to be happy. If you don't have that
to measure your mood against, you think that you're 'normal' when (at least
with me) you were miserable. Suffering is not normal, being depressed is
not normal and while everything _is_ somewhat relative, you still have the
power to be as happy as you want. but you have to want to!
        best of luck with the situation, shawna,
                hugs,
                        brad

Since quite a few of you seem to be interested in finding good trance 
compilations on CD, I thought I make a list of the ones I have and recommend.
Here goes nothing:

Trance Nation 1-6+95. 2 unmixed CDs + 1 mixed CD. The only bad thing 
about these CDs is the low sound level. :) (and the second CD on #6 is 
just a tad bit too housy for me...it's still trance though.)

Rave Mission 1-5. 2 unmixed CDs. Volume 5 is a "jubilee box" and has an 
extra mixed CD. It's not only trance, some acid and rave as well.

RaverMeister 1-2. 2 unmixed CDs.

Dream Injection 1. 2 unmixed CDs.

Cosmic Cubes 1-2. 2 unmixed CDs.

HyperRave 1-4. 1 unmixed CD. Somewhat commercial trance (close to some 
euro even), but a good compilation.

TranceMental Music 1. 1 unmixed CD. Hardtrance from Cologne, Germany.

Nordic Rave 1. 2 unmixed CDs. The best of Scandinavian trance. Get it!


These are a few of the ones I have. They are mostly german trance and 
kick ass! If you want to know more, just let me know! =)

DJ Eskimo (Jonas)

Mr. Darkness,

I sometimes wonder why you post so often. Is it because you *truly* have
something to say, or is it because you enjoy seeing your bright smiling
ASCII repetively conveyed for us to wade through?

I'm curious how you recieved the post you list below. I never created any
such post, nor do I appreciate having any such post relayed to the list
without my permission.  

Are you making things up? Is someone posting with my sig? Or is there
perhaps another Jonas on this list? 

To clear the air, I like House (yes, the thing you - and the rest of us -
live in). I might own a Trance record store, but I love House music. Kinda
crazy, I know, but I was always one for doing something different.

I feel my involvement with Frequency 8 (the store, not the parties) sets a
precedent for many who have become set within one genre of music. There's a
LOT of underground music out there. Whatever genre you prefer, I feel it'
all heading in the same direction - to facilitate the opening of our minds
and encouraging the seeking of a higher conciousness.

So be it House, Ambient, IDM, Trip Hop, Goa, Jungle, or whatever, it's all
good music. Just DIFFERENT - get it? Different strokes for differnt folks.
Who's to say what is better?   

I find it ironic for a community as open minded as ours, that we can be so
divisive as to our musical tastes. What a bunch of hypocrites.

Please advise and explain yourself at your earliest convenience.

later...


Jonas Judd

I was there.  I played at that show.  That was Rig-a-Tony's record.  I
remember we were doing the ambient room when he came running in and grabbed
a record and ran back out, then I heard it.  I wasn't having a very good
night, and didn't get into the circle when it formed...but I watched, and it
was pretty beauitful. I remember the ambient room had tons-o-bleed through
of sound from the main room.  There was only a sheet of plastic seperating
them.  I could not hear what I was playing even with the monitor blasting in
my ear.  I was beat mixing some slow kinda dubby stuff and royal screwed it
up.  I couldn't even tell at first that it was messed up cuz I couldn't hear
it.  Then Tony looks up at me like "What the fuck are you doing", then I
hear "Ha Ha Ha Ha Ha...Ha Ha Ha Ha Ha"...coming from the music in the main
room.  It was the first time I heard the song "Don't Laugh".  It fueled my
misery to unprecedented hights.  

Well, the whole scene was alot different for me then...I didn't really feel
it like I do now.  Can't wait til Sat.

Rick

I'm afraid I only caught the last posts on this subject, regardig what
sounded like some advice on dealing with someone who mentioned suicide: I
would like to input:  BE CAREFUL, you're all in the right peter,  suicide is
real, and like aids or drug abuse it isn't going to go away when we turn our
backs.  Ian (Nutralight Visuals) Lillibridge was my best friend for over 10
years.  He commited suicide just over 3 months ago, much to the surprise of
myself, his girlfriend, and the entire sacramento scene.  I am not an expert,
but peters advice seems well said.  Perhaps have a mutual friend talk to him
and assess the situation. The only advice I can give is to do everything you
can, but be cautious of immersing yourself in the process.  Your friend is
the only one that can truly make a differnece in the outcome.  I can also
tell you that strangely enough some of the signs I was aloof to with my
friend's suicide were an increased level of creativity and spirit in his last
days, an unusual socialness.  And I guess some subtle references to suicide
methods were mentioned to his girlfriend, at this point I would consider the
situation very dangerous and not hesitate to have him/her hospitalized.  Take
care of yourself, and keep in touch.
Love & life,
Steveo

On Thu, 25 Jan 1996 MEAD@uwplatt.edu wrote:

> Gabber is related to "techno"
> it typically moves over its victims at 200+ BPM
> and says fuck and bitch a lot....

	I think the BPM can be dropped to about 180+. And a lot of the 
samples have nothing to do with "bitch" and "fuck". Maybe my 
characterization is wrong, but this is what I took as gabber when I lived 
in Scotland:
	180+ BPM
	hard hitting kick drums
	has dark undercurrent (the strong, well defined kick of the kick drum
		helps with this).
	No divas

	Some current records like VDD Energize's Belgium Frites have no 
reference to any type of "obsenity" but it is hard and dark as hell. I 
have heard that the Kotzaak releases are the same and if Rebecca will 
surface in Oakland I can tell you from personal experience.
	There was this sound system called Sativa that did a fornightly 
club and the occasionly free festi (with a few other systems) that 
provided the environment where I came to appreciate the energy that 
gabber can produce. Imagine 200+ people crammed into a basement where 
everyone is shoulder to shoulder and there is a dripping off the ceiling 
cuz everyone is sweating but you don't notice the heat cuz the music and 
the people are both making you dance harder. And the harder you dance, 
the more energy there seems to come frm the music which makes you dancee 
harder which makes the people around you dance harder cuz they feel the 
energy coming off you and then you have to dance harder cuz their energy 
is filling you up to a point where you simply cannot not dance harder 
(you might think you are going to get very tired soon), but this energy 
just keeps going round and everyone keeps going til it ends and the 
Sativa drummers do their thing and everyone has this big smile on their 
face on the way out (into the freezing air of Edinburgh with steam still 
pouring out of the door you just came out of).

dave

	id QAA05575; Thu, 25 Jan 1996 16:56:43 -0800

Subject: rave/ritual LONG

Precedence: bulk


i apologize for the length and the messiness. comments are welcome.



aced themselves in oppositon to the integrity of the bounded nation-state.  	So-called "youth" cultures or "counter" cultures have always delighted in their rejection of and separation from dominant cultural discourses such as mass or popular culture.  While the separation of what I will call "underground" discourses, the catagory in which renegade parties or raves fall into, may be physical and ideological, they are tethered to popular culture by the media.  "The idea that authentic culture is somehow outside media and commerce is a resilient one...that grass-roots cultures resist and struggle with a colonizing mass-mediated corporate world." (Thorton, 176)  In this excellent article on "Moral Panic, the Media and British Rave Culture," Sarah Thorton amends Bordieu's framework and discusses the subcultural capital of the underground.  In particular, it is the economic indiscipline of youth, that are in the stage of life "exempt from the...accumulation of ecomonic capital."!
   The primary difference between s
ubcultural capital and economic capital is in how it ages; subcultural capital deteriorates with age, as it is specifically defined against popular or mass culture, which can be associated with older age groups.  Thorton claims it is not the police that are the antagonists of the underground, but the media, who threaten the very boundries of this discourse by "[continually threatening] to release their cultural knowledge to other social groups." (Thorton, 179).   If the cultural knowledge of the underground is, via the media released to other social groups or the mass media, it changes the subcultural capital and  in effect makes it not as underground or not as cool.  This may affect the raves themselves, forcing them to become more underground, and less accessible to those without a knowledge of how to get to them.	The police have an important role, as someone pointed out to me that it wouldn't be fun without the police, but from personal experience I believe it would be. !
  They form a huge part of the "oth
er" from which a space is taken and ultilized, and also more tightly binds the community against a common enemy; there is a shared sense of transgression, it is a terrorist act to claim space that does not belong to us, in the name of freedom to gather and dance.  Without the police to maintain the integrity of the bounded nation-state, there would be no social drama played out almost every night of the week in cities all across the countries- seemingly empty streets and warehouses from which a visceral throbbing eminates, and as as you get closer, if you look up to the high windows, you can see flashes of light and lasers.  There would be no breach of legality in noise level and drug use and people packed in tighter than cattle, their collective sweat dripping off the ceilings.  The police are highly symbolic as well as represent a very real potential for coming directly into conflict with nation state ideology. 	Nation state ideology, along with specific kinds of culture !
 form the boundry against which und
erground discourse itself is formed.  If the culture industry is truly a monolithic machine that spews out culture as easily as industry spits out tubes of toothpaste, then culture's role is to unwittingly subjugate the consumer back into capitalism, as if he strayed away in the first place.  Underground discourse tries very hard to break away from as well as spit in the face of capitalism and mass culture.  The culture industry works inside of the boundries of nation state ideology, and patrols its borders as well.  The content of art, or movies or any other type of "culture" may attempt to say something about the overweening culture machine, but the production, distribution and what materials produced it all were supplied and therefore controlled by the culture industry.  Underground discourse must participate in the system of prduction, but only so far.  Records and sound systems are bought, as are other items, but in many cases these parties are free or cost very little,!
  to cover only the cost of produci
ng the event and therefore,  in Marxist terms there is no surplus to be recycled back for the further production of capital- the cycle is broken.  	One kind of underground that has been very popular in the Bay Area the past five years has been the Full Moon Rave.  Held on the full moon, it aligns itself with another very ancient kind of underground discourse, the pagan.  These parties have been held at beaches up and down the Northern California coast and the ones I've attended have been held at Bonny Doon in Santa Cruz.  These parties are free and lately have had to start very late at night (1 or 2 a.m.) to avoid being shut down by the police.  "...beach.  Cove.  Cliffs. Pale green fields of brussel sprouts.   The pregnant moon over the ocean.  Royal blue. Dawn peeking yellow, orange, pink.  People searching for community."  (Kathy, personal communication)  Especially in Santa Cruz, this party brought together especially diverse elements of the population- there was a home!
 less guy stationed at the top of t
he beach threatening all who entered not to litter.  Wanna-be hippie kids with their dreads and nitrous balloons, the homeless and club kids, fashionably dressed with shiny shoes and stylish clothes.  They were all gathered around small fires, trying to keep warm and sharing water and dried apricots.	This was the essence of community.	In industrialized nations especially where passages through life are demarcated by aligning oneself within institutions that produce ideology, individualism can be signified by aligning oneself with a culture that defines itself aginst dominant or popular culture.  Underground culture believes that it struggles against mass media and the corporate world, that it represents an authentic, as opposed to popular culture.  Criticisims of mass culture as forms of entertainment claim that it merely serves to reinterpellate the consumer/worker into a system of production.   This rebellion against mass culture is a ideological as well as a physical reb!
 ellion.  It isn't illegal to gathe
r 500 people together at 11pm on a Saturday night in a sactioned spot to watch yet another cutsey Christmas tragicomedy that reinforces notions of what this culture relies on as "family", "religion" and gender roles, yet gather together 500 people, mostly young, to dance to techno, and suddenly you have an illegal situation requiring police interference.  		"The whole world is made to pass through the filter of the 	culture industry.  The old experience of the movie-goer, who 	sees the world ouside as an extension of the film he has just 	left...is now the producer's guildine.  The more intensely and 	flawlessly his techniques duplicate empirical objects, the 	easier it is today for the illusion to prevail that the outside  	world is the straightforward continuation of that presented on 	the screen." (Adorno & Horkheimer 1980)The culture industry serves to reflect commodity and worker culture and reinforces the roles that one plays in both.  Culture therefore patrols the!
  boundries of the nation-state, bu
t the nation-state patrols the boundries of culture- it is a cyclical interaction that involves finanical and ideological controls.  Ultimately, the state holds the power and authority that can be physically enforced.   	It is the looming threat of what the state can do to an individual that is on the minds of the organizers and ravers.  This knowledge binds all who are at an underground together, with the fact of them merely being there that threatens the integrity of the nation state.  Undergrounds threaten the ideology of the culture machine as well as the ideals that subsume human bodies to the maw of the nation.  They provide resistence against the cuture machine and break the cycle of production by providing commodities- the physical party and the subcultural capital without full participation in the system of production.  Victor Turner's notion of a social drama is useful as well to contextualize how the individual is actually breaking with a specific ideology and jo!
 ining another.	The template of Tu
rner's social drama is as follows:  breach, crisis, redressive and reintegration.  (Turner 34-35, 1987) The breach separates members of a group from everyday society, and takes place when one steps inside the space of a rave.  They are, in effect, are consciously choosing to accept the illegality of the space and simultaneiously rejecting the hegemony of governmental controls.  The crisis is the space of indeterminantcy or liminality- the rave itself.  Many raves go off without a hitch, but  many are shut down by the police and people are arrested.  I will discuss a particular case in a bit.  The space of liminality exists for the entire length of the rave.  There exists a palpable unknowing whether or not the police will show up.  The redressive part of social drama returns the participants back to the realm of society supposedly changed from their experiences, and reintegration is the ongoing recongnition that this particular "social group" will not be accetped and integra!
 ted into the society, because of i
ts illegal actions.  It is possible though, for the media to have some integrative effects by making undergrounds a part of mass culture.	  In one particular case, a personal experience on New Year's Eve 1994, the state did intervene, in the form of the police and the ABC (Alcohol Beverage Control), creating an actual "crisis" with redressive/reintegrative action still being played out.  	At four in the morning on New Year's day, in a warehouse in 	the SOMA district of San Francisco, the police and ABC arrived 	to break up on of the best parties I had ever been to. I had 	gotten there twelve hours earlier to help set up and the vibe 	of the place was so strong it had kept me going the whole 	time. There was a main room playing techno, a smaller disco 	area and an ambient room filled with bean bag chairs, and 	crowed with people. The party was the most diverse I had 	ever been to, mainly gay, and everyone was friendly.  I was 	curled up with some friends in the ambient roo!
 m when the 	lack of noise in the m
ain room drew our attention.  The lights 	had been turned on and the room was filled with several 	dozen cops and what we would find out later were ABC agents. 	The bliss had been suddenly and irrevocabley broken, and the 	vibe would soon turn violent.  The police rushed everyone out, 	but a long line formed to retrieve their things from the coat 	check. Suddenly, groups of police were wrestling party-goers 	to the ground.  Disbelieving the fierceness with which this 	party had turned ugly, I rushed to get my camera and 	starting snapping picturces of the police in action.  Soon I 	became a victim of that violence as I was grabbed from 	behind, my head ground into cement by a black boot and my 	camera was ripped from my hands.  Part of my New Year's 	Day was spent in jail, along with the eleven others who were 	arrested.  We are now in the process of sueing the City of 	San Francisco for the violence enacted upon us and the 	violations of our civil rights.In this case, unl!
 ike most raves, the warehouse was 
the residence of the party organizer and he had initially gone to the police and received what he thought where the necessary permits.  Another element to this party was that it was thrown and primarily attended by gay men,  and in San Francisco especially there is a long history of police violence against orgainized gay activies, themselves a marginalized group, bounded and othered by a patriarchial and homophobic discourse.  Although this party was not a rave, per se, it is a useful case to contextualize social drama.   The breach was entering what most partygoers (including the host himself) thought to be a legal party (which was an AIDS benefit) at which donations were encouraged.  Even thought the party was assumed to be legal, it was the sexual orientation of the parytgoers that engendered the breach, as they were all too familiar with police action in the past.  The crisis occured at moment the state, in the form of the police, entered the building, placing all those !
 inside at risk of being in conflic
t with state discourse, and an unlucky few became physically involved.  The redressive action started with the arrests and jailing of the "offenders".  The action of arresting and "processing" those who are found to be in conflict with state ideology carries a certain cultural currency and frees them changed- in the eyes of their fellow citizens and the state itself, which may require them to participate in the judicial system.  Ironically, the only way to undertake any redressive action, especially after you have been arrested is through their own bureaurocratic channels.  In this case we were lucky, the gay community was fed up with their marginalized status and lawyers took on the case pro bono.  The reintergration part of this particular social drama is involving suing the City of San Francisco.  With much political pressure, the Chief of Police has been required by the Mayor to subject some of the officers to discinplinary action.  This is an exceptional case, with an e!
 xtensive history that allowed it t
o go this far.  The media, in the forms of television, newspaper and radio have had a part, as have extensive networks of individual and concerned organizations, in making the public aware and making the nation state, in the form of the police and local government responsible for their actions.  Reintegration, according to Turner involves "reintegration of the disturbed social group, or of the recongition and legitimation of irreparable schism between the contending parties."  If the social drama runs its full course, the final phase "consists of actions restorative of peace" (Turner 35)  In this case, reintegration of the group is not possible as it is bounded by homophobia and the unacceptability of so called "alternative lifestyles" that essentially do not affirm the culture and ideology of the nation-state.  Restorative actions, which are currently tangled in the judicial process, the only legitimate form (to the state) of restorative action avaible,  just reinforces thi!
 s "irreparable schism" bewteen the
se bounded cultural entities.   	This example reinforces that the state, while composed of individuals always presents a monolithic facade, the police are a symbolic as well as a physical force.  That night they were wearing non-descript matching blue jackets over their uniforms.  There badges could not be seen and it was only the yellow SFPD emblazoned on the back of the jackets that signified they were part of the police force.  One of the attendants of the party kept yelling "Get their badge numbers. Get their badge numbers"  He was carried bodily and thrown into the same police wagon I was in.  That is what he got for brushing up against the state's boundry.   As part of the redressive action of this social drama, the Office of Citizen Complaints, themselves patroling the liminal space between legality and illegality- monitering the behavior of the police, was responsible for interviewing those that were involved.  Those interviewed got to view individual  pictures of p!
 olice officers and could point to 
them if they felt they were involved.  As a result of this, several officers will be subjected to disciplinary hearings.**badge numbers/faces= individual**	Because the breach with nation-state ideology is so easily made, it goes just as easily the other way, the breach is too easily realized and dealt with by the state.  Therefore, it must be acknowldeged that raving is not outside of culture.  It can, however, occupy a liminal space between legal and illegal and create a sacred space apart from, though not exclusive of production,  a space that is lacking in our culture for many people.  The space a rave occupies is physical and metaphorical- in many cases, a warehouse or a public beach becomes temporarily reclaimined and reappropriated from a secular and industrial space and transformed into a sacred one.  		"Undergrounds and renegades [parties] are inherently 	subversive gatherings.  They do not pay for the right/	permits to dance, they reclaim public land and  	parti!
 cipants often expenrience higher/i
llegal mind 	states." 						- The Little Red Rave BookThe leglity of the space is usually in question, at once taking the entire event and placing it into a liminal space, as according to the law, it is illegal and therefore subject to legal discourse in the form of police action.  There are variations on what is termed a "rave".  With names like "Roots", "The Gathering", "Friends and Family" and "Kundalini", they can the form of a large or small gathering and have dj's spin techno and ambient music.  Often the participants are engaged in a psychedelic mindset, from the music, drugs, vibe or some combination.  The production of a rave is not outside normal capitalistic modes of production, rather it seeks to use them and subvert them, in effect creating resisitence.  The principle difference between raves is those that seek to profit, normalizing capitalist modes of production within an underground discourse, and those that put on raves with the intention of creating comm!
 unity within that same discourse- 
production as play.  "Big raves and clubs do not pose the same threat....they create a heirarchy...[and] encourage divisions by having guest lists, fixed door prices...and overbearing security." (The Little Red Rave Book)  Both kinds of raves are usually put on by collectives composed of dj's, organizers and volunteers.  	There are three principle types of media that have a role in rave and greater underground culture- the internet, micromedia and print media.  The media serves a dual purpose, the first and most important to the subculture is communication, the other serves to parlay this so-called "scene" to the realm of mass culture which may have political outcomes.  The creation of a virtual community allows relationships to be maintained and parties to be planned.  There are mailing lists for events in the Bay Area and all over the world and there are forums for discussion of the planning and execution of raves and well as how well they went off.  It is an almost steri!
 le form of interaction compared to
 the quick and easy social interactions that take place at undergrounds, though it is necessary for the continuity of this community.  Micromedia are the flyers, often a genre of psycedelic artwork within themselves- they get posted on windshields of cars parked at parties and are available at suitably hip stores in major cities.  Print media which popularizes underground parties takes away some of their subcultural capital- they're no longer thought of as hip by the die-hard ravers, who either have stopped going for a while or are forced to make their parties less accessable and parlays them into mainstream youth culture.	A parallel can be drawn between the subsuming of human nature and individulism to the overweening culture of the nation state and the disappearance of the sacred, once occupying the place of opposition to the secular.  A blurring occurs because of the shift in what is considered "sacred" or "secular" and how they have become defined.  Some aspects of cult!
 ure, it can be argued, such as art
 and music have become utilized to create a respite from the secular, a sacred space that serves to remind us that there is more to life than work.  But if, as Adorno and Horkheimer argue, the products of culture we use to distance ourselves from everyday life and work institute us closer to them, then what is truly sacred space?  	In defining the rave as sacred, in opposition to the secular in culture, raving can be termed a ritual act or performance, or ritual play, according to Turner.  It is not so much that the actions one undertakes at a rave are ritualized, it is the mass experience of communitas, catharsis, and ecstasy- the shift away from what is regimented and secular.  The enactment of a rave is also a part of Victor Turner's notions of social drama fitting into his larger framework of play and performance.  The entire rave is a performance- a political and social one that demonstrates the ability of a collective to amass and transform secular space.  So why is i!
 t a sacred space and what are the 
components that would make this communitas?  	The secular world consists of specific events and interactions that differentiate it from the sacred.  There is work, buying and selling and carefully controlled interactions with others, a complex web of symbols that create and control society.  These actions all make explicit class distinctions as well as race and gender, and serve to separate people and create antagonistic relationships.  Sacred space is a healing space where people are brought together with differenent intentions and a common purpose, namely the creation of a community through music and dance.  "House culture and rave  culture are all about ecstatic expression and opening yourself up, and that's the attraction; I think that's what scares a lot of people, because it's so foreign." (The Cult of the DJ 68, 1994) The rave is a transformative performance that contradicts the separations of the social world.  It is a safe space of play in addition to political spa!
 ce.	It is important to not take f
or granted the roles our senses play in perceiveing and interepreting the world.  In the secular world, beyond our visual sense, they are rarely stimulated.  Control is key- control of our emotions and our impulses.  You could say that the secular world has been ritualized by work and how we interact socially to provide continuity and control. The sacred world makes a point of stimulating our senses to "awaken" us in other ways.  Raves stimulate the sense, rather, assault them.  Turner uses the term sensory code to denote the change the senses perceives in a performance or specific cultural space. (Turner 23) The room is usually hot, the music overbearingly lound, incense is burned and mixed with the smell of bodies.  Touching or hugging others is one of the final barriers of secular culture that is broken- these are the sensory codes of this particular space of performance and play.  Drug use is partially responsible and conducive to physical interactions that are not prece!
 ded by ritualisic encounters (in t
he secular world).  To embrace other people- hug and caress them and be caressed, this is one of the common practices of ecstatsy.  Entire groups of people, under the influence or not will spontaneouly form to cuddle and hug, a very physical acceptence into the social body.  The touch taboo of our society is broken- strangers are embraced and words are usually not necessary.  "What is your name" comes after, if at all, your personhood is the most important thing, the name is merely a marker.   	Dance and music and what most people would consider the most important elements of a rave and they stimlate the senses as well.  Dancing is a sacred, as opposed to secular act- it is the essential part of participating in the rave.  The way we move in secular space is conditioned by social norms and acceptablity and displays a capitalistic mindset- superfluous movement is unnecessary and unproductive, dance is ecstatic and sensual, "exuding gratitude and joy I dance.  When I dance I !
 am the interpreter." (Kathy, perso
nal communication)  It is also part of the collective performance of the rave.  For many people, a rave is the first place they learned to dance.  They felt comfortable enough in the atmosphere and driven by the rhythm to move and as some would argue, a collective surrender to a righteous vibe.  The DJ is very responsible for that vibe.  Why techno? Why is a single genre of music responsible for an entire underground discourse and all its parts?  As Patrick Farley describes it, "the music was a muscular, relentless, overpowering the lower chakras, a hard current into the human sex drive." (1991)  People describe not being able to stop dancing, being driven by the music.  Music which ironically sounds like machines.  He continues.  		"Mr. Floppy's crew pushed the music up to an impossibly 	higher level of intensity.  After non-stop for six hours, I 	believed myslef completely drained of energy but amazingly, 	found myslef sucked back onto the dance floor by an ineffable 	wh!
 irlpool of energy, surrendering my
 body and mind to that 	thundring beat.  Surely this was the same experience 	described by fire-walkers, Bacchanalians, Sufis and yogis 	throghout history, that moment whn the human body 	transforms into pure electricity." (Farley 1991)The beat is hypnotic and some claim that a mass trance engulfs overcomes the participants.  		"The Cult of the DJ" was part of a symposium on popular music and was a forum-style discussion by DJ's, music critics and others, that centered around the role and responsibilities of the dj and how he (very ususally a he) interacts with his crowd. Variously described as a collective experience, a community and a bodily experience, they all acknowledge that there is an electricity between the dancers and the DJ, they feed off of each others' energy. In this way the DJ is repsonsible, to an extent for what people feel .  "Part of the pleasure that the audience indulges in is giving up all of it's agency, becoming passive, becoming subject to the DJ's!
  will." (The Cult of the DJ 71)  T
hey build their reputations on good sets.  A good DJ is like a good lover, they can sense what you're feeling and they know how to work you to take you to higher levels.  DJ's are also "glorified consumers".  They "have access to records unavailable to other people, and they seen to be a part of an elite consumer club."  (The Cult of the DJ 72) To play their music, they must participate in some form of production, that is, they don't get their records for free, but in many cases they do play them for free which can be seen as resistence to the system of production.  	Dance, music with an unrelenting rhythm, sensory codes, and liminality- these are all part of the underground experience and compose the rituals which sucks the raver into a different space and plays out a social drama in which we all take part, actively or passively.  It is the pleasure that one experiences, the cartharis that you feel physically and knowing that you are ideologically breaking barriers that is!
  seductive about the underground. 
 There is a real sense of freedom and participation in that community that is together out of mutual desire to create joy and love.u

I caught a little of the new jungle party at Bahia last night - it
seems to be starting pretty strong, so check it out in the weeks to 
come.  Then I stopped by Roots/Black Diamond for their action - a 
decent crowd too.  

This weekend, the Groove Trip and Rain Dance parties seem to have the
biggest lineups; I'm not sure where they're supposed to be though.  I
don't know exactly what the Mixman thang is, but this weekend's party has
been scaled down from the original plan.

If anyone really wants to thank me for the calendar, you can send me
some Tom Waits tickets ;)...

   10-4. 415.512.5713 415.675.5660
   
   cosmic lounge - space jazz, galactic grooves, jungle. DJs Caspar,
   Paul, Seth + special guests. cafe mars, 798 Brannan @ 7th. 10pm-2am.
   No cover.
   
   Reunion - Danny, Naz Cafe & guests. 21+, 9pm-, free. The Fulton Bar,
   1243 Fulton Mall, Fresno. 209.488.5332
   
   Europa - ambient + experimental industrial. DJs from House of Usher &
   Winter Gone By. $5, 21+, 9pm-3am. 540 Howard St - rear entrance, SF.
   415.789.7359
   
   Energi - jungle w/residents DJ Flux and Abstract, plus guests. Bahia
   Cabana, 1600 Market. $3, 21+.
   [1/31 - DJ Thad & Stareyes]
     _________________________________________________________________

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.

     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338
     * The Groove Line - (415) 321.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bustop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
 Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

since we are all on this substyle definiton kick, how does gabber differ 
from old school hardcore?? On Thu, 25 Jan 1996, 'Dave Bayer' wrote:

> 
> 
> On Thu, 25 Jan 1996 MEAD@uwplatt.edu wrote:
> 
> > Gabber is related to "techno"
> > it typically moves over its victims at 200+ BPM
> > and says fuck and bitch a lot....
> 
> 	I think the BPM can be dropped to about 180+. And a lot of the 
> samples have nothing to do with "bitch" and "fuck". Maybe my 
> characterization is wrong, but this is what I took as gabber when I lived 
> in Scotland:
> 	180+ BPM
> 	hard hitting kick drums
> 	has dark undercurrent (the strong, well defined kick of the kick drum
> 		helps with this).
> 	No divas
> 
> 	Some current records like VDD Energize's Belgium Frites have no 
> reference to any type of "obsenity" but it is hard and dark as hell. I 
> have heard that the Kotzaak releases are the same and if Rebecca will 
> surface in Oakland I can tell you from personal experience.
> 	There was this sound system called Sativa that did a fornightly 
> club and the occasionly free festi (with a few other systems) that 
> provided the environment where I came to appreciate the energy that 
> gabber can produce. Imagine 200+ people crammed into a basement where 
> everyone is shoulder to shoulder and there is a dripping off the ceiling 
> cuz everyone is sweating but you don't notice the heat cuz the music and 
> the people are both making you dance harder. And the harder you dance, 
> the more energy there seems to come frm the music which makes you dancee 
> harder which makes the people around you dance harder cuz they feel the 
> energy coming off you and then you have to dance harder cuz their energy 
> is filling you up to a point where you simply cannot not dance harder 
> (you might think you are going to get very tired soon), but this energy 
> just keeps going round and everyone keeps going til it ends and the 
> Sativa drummers do their thing and everyone has this big smile on their 
> face on the way out (into the freezing air of Edinburgh with steam still 
> pouring out of the door you just came out of).
> 
> dave
>

Please visit http://www.travelpartners.com

Please enter the drawing!!!

My partner and I have a web development company.  We met (in the hot tub of the
now infamous "Blue House" of Santa Cruz) after a 92 Funky Tekno Tribe.

ANYWAY,

building the site we get to go to Belize (in May) as part of Team Travel for
free.

At the Travel Partners site people can enter to win a trip to Belize (in May)
with Team Travel.  This is for real, they're not selling anything (the prizes,
including the trip were donated by the sponsors)  We need more people to enter!

possible to enter. I'd really love to go to Belize with a fellow raver!!!

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: A revolution? Ponder this over the weekend!
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9601261528.A8820-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I had forgotten to ask about this earlier.
Noticed how really *REALLY* good parties have had more and more people 
attending them? (Chrysalis and F&F are the first to come to mind.)
While at Chrysalis I asked somone if he thought maybe it was because more 
and more people want to attend a genuinely good party and want to support 
what the scene is all about. "Yes, that has to be it!" said he. "So maybe 
this is like a raver revolution - 
we are finally getting what we want!" I exclaimed in happiness. 
Later that morning I asked another really close friend the same 
question.  He said no - it was more like people coming because it is the 
next cool party to go to.  It kinda burst my bubble.  Now I ask you the 
same question:  Why *ARE* there more and more people coming out to these 
low profile, not-highly-promoted, really down to earth, no sugar and 
cream raves?  I would especially like to hear from those who are involved 
in these parties to speak up.  Is it a phase or a revolution - or neither?

love,
Amy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 26 15:45:47 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA24660; Fri, 26 Jan 1996 15:45:47 -0800

          id AA10415; Fri, 26 Jan 1996 18:45:49 -0500
Date: Fri, 26 Jan 1996 18:45:49 -0500
Message-Id: <9601262345.AA10415@python.magnet.ca>
X-Sender: spooky@mail.magnet.ca
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: spooky@python.magnet.ca (renae satterley)
Subject: re: A revolution? Ponder this over the weekend!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My take on Amy's question is:  It is my current theory that more and more
people are getting serious about the music.  I think a lot of people (myself
included), when they first get involved in this scene, are entranced by the
new experiences, the new music, the drugs, the people, etc...  Many don't
really have time to seriously look at the music, or for that matter, the
quality of the party.  As people go more often, however, they start to
become aware of the quality (or no quality) of an event, which imho, is
rooted in the music.  At a certain point, people are more interested in
basic parties that are really good, rather than flashy parties that are only
so-so.  

Like i said, this is just my current opinion, which may explain why more and
more people are going to low-brow, high quality events.  Renae
            
`                          ~~~ spooky@magnet.ca ~~~
                             aka renae satterley
         "Nothing is ever the same as they said it was.It's what I've
never seen before that I recognize."  -Diane Arbus

I caught a little of the new jungle party at Bahia last night - it
seems to be starting pretty strong, so check it out in the weeks to 
come.  Then I stopped by Roots/Black Diamond for their action - a 
decent crowd too.  

This weekend, the Groove Trip and Rain Dance parties seem to have the
biggest lineups; I'm not sure where they're supposed to be though.  I
don't know exactly what the Mixman thang is, but this weekend's party has
been scaled down from the original plan.

If anyone really wants to thank me for the calendar, you can send me
some Tom Waits tickets ;)...

     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338
     * The Groove Line - (415) 321.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bustop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
 Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

to start the weekend off right and clear away some of the icicky vibes that 
have been wandering through sfraves, i thought a short passage from 
b.hoff's the tao of pooh would do us all some good.

"Let's  consider Emptiness in general for a moment.  What is it about a 
Taoist landscape painting that seems so refreshing to so many different 
kinds of people?  The Emptiness, the space that's not filled in.  What is 
it about fresh snow, clean air, pure water?  Or good music?  As Claude 
Debussy expressed it, "Music is the space between the notes"

"Wooh Baby!  Oooaowee BABY!  (Wanga wanga wanga.)  Baby, don't leave me!  
(Wanga wanga crash bang!)  Baby, don't LEAVE me!" (Click.)  Like silence 
after noise, or cool, clear water on a hot, stuffy day, EEmptiness cleans 
out the messy mind and charges up the batteries of spiritual energy."

hope to see some of you sfravers at the pacific party tonight or the sc 
party tomorrow.

peace*Jamie

involved with various and still spin), and I have seen and experienced so
many things, so many things come and go:  people, places, things, music
styles, Dj styles, Dj's, drugs, attitudes, venues, philosophies, you name it.

>>low profile, not-highly-promoted, really down to earth, no sugar and 
>>cream raves?
>
 Here are my thoughts: :
>        After discovering and attending a few raves, I quickly found myself
at less attended, no frills, more intamate parties, mostly due to the
friendlier vibe and the better intentions of the partygoers. By better
intentions I mean the people were not so concerned about image ( how
you/they look, how well they/you look on the dance floor as instead of how
much fun they/you are having ). I found the clubs to be too much of a meat
market atmosphere, too much of a fashion show & the 2 massives I attended
were dissapointing. The group of friends I partied with also enjoyed the
intimate atmosphere at smaller parties, where we could actually find one
another. We would always end up seeing the same folks and actually
developing relationships, It felt like a family. So I think the higer
attendance at smaller  parties can be attributed to the fact that ravers do
grow up, and I think  grow out of the main stream raves to attend less
glamourous events that cater to the vibe and the people not the allmighty
dollar.                            
>     
>         I also think that we can thank the people that promote and produce
these smaller events for they do it with vary little thought to how much $
they are going to make and alot of thought and energy in just throwing a
good party. Sunset is a good example. They throw a FANTASTIC free party, for
wich they only ask a donation for, and do it every week all summer. Now that
is dedication, and good intentions. My hat goes off to the Pacific Crew and
all the hole in the wall promoters for what they do for our scene.
>
>>  Is it a phase or a revolution - or neither?
>>
>>love,
>>Amy 
>>
>
>A phase...probably, a revolution.....hopefully. But if this is a
revoulution I hope these parties dont loose thier charm as they gain in
popularity. It would be a shame. But then again, there will always be the
little guys..... and the new parties.
>
>
HUGGZ,
>
Jennifer Susser
>
aka
>
little jen sus              
>

      ~ Increase Your Serenity ~

I've been following the music and the scene for quite a while also. Back
in my Manchester days where the dance/club culture flourished, the
hippie/tribal element was still in its infancy. There are many, many
people who thrive on this culture and while attitudes are as variant as
the people themselves there is often common treads the link our culture
globally. While most would say "the music", I think that the music has
changed and progressed, which is a  wonderful thing. I believe our
common link is our "open mind" attitude. This has allowed the scene to
grow, to bring people together. When we stop progressing, our minds will
close, and our culture will die. But this has happened before and new
cultures built from echoes of past cultures will emerge to start the
whole thing rolling again. I hope...

Be happy... JOB.

It was only 11:30 when I arrived and the line was huge - seemed like 
over 100 people waiting to get in.  Sean from Groove Trip told us all 
that they were already full to capacity and could not let anyone else 
inside.  I was at the end of the line, so I decided I didn't want to wait 
for who knows how long - so I came home.  Such a great party and only 20 
minutes away from my home - what a change *that* is!  I just feel bad for 
the others in that line who had come from farther away.  

But I am happy that Sacramento is putting on some good parties.  It's 
about time.  But as I write this, GT is only just beginning; so I hope 
for Sacramento's sake and for GT's sake that the party goes off!  Those 
on the list who made it in, please let us know how it was.

I'm gwan ta bed.

love,
Amy

Dear Friends & Family,

My computer tells me that on Tue, 23 Jan 1996, Eric Hill shared:

> "Starchild" [[I wonder why my name appears in quotes here?]] (among 
others) recently typed: > >> >>
> >> >> 	...[There seems] to me two possible solutions (besides 
> >> >> the obvious do-nothing option and the ways to decrease the likelihood 
> >> >> of violence at parties I outlined in the message you quote from above):
> >> >> 	(1) Try to remove the drugs from our scene, or
> >> >> 	(2) Try to remove the violence by getting them legalized, or at least 
> >> >> 		decriminalized.
> >> >> 
> >> >> 	I opt for the latter.
> >> >
> >> >                   I agree and go with option #2:).
> >> 
> >> I assume you both are willing to not do drugs until they are legalized,
> >> since you would be tacitly supporting the very same side effects you are
> >> trying to eradicate.
> >> 
> >> eh
> >
> >	That's a big assumption there, Eric... :)  Interesting dilemna 
> >though, I'd never really considered it that way.
> >	Frankly, I think curtailing my use would be sending the wrong 
> >message to the authorities:  It would contribute to the mistaken idea 
> >that the War On Drugs is working, thereby encouraging them to perpetuate 
> >it, with the resulting continuation of the violence.  
> >	After due consideration, my decision is that I will continue to 
> >break the law.  It is not for nothing that Dr. Martin Luther King said 
> >unjust laws deserve to be broken.
> 
> I wonder how many other drug-legalists view the War on Drugs as a matter of
> pride, that letting the prohibitionists think they're "winning" is worse
> than any possible good that might arise from that situation? Anyone out
> there care to comment?
> 
> I'm just looking for ways of changing that don't involve cool people getting
> shot. And hey, just because they *deserve* to be broken, doesn't mean they
> *must* be broken. I think there can be other ways.
> 
> eh

	When I speak of not wanting the authorities to think they're 
"winning" the War On Drugs (I think I used that term in a private email 
to Eric in response to a private message he sent me on this subject) it 
is not because my pride is such that I am unwilling to be a "loser" in 
this war.  I am less concerned with being "right" than with seeing the 
right results.
	The reason I don't want them to think they're "winning" is that 
this will allow them to justify the continuing persecution of non-violent 
drug users, and ensure that the violence surrounding the illegal drug 
trade continues well into the future.  
	The main force driving the growing public demand for an end to 
prohibition is not a sense that the Drug War is wrong, but a sense that the 
Drug War is *not working*.  Believe me, the Drug Warriors are eager for any 
successes they can point to at this point to justify the ongoing expenditure 
of vast amounts of yours and my money to pay for their crusade.  Personally 
I can't see any possible good arising from the continuation of this crusade.  
	Can you?
	
Yours In Liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jan 28 11:25:51 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA22387; Sun, 28 Jan 1996 11:25:51 -0800
Received: from netcom6.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA22382; Sun, 28 Jan 1996 11:25:48 -0800
Received: by netcom6.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id LAA15650; Sun, 28 Jan 1996 11:25:04 -0800
From: darrele@netcom.com (Darrel Etter)
Message-Id: <199601281925.LAA15650@netcom6.netcom.com>
Subject: mixman rip-off
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves)
Date: Sun, 28 Jan 1996 11:25:03 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2319      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk




Well, I was very confused, and a bit ticked off about the mixman thing
last night. 

I wanted to see Freaky Chakra and Bassbin Twins, so I went to the DNA
lounge. I paid $10 and walked into what looked like an office party
with Moria Carey playing. I should have left at that point, but I
proceeded to survey the premisis looking for signs of life. In the
back room , the VIP room, I found bunches of people with mixman
tee-shirts. It turns out the whole thing was some software package
release party, or just some demo of this mixman software. Bassbin
Twins were sitting around. They said they were supposed to spin, but
there were no turntables. I heard Doum (sp?, Mr Chakra) was there, but
clearly he was not going to be able to setup. I split around 1am
feeling like I do after a bad day at the shopping mall.

I knew that this mixman software thing was going to be there, but I
thought it would be on the side, and there would be real DJs and
Mr. Freaky. I can see why the United Systems event was canceled. This
looks like some marketing ass-holes clever idea for media attention.

There were even two TV stars there; Frazier and one of the acters from
Saturday Night Live. Very Weird!?!

The software was very un-interesting. It's a $40 PC package that has
two turntables on the screen ( very dumb ). It has 11 built-in sounds,
and you can play each from a different key "like you're a real DJ"
through your PC soundcard. There was no sound system, to speak of, in
the room.

I feel sorry for Bassbin twins and Freaky Chakra. I'm sure they were
equally confused. I can only hope that the mixman people didn't expect
them to "mix" on their cheesy little software game. That's my guess,
and if its correct, they should be banished to working the record
department at K-MART!

I met some others there like me who where confused and a bit
pissed. Some nice lads from Canada were very happy to find someone
else (me) who thought the scene was all wrong. One of the lads wanted
to interview Mr Chakra. I gave them my sfraves calender printout, and
went home.

I guess I was fooled by the mention of United Systems, or maybe I just
left too early. I suggest that if the "postponed" thing with United
Systems and mixman ever happens ( which I doubt ), that it be avoided
like the plague.

-Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

You wrote: 
>
>
>I had forgotten to ask about this earlier.
>Noticed how really *REALLY* good parties have had more and more people 


>attending them? (Chrysalis and F&F are the first to come to mind.)
>While at Chrysalis I asked somone if he thought maybe it was because 
more 
>and more people want to attend a genuinely good party and want to 
support 
>what the scene is all about. "Yes, that has to be it!" said he. "So 
maybe 
>this is like a raver revolution - 
>we are finally getting what we want!" I exclaimed in happiness. 
>Later that morning I asked another really close friend the same 
>question.  He said no - it was more like people coming because it is 
the 
>next cool party to go to.  It kinda burst my bubble.  Now I ask you 
the 
>same question:  Why *ARE* there more and more people coming out to 
these 
>low profile, not-highly-promoted, really down to earth, no sugar and 
>cream raves?  I would especially like to hear from those who are 
involved 
>in these parties to speak up.  Is it a phase or a revolution - or 
neither?
>
>love,
>Amy 
>
>---------------
>|   _  ,/|    |
>|  '\`o O'    |
>|   =(_^_)=   |         Amy Starkey
>|     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
>|     | |     |      
>---------------

>

How are you?  I've been wondering some of the same things about these 
parties and have been thowing them for close to a year with my two 
partners David and John.  We believe firmly, that these events hold a 
spiritual value that can penetrate anyone if correct symbolisim, 
attitude,  music, and care are sincerely given.  So yes I believe that 
there is somewhat of a revolution going on from groups of party 
throwers that really take this seriously and are not motivated by big 
money.  We know that it takes money to make it happen but we also know 
that if you put back in continuiously with a level head it will grow in 

a positive direction.  These may just be the parties to go to for now 
however we are trying very hard to protect and at the same time feed 
the quality of these events.  It's a difficult balance to maintain, I 
believe it requires a family-like structure and honesty with the party 
throwers and goers.  A little trust can go a long way.  We want to see 
just how far.  What you believe and say creates a reality for others, 
so if you feel there is some sort of revolution going on - there 
probably is.  You with others that sense this are also giving and 
creating it, if others haven't figured it out do not doubt yourself but 

help them figure out and create it.  All is one.  Hope this message 
finds and leaves you in good spirits.   -Claire Korich
                Gateway Systems  Feel it - Love!

is it bad for you ?  i know it has nothing to do with raving, and probably
most of you have a negative opinion about it, but i just did it, and was 
wondering if i was doing my body a misfavor.  a roomy of mine had some, 
and after the superbowl, and drinking all day, he pulled out a rock and 
we all did it.  

it didnt really do much for me.  a little rush, but i dont feel a 
complusion to do more, and i thought it was supposed to be addictive as 
all hell.  

i think its a lame drug, and cant really understand how you can become a 
crack addict.  maybe that is all media hype.  maybe it is just my 
reaction to a particular drug.  

hope everyone had a great weekend !  i sure did !

bye all !

hugs to all !

doug

amy and some others responded (i think immersive arts) right before an 
FnF, i think the halloween one. this seems to be a reoccuring theme on 
our minds, as it pops up from time to time. but we always wonder wether 
were idealists wanting a revolution and thus seeing one, or wether there 
really is something deeply profound happening with our consciousness and 
all of humanity. (this is about where ecto joins in on the conversation:) 
i think that if we choose to see it, then our own desire influences what 
we see, but then if this is true, that doesnt mean were just idealists. 
because even if we see something that isnt there and believe it is, then 
*we will still act accordingly* to our belief it is there. and this 
*action* is what sets it in motion. each one of us has a little power to 
influence our environment according to our perception of it. so now 
picture us gathering together in love and harmony, each creating with our 
own energy and perception of change and love, gaining momentum, because 
others want to see what were about. 
and they too see it, because were influencing their perception thru the 
vibe were creating, and their perception in turn does the same thing.
its like the gaia theories. or morphogenic feild resonance. what it comes 
down to is we all have that power, that inner light,and when we come 
toghether to share it something beautiful *does* occur. and in keeping an 
open mind, we accept others into our "family of light" (copyright:)
and grow. evolve. change.
so maybe it wasnt there to begin with, but just the fact that were 
thinking it *now* is *setting it in motion.* 

so dream out loud, friends!
	evolution of energy:) tom

        Some people will tell you that it will rob you of your mind & soul.
Some, like me say, gee this was really anticlimatic, and never did it again.

especially if you develop a taste for it. I had to do that with cocaine,
before I waisted a lot of time & money on it. My advice to you is stay stay
from it, & football for that matter, they will both rot your brain; &
epecially if you like the Cowboys.

Thank you thank you so much to everyone for the kind thoughts during 
my surgery and recovery. The support from you all was wonderful and 
truly helped lessen my anxiety.

The update: The doc says that I'm recovering speedily, more quickly 
than expected! I can see out of my right eye, I can read large type, 
and it aches quite a bit. The pupil is still HUGE, it's red and kinda 
swollen, lizard-like with the cut lashes, and everything looks like 
an over-exposed photo. Eventually my vision should be back to it's 
"normal" 20/40, I should be able to read fine print within two 
months, and the pain will gradually diminish. Of course, the lashes 
*will* grow back so I won't be a lizard-eye forever.


Thanks again to everyone for your kind and healing thoughts, your 
support and love. I don't think I can say anything to thank you all 
enough, but thank you!

Big hugs,  +++++
Alissa

On Sun, 28 Jan 1996, Tom Leichardt wrote:

> i think that if we choose to see it, then our own desire influences what 
> we see, but then if this is true, that doesnt mean were just idealists. 
> because even if we see something that isnt there and believe it is, then 
> *we will still act accordingly* to our belief it is there. and this 
> *action* is what sets it in motion. each one of us has a little power to 
> influence our environment according to our perception of it. so now 
> picture us gathering together in love and harmony, each creating with our 
> own energy and perception of change and love, gaining momentum, because 
> others want to see what were about. 

I absolutely believe in that, Tom.
When directly relating it to these great parties that more and more 
people are attending, I can see 2 things happening:

1: The realization you talked about above - lots of people gathering 
together for love and hoarmony, etc. with partythrowers like Claire and 
co. keeping the greed for the almighty dollar nil.

2: Then I see these parties getting bigger and bigger (still staying 
"true" though) and those who are convinced that massives simply are not 
good parties to go to because of the reputation that massives have. Then 
we will go full circle again with the smaller no name renegades - just 
when we have the momentum going!  Can you imagine the energy a rave can 
have if it has the vibes of a Friends and Family but the size of the 
Gathering?!?!??  Who needs substances!

In any event, I am looking foward to how F&F, Gateway, Pacific, 
Frequency-8 and others change and grow this year. 

love love LOVE,
Amy (Starkey)

I am relaying this message for Sean (Groove Trip), it may not be word for
word.  Please don't pastebomb my mailbox or anything, I didn't get in either!
-----------------------------0---o-------------
We are very, very sorry that we could not accomodate all the good people that
showed up Saturday night.  We lost our original space and had to use a
smaller warehouse.  By 11PM we had nearly 1,000 people, already over max
capacity.  Aside from the fact that we needed to assure everybody a
reasonable amount of oxygen in there, we also had the firefolks and the popo
threatening to shut us down all night.  But we can promise that we'll do our
best make room for all of us in the future.  
Thanks-    Sean, Jason, Erin

P.S.  A really big thanks to all those who packed the energy in as tight as
the bodies, making it known that we're growin, in & outside of Sacramento.

Actually, Doug, I think it's entirely appropriate.  SFRaves is a bunch of
different things to different people.  If the authorities monitor this list
then it's in your judgement wether or not to post.  If the suggestion is
that it's "off-topic", then how 'bout half the other posts here such as
"I've had a bad day and I need some energy" or "I'm looking for an ISP."
These aren't strictly rave-related, but then again, one doesn't need to be
on SFRaves long to see that it discusses many topics which may not be, in
the strict sense, rave-related.  In light of this, I think that your
question is welcome here; I'm sure you're not the only one of the hundreds
of readers here who would like to know the answer to your question.

Jake

Subject: Raindance Review
In-Reply-To: <199601300001.AA079470118@hpcc119.corp.hp.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.960129170212.20315C-100000@elaine41.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Heya all,

	I went to RainDance this weekend, and had a good time. This was 
the first time I've seen the Acme warehouse open on all three levels.  It 
was a good thing, otherwise the whole place would have been way too 
crowded (a common problem at Acme).  Frankly, I'm getting a bit tired of 
the Acme warehouse and in particular of that evil, narrow staircase at 
the entrance... There simply isn't enough room for people to maneuver in 
that place, and the stairwell is too steep/narrow/dangerous to accomodate 
400+ people trying to get out in an emergency.  I have 
scary thoughts about what might happen in the event of a fire... <shudder>
	But, enough of that.  The party was really enjoyable, although 
not quite worth $15.  The crowd was different from my 'usual' 
gang.  There seemed to be many more youngsters (highschoolers) than I am 
used to.  Nonetheless, the vibe was pretty strong and everyone boogied 
hard.  I didn't see a single laminate, although I did see the 
indefatigable Cap'n Crunch boucing around.
	I spent most of the night on the ground floor, 
where Tracy spun a wicked set (as usual), and then some other guy I don't 
know came in between her and Garth.
	There was jungle spinning on the second floor, and some trancier 
house in the basement, although I can't be sure 'cuz I didn't spend much 
time in either of those locales.  The second floor turned into a big 
chill room early on, so the DJs responded in kind with mellower music.  
Some DJ I've never seen before, named Pollywog, was spinning there around 
3am.  She/he (sorry, I couldn't really tell...) had *really* cool hair and 
plastic gremlin ears (?!) and was spinning some gruvy shit.
	I left at 3:30am (early Sunday meeting), but overall had a swell 
time.  It was nice to hear some thumping deep house after a long sojourn 
of acid and trance.  (although I still prefer the latter!)
	I went home and slept through my meeting.  Feh.

		take care all,

			jon--Oven broiled, not deep fried like the others!

                 Travis, Garth, Tracy.

A new weekly brought to you by Donovan and T-Bone:  Solid State at the 
End Up on Friday nights.  This one starts this week and features Garth 
as Resident with another guest. Solid Grooves, Solid Vibes and No House 
Music (That is what the flier says).  For the best in classic disco, 
funk, soul, and rare groove...Free before 11 $8 afer.  @ The End Up at
6th and Harrison. 21 and up.

              The Chunk (featuring former members of Psychefunkapus).
