On Jan 29,  6:29pm, John Bagus Haig wrote:
> Subject: Re: Perceptual effects (fwd)
>
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> Date: Fri, 26 Jan 1996 12:36:28 -0800 (PST)
> From: ******@cyborganic.com
> To: mind-space@macc.wisc.edu
> Subject: Re: Perceptual effects
>
> >Personally I enjoy rock for what it
> >was (and still listen to it), but I believe the genre to be mostly dead
> >now and that the true innovation and inspiration is in Rave music.  Raves
> >are particularly good for tripping I find because the lack of lyrics
> >allows for broader interpretations, deeper thought and a non-literary
> >frame of reference.  It is also exciting to gain insight into group
> >dynamics and the power and energy of many people on a higher plane.

	opinion watch!  do not forget to insert (for me)'s in these statements.

> WHile I appreciste the rave scene for striking out on its own and shedding
> tired old cliches about what psychedelic means, a drum machine will never
> be as effective at communicating meaning as a human drummer.

	you for got to add "to me" at the end.  well, you sort of do later.
	anyway.  i am a trap drummer of 15 years, and a "rave" musician
	(chill music and dance) and a dj.  dj's communicate with the crowd.
	when i spin, i don;t just play my records.  i agonize over the
	choices, "feel" when the crossfade should occur.  i get off on
	watching people in the crowd get off, watching them feel where
	the are and let me take somewhere.  i watch them intently.  i am
	most definately communicating meaning.  i want them to feel
	something specific with my craft.

	not to mention my live music.  human-controlled filter sweeping
	can send people into fucking outer space.  i have seen it, i have
	been the human on the one knob.  i have clicked a mouse between
	sequences with one hand, controlled a single filter with another
	while surrounded by people going completely apeshit wacko with
	dancing euphoria - a few joining in on didgeridoo or bongos.
	it's not always the medium.  many mediums can convey the message.
	it's like saying that you can only get the truest meaning of
	something if it is spoken in chinese, when in fact it is just
	another way of saying somthing.

	a drum machine obviously cannot play drums like a drummer. and
	people on teevee are not in the same room with you as you watch it.
	this is kind of a non-issue with me.  the music is different, a
	live drummer is not needed to pund out relentless, perfectly
	repeated beats to help induce trance states.  we are not trying
	to sound like drummers, we are trying to beat fucking fractional
	math into dancers heads to send them out farther, to distract
	their conciousness so they can finally forget about it and fly
	around outside their body for a while.  if you don't get off
	this way, hey, that's fine.  some people get off on jesus and
	feel the same effects.  whatever it takes.

	in the end, it is about what gets you off.  just be aware that
	there really are people composing this music, and the dj's and
	live artists are just as into setting up hardcore feedback loops
	between themselves and their audiences.  i mean, things have to
	be happening like that when you see a room with 200 people
	erupt into simultaneous screams when the music is *on* and the
	dj does a killer crossfade.  this happens.  i have seen it.
	in fact, someone not paying attention, walking in the room, might
	not notice it as much as when you feel it, because part of that
	screaming is a rush of energy that the group of focused individuals
	create around themselves.  i have seen this not just at raves...
	actually the most intense time i experienced this was at a hemp
	festival put on by the holy hemp sisters in santa cruz - my friend
	was hit by the rush so hard that it knocked him over.  without
	question, this happened at dead shows.  sufis, native american
	sundancers, jesus' yoga tricks on the cross, 3 hours of masturbation.
	whatever man.  it's about getting off.

> From my own
> little demented experiences at live concerts with humans at the wheel, I
> find that they can anticipate the mood of the room and change gears
> spontaneously according to the zeitgeist of the second, to the point where
> I've smelled key changes and beat braks in the middle of nowhere, just as
> the musicians did as they performed.

	again, i assert that dj's and live techno artists have the
	same powers.  i have seen it.  granted, you are talking about
	the best experiences you have had, and have been fortunate to
	find your best experiences in the dead, who were quite adroit.
	i mean, you will find more "rave" parties that suck than dead
	shows.

	i have seen the same exact behaviors at good parties that i have
	seen at dead shows.  even spinners.  eben the same jokes, man!
	"why do deadheads/ravers dance like this? (wave hands in the
	air)  --  to keep the music out of their eyes!"

> THAT's why people flip for the dead,
> theycan tell that they are part of what makes the music go. A dj will never
> be able to respond with anything like the sophistication of a musician.

	a dj is a musican.  you have not seen the right dj's, or
	watched them.  watch andre lucero spin a set, up close.
	someone like him who practices 4 hours a day would probably
	be rather offended at the narrowmindedness at which their
	art is being viewed in this sentence.  no offense, dan, just
	be careful.  people have *plenty* of mean, nasty shit to
	say about the dead, some of it sounds like this.  i could
	harp on the fact that bobby *never* sang harmonies on pitch.
	but you know what?  people *liked* it anyway.  so who cares.
	the feedback loops do not require acoustic, two-drummer rock
	bands to make them happen.  listen to qaawal (sp?) music -
	nurat fateh ali kahn.  listen to most *anything* that is done
	from the heart.  because it doesn't get you off does not mean
	that it is bogus.

	dj's, good ones, are artists of human soulful musical communication.
	different hardware, different software, same wetware.  ik.  sorry
	i got a little too /mondo2k/ on y'all there.  what you are talking
	about here is taste, nothing more.  and the misconception that
	drum machines are supposed to 'replace' drummers.

> Think about shamanism - where do they get to, how do they reach into the
> people in the room?

	not with the greatful dead, or guitars, or amplifiers, or bill
	graham, or turntables, or analog synthesizers.  they have their
	own way, just like you and i do.

> -dan

	that reminds me, we gotta jam sometime soon!  bring over your
	gear again!

From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>

I was really looking forward to Rain Dance since I hadn't heard Jeno and Garth
spin for a while -- but didn't get what I expected -- 

The main floor was SOOOO crowded, it was out of the question after about 1am
(but Tracy's set when I got there was right on) -- so I spent most of my time
upstairs and had the amazing experience of listing to Polywog, (yes a woman and
an awesome one) spin the most outrageous crazy mix of "don't ever think you can
predict what I'll spin next" stuff -- she played Close Encounters, which totally
put me over the top, since that's my metaphor for what raving is about.
Remember in Close Encounters, the people who were drawn to that mountain didn't
know why, didn't know what it was, and didn't know what they'd find there -- but
they had to be there, and be there together -- That's what raving is to me --
anyone who is drawn to be there belongs there -- and having her play that
awesome sequence where the mother ship not only communicates with us earthlings,
but takes off with that riff -- that was really awesome.  Then she'll happily
mix in off-beat rap, Rolling Stones, gospel, weird minimal tones -- anyway, if
you've never heard her spin, look for her and you'll hear something really
unique.

The energy there was really great and friendly, and I want to thank everyone I
met and saw there for their great spirit -- and thank everyone who appreciated
my white feather hat -- 

See you at Wicked!  Leslie : )

Cc: Doug Fairclough <kensey@wired.com>

Doug,

crack is evil, stay away. I had a friend who got seriously addicted to it,
to the point of smoking it all the time, spending $500+ a week on it, lying
to all his friends and girlfriend, and finally attempting to kill himself.
He could not stop on his own, and was doing it behind a lot of people's
backs, when he'd said he had stopped.

It may not be addicting the first time, but I guarantee if you do it a few
more times (taking its seriously addictive properties lightly), you WILL
become a crackead. Your statements about how you don't really understand
how it could be so addictive exactly echo my friend's response the first
time he did it. It was this "I don't get it" response that caused him to
seriously underestimate the power of this substance. By the time he
realized what had happened, he was a hopeless addict. He is still battling
the addiction - he claims that he craves it daily - even though he hasn't
done it in over 6 months.

I don't mean to sound like a hard-line "drugs are bad" fanatic - but I've
seen firsthand the damage that crack can do. You don't want to go down this
road. I would STRONGLY urge you not to do it again, and to try to get your
friends to stop as well.

- Brian Benitez

yes, i agree, STAY AWAY FROM IT.  crack (and crank) IMO are drugs that 
bring you to a lower level of consciousness and all you become aware of 
is that you are at a different level but you may not realize how low it 
is.  i also have had friends who succumbed to this and one of the saddest 
things i've ever seen was a friend of mine who was pregnant and addicted, 
lied, cheated and stole from those who cared about her and she just 
didn't even know that things were fucked up.

for the good news, you don't need it.  you are a beautiful and perfect 
spiritual being just the way you are! there are so many enlightning 
experiences ahead of you keep your mind pointed in the direction of 
higher consciousness like you already are by being on this list.  you 
will learn alot from the wonderful people here as i have and share your 
wisdom, too.  thanks for posting!

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA22592; Tue, 30 Jan 1996 16:25:47 -0800

From: SteveOSac@aol.com
Received: by emout07.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id TAA18078 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 30 Jan 1996 19:26:37 -0500
Date: Tue, 30 Jan 1996 19:26:37 -0500
Message-ID: <960130192636_210376912@emout07.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Lots o' babble: newbies, ol'skool, etc.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ahhh the joys of raving,
Two weeks ago I took a newbie friend to sythetic, they liked it, a lot.  Last
week she went to two parties by herself, and enjoyed them, a lot.  I was
speaking with her last night, and she made references to how sensitive she
was to the energies she encountered there, specifically the negative ones.  I
consider her wise, and she understands the reality of the different people
being there for different reasons.  After much consideration, I decided to go
into the "old school" speech, in a constructive manor, and not full bore of
course.  I was explaining rememberances of how earilier, almost every party
goer in any given venue was there for one common reason, defined
individually, yet the same in principal.  I explained the theory of Rick &
others of "creating the vibe" not finding it.  And reinforced the idea that
that central purpose is still very much alive, just a bit dispersed amongst
the crowds.  She shared with me how she felt that finding the right people
was neccessary for the creation to occur, I had to agree, and went off for a
while about the more underground events & the joys of being surrounded by a
single harmonizing energy.  We both brought up the issue of
elitism/seperatism as claimed by some, and after a while determined it was a
crock of shit.  Simply put, the strength and truth lies underground, and
there's really nothing wrong with that.

I've only been on sfraves for about a month, and love it.  I'm looking
forward t catching wind of the type of event I am speaking of, so I can
immerse my newbie sister and myself in the pure, undilluted energy, and give
her a really clear picture of exactly what it is we're working toward here!
 She thinks she's excited now?! 

Love & Life,
Steveo

no real chance of doing it again, it was on of those things where you are 
in a situation where it is handed to you, you've been hanging out all day,
drinking, in a good mood, good vibe, so you trust and try it cause it is 
there.  the whole experience just made me curious as to how someone could
become addicted to it, but you kind of answered that.  first time, mild,
second time, it digs in deeper.  i guess maybe like any drug.  it always 
starts off seeming so controllable and benign and no big deal.  then, as 
you continue in, cause you think you are in control, bango, it subtely 
gets a hold on you.  

thanks for your post, it made me realize how it is with any drug.  and 
how careful you have to be.  i hope your friend gets over its hold it has 
on him.  each day should get easier, and staring it down should make him 
stronger.  

addiction.  hmmm.  what a topic.  how it subletly starts, how it grabs 
hold.  pick any drug.  its always the same.

doug

On Tue, 30 Jan 1996, Brian Benitez wrote:

> Doug,
> 
> crack is evil, stay away. I had a friend who got seriously addicted to it,
> to the point of smoking it all the time, spending $500+ a week on it, lying
> to all his friends and girlfriend, and finally attempting to kill himself.
> He could not stop on his own, and was doing it behind a lot of people's
> backs, when he'd said he had stopped.
> 
> It may not be addicting the first time, but I guarantee if you do it a few
> more times (taking its seriously addictive properties lightly), you WILL
> become a crackead. Your statements about how you don't really understand
> how it could be so addictive exactly echo my friend's response the first
> time he did it. It was this "I don't get it" response that caused him to
> seriously underestimate the power of this substance. By the time he
> realized what had happened, he was a hopeless addict. He is still battling
> the addiction - he claims that he craves it daily - even though he hasn't
> done it in over 6 months.
> 
> I don't mean to sound like a hard-line "drugs are bad" fanatic - but I've
> seen firsthand the damage that crack can do. You don't want to go down this
> road. I would STRONGLY urge you not to do it again, and to try to get your
> friends to stop as well.
> 
> - Brian Benitez
> 
> 
>

just have to say, that i agree, totally, that you walk into an event, and you
are hit with an initial vibe, of the entirety of how the event is going 
off.  you take it all in, and sometimes it is negative.  but, if you hang 
with it, get back into yourself and close your eyes, that negative for me 
always crosses to positive, you pick it up, it picks you up, and you are 
there.  

but its funny how mostly for me, events start off negative, and then turn 
positive.  dont let that initial reaction scare you off !  it always 
turns positive if you turn in, then turn out.  of course, the music has a 
lot to do with it too !

smiles !

hope everyone is well !

doug

On Wed, 31 Jan 1996, Doug Fairclough wrote:

> 
> addiction.  hmmm.  what a topic.  how it subletly starts, how it grabs 
> hold.  pick any drug.  its always the same.
> 
> doug
actually, drugs can be split into two categories. Addictive and 
non-addictive. the addictive ones, such as crack, crank, heroin, alcohol, 
... can make you phisically dependant on the substance. however, some 
drugs dont cause any addiction whatsoever, such as psylocybin, LSD, 
marijuana, MDMA,...   unless ya count psychological addiction, but that 
has more to do with the person, 
your body wont go thru withdrawls if you stop taking the latter mentioned 
substances.
	take it easy:) tom

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 31 10:28:55 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA18397; Wed, 31 Jan 1996 10:28:55 -0800
Received: from beta.sirius.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA18300; Wed, 31 Jan 1996 10:28:37 -0800
Received: from [205.134.228.29] (ppp029-sf2.sirius.com [205.134.228.29]) by beta.sirius.com (8.6.11/8.6.9p) with SMTP id KAA22821; Wed, 31 Jan 1996 10:30:19 -0800
Message-Id: <v01520d02ad35659cab41@[205.134.228.40]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-Priority: 1 (Highest)
Date: Wed, 31 Jan 1996 10:31:22 -0800
To: ambient@hyperreal.com, socal-raves@UCSD.EDU, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: natural@sirius.com (Natural)
Subject: FCC and NAB Join Forces to Silence Free Radio Berkeley
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is a very important thing here. Maybe a few community radio stations
should start  appearing all over.
Then lets see what they do.
Knowledge is power
Stay informed!
DH
>
>
>**********************************************************************
>
>                MEDIA RELEASE FROM FREE RADIO BERKELEY
>
>             FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE, TUESDAY, JANUARY 2, 1996
>
>*************************************************************************
>
>
>FCC and NAB Join Forces to Silence Free Radio Berkeley
>
>     One week after filing a motion in Federal Court asking for an
>injunction to stop Free Radio Berkeley (FRB) from broadcasting, the
>Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has been joined by the National
>Association of Broadcasters (NAB) in its effort to stop the growth of the
>micro radio movement across the United States.  By filing a "friend of the
>court" ("amicus") brief the NAB now stands in support of the FCC motion to
>enjoin Free Radio Berkeley.
>
>     Free Radio Berkeley has remained a First Amendment thorn in the side
>of the FCC since its ... FIRST broadcast on April 11, 1993.  Since the
>FCC's motion for a preliminary injunction was denied by a Federal District
>Court on January 20, 1995 the micro radio movement has continued to grow,
>giving the people of this country access, almost for the first time to the
>air waves.  This joint action by the FCC and NAB sets the stage for
>another First Amendment confrontation.  The case will be heard in District
>Court in Oakland, California on March 15, 1996 in Courtroom #2, at the
>Federal Building, 13th and Clay streets. A free speech support
>demonstration will start at 9:00 AM, the hearing begins at 10:30 AM.
>
>     Since the beginning of this legal battle the FCC has steadfastly
>refused to recognize the merits and constitutional issues raised by Free
>Radio Berkeley.  Now they seek to have Free Radio Berkeley and Stephen
>Dunifer permanently barred from the airwaves without ever letting a court
>even consider our substantive constitutional arguments.
>.
>     Luke Hiken, Dunifer's attorney, filed a responding brief on behalf of
>Free Radio Berkeley on Friday, December 22.  It was accompanied by a
>supporting brief filed by the National Lawyers Guild's Committee on
>Democratic Communications (NLGCDC) on behalf of itself and the Media
>Alliance and the Women's International News Gathering Service (WINGS).
>Another amicus brief will be filed on behalf of Free Radio Berkeley
>listeners, community organizations, and other micropower free radio
>stations.
>
>Speaking for the National Lawyers Guild Committee on Democratic
>Communications, Attorney Alan Korn commented,
>
>     "In spite of the Communications Act's requirement that the FCC
>regulate the airwaves "in the public interest," and that they ensure the
>best use of new technologies, the FCC refuses to promote citizen access,
>arguing instead that it is more "efficient" to allow corporations and the
>Rupert Murdochs of the world to control the airwaves.  Meanwhile, merger
>mania in the broadcast industry continues unabated.  At no time in our
>history have so many broadcast stationns been controlled by so few.
>Entire communities, cultures and ideas are now systematically excluded
>from the airwaves.  It is only by reclaiming the airwaves by direct
>grassroots action that the American public can regain its voice and begin
>to engage in true self expression, which is the essence of
>self-government.  This is why the National Lawyers Guild Committee on
>Democratic Communications is committed to fight for the legal rights of
>Stephen Dunifer and Free Radio Berkeley".
>
>Speaking for Free Radio Berkeley and as the named defendant, Stephen
>Dunifer said:
>
>     "With the outrageous claim that the Federal Court has jurisdiction to
>issue an injunction against me, but does not have jurisdication to hear my
>challenge to the constitutionality of the FCC's rules barring low power
>radio, the FCC is attempting to shield itself from judicial scrutiny and
>deprive me of my First Amendment rights and due process.  Who are they to
>determine what is in the public interest when their own chairman, Reed
>Hundt has stated that 'the FCC 's current implementation of the public
>interest mandate is intellectually indefensible' ?  Free Radio Berkeley
>and all the other micropower broadcasters will not be silenced by this by
>this self-serving cabal of corporate broadcast media interests and their
>lackey, the FCC.  As the guardian of the airwaves as a public trust, the
>FCC is guilty of desertion, reckless endangerment and dereliction of duty.
>What are they going to do to stop this movement - make the possession of a
>transistor a felony offense ?"
>
>Allen Hopper, another member of the legal team stated. "
>
>     The FCC's audacity is amazing. They themselves have gone into federal
>district court, and have invoked the jurisdiction of the court to ask for
>their injunction against FRB. Now they argue that the court doesn't have
>jurisdiction to determine whether the regulations their injunction request
>is based upon are constitutional. They are essentially telling Judge
>Wilken that she has jurisdiction, but if and only if she agrees to grant
>their injunction. Otherwise, says the FCC, "no jurisdiction." The FCC's
>audacity is even more incredible when you look back to their position
>before the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of Dougan v. FCC,
>where Bill Dougan challenged the FCC's regulations in the Court of
>Appeals; the very court the FCC now argues has "exclusive jurisdiction" to
>hear challenges to their regulations.  In Dougan, the FCC argued to the
>court that "Jurisdiction to decide Dougan's arguments is vested in [the]
>United States District Court."  The FCC's blatant attempts at forum
>shopping, and at evading judicial review of their unconstitutional ban on
>micro radio, should and will be rejected by the Court.  We believe that
>the Court will deny the FCC's request for summary judgment, and we are
>ready for a trial on the merits, at which we will prove that the FCC's ban
>of micro radio is not in the public interest, and violates the First
>Amendment.
>        "Seeing the NAB filing an amicus brief supporting the FCC reminds
>me of the argument that the FCC made when the NLG's CDC filed its amicus
>brief: that the court should refuse the brief because the CDC and FRB
>attorney Luke Hiken are "one and the same, interchangeable." That charge
>is much more accurate when applied to the NAB (the lobbying arm of the
>corporate media cabal) and the FCC; they really are two heads of the same
>monster."
>
>     Copies of all legal documents are available upon request.
>
>For further information contact:
>Luke Hiken, Attorney at Law                             (415) 705-6460
>Stephen Dunifer, Free Radio Berkeley                    (510) 644-3779
>NLG Committee on Democratic Communications              (415) 648-8450
>
>
>\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\
>
>                       RADIO BERKELEY
>                        MEDIA RELEASE
>
>For Immediate release Monday, January 22, 1996
>Contact: Stephen Dunifer, (510) 644-3779
>
>
>      Urgent Help Needed For Silenced Salvadoran Community Radio Stations
>
>
>        On December 3, 1995 Salvadoran National Police raided 11 community
>radio stations.  Equipment was seized from ten stations, effectively
>silencing them.  All of these radio stations are low wattage operations
>serving peasant communities in El Salvador.
>
>        "The silenced radios are essentially peasant-oriented, educactive
>and participative.  The owners or administrators are the communities
>themselves, the peasant organizations or local non-governmental
>organizations.  In the most distant and marginalized zones of the country
>these radios serve as public telephones for emergencies or festivities, as
>a primary source of local and regional news, as a channel for announcing
>community meetings and activities, and as a medium for bringing together
>different cultural expressions in the zone.  In all of the radios the
>voice of the most humble Salvadorans have the right to inform, express
>their opinion and be heard."
>
>- Press release from A.R.P.A.S. (Association of Participative Radios and
>Programs of El Salvador)
>
>        Free Radio Berkeley has been requested by A.R.P.A.S to supply ten
>75 watt transmitters for these community radio stations who plan on
>returning to the air en masse around the first of February.  Unfortunately
>the financial resources of A.R.P.A.S are rather meager.  In addition to
>manufacturing the transmitters Free Radio Berkeley has undertaken a
>funding campaign to raise at least $5000 to cover initial costs with a
>final goal of $10,000.
>
>        Speaking for Free Radio Berkeley, Stephen Dunifer said "We are
>doing everything possible to ensure that these radio stations can go back
>on the air.  When people have been silenced by their government our only
>choice is to support their efforts to regain their voice.  This is clearly
>a move by the government to strike back at a growing movement of
>grassroots democracy in the rural communities and elsewhere.  Further,
>with increasing violence against opposition leaders, it may be a harbinger
>of even harsher moves yet to come.  I find an interesting parallel between
>our struggle with the FCC and the actions taken by the Salvadoran
>government, it seems neither entity wants to see the development of truly
>democratic grassroots broadcast media.  Free Radio Berkeley is developing
>an international operation called IRATE (International Radio Action
>Training Education) to aid in the development of low cost grassroots
>community radio stations.  We are working with Salvadoran solidarity
>groups in the Bay Area and individuals to raise the necessary funds and
>educate the public about this situation.  Any further support would be
>most welcomed."
>
>        A solidarity support celebration will held on the day the
>community radio stations go back on the air.  The time, date and place
>will be announced later.  Call (510) 644-3779 for further information.
>

[Note: feel free to insert "for me" and "in my opinion" below wherever you
think it will do the most good.]

"Rocky Mullin" <caliban@organic.com> wrote:
>	in the end, it is about what gets you off.
  [...]
> i have seen this not just at raves...
>	actually the most intense time i experienced this was at a hemp
>	festival put on by the holy hemp sisters in santa cruz - my friend
>	was hit by the rush so hard that it knocked him over.  without
>	question, this happened at dead shows.  sufis, native american
>	sundancers, jesus' yoga tricks on the cross, 3 hours of masturbation.
>	whatever man.  it's about getting off.

Right on to that.  As for some other rave alternatives, I'll mention that I
danced myself to a frenzy at Gwar not too long ago (a frenzy being about
the only way you *can* dance to Gwar) and just about lost my mind to Sonic
Youth last summer.  But leaving all this, and indeed *everything*,
behind--beyond rave, rock, rap, the Dead, Burning Man, sex, drugs,
bungee-jumping naked from collapsing bridges, or whatever other paltry
thrills you may turn to for your occasional tot of ecstasy, that little
electric taste of The Edge--there is CRASH WORSHIP.  You want to talk about
temporary autonomous zones?  A Crash Worship show is, without exception or
reservation, the farthest remove from everyday reality, from normality,
from life itself as we know it, I've ever found.  A Crash Worship show is
not a place, not an event--it's an entity, a single seething fusion of
audience and performers that can grow to be invested with an awesome, even
terrifying, elemental force.  I've felt myself dissolved, become a single
swarming cell within the greater being, catalyzed by the power and
intensity of the performance.  Really, there are no words.  It's just WAY
OUT.

anarch@scruznet.com



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 31 13:29:17 1996

From: David Kilimnik <davidk@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Ecstasy and Williams Disorder
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960131093107.24936A-100000@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey there-

	When i was home (Boston, MA), for the holidays, I was going 
through a pile of newspapers that had been set aside for me, when I came 
across an intriguing article in the Boston Glone of September 4, 1995.  
It was entitled _For this disorder, music is a hallmark_. It goes on to 
describe a group of youngsters who go to a music camp in the Berkshires 
(mountains in Western MA), who have Williams Disorder, a "rare 
developmental disorder that results in an unusually complex distribution 
of abilities and disbalities."  The thing is that these people are 
considered learning disbaled, mildly retarded (I hate that word), and 
have limited motor control. But they also have this incredible 
response to music and incredible social interactions amongst themselves.
	One of the stories in the article is about the group talent 
show.   A seventeen year old boy plays his own composition on the piano, 
while the others look on.  All are "completely absorbed in the music, 
rocking to and fro."  When he finishes, the group "bursts into applause, 
the cheering becoming a spontaneous collective performance.  Everybody's 
having a great time.  One boy gets up, does a little jig, and turns to 
high five his (smiling) neighbor."  
	The "disorder" is caused by a deletion on chromosome 7, so 
researchers are intrigued by thinking about genes for musicality and 
sociality.   One researcher said "It's as though these kids have a sort 
of instant compassion, a biological empathy." 
	
	The parallels with E are obvious, I think.  Most of you have 
experienced the incredible connection with music and with other people 
when on E, and you know what I mean.   So, I'm wondering if some of the 
same things are happening to these people with Williams Disorder.  Does 
the partial deletion of chromosome 7 affect the same chemical balances 
in the body that ecstacy does?   

	Does anyone know anything more about williams syndrome, or does 
anyone have any thoughts about this?  

				Ponderous, -dave.

> electric taste of The Edge--there is CRASH WORSHIP.  You want to talk about
> temporary autonomous zones?  A Crash Worship show is, without exception or
> reservation, the farthest remove from everyday reality, from normality,
> from life itself as we know it, I've ever found. 

Which is really too damn bad, because festivals involving fire, masquerade,
and ecstatic dancing are a longstanding human tradition.  It's sick that we
look on this as something alien, usually to be shunned.

> A Crash Worship show is
> not a place, not an event--it's an entity, a single seething fusion of
> audience and performers that can grow to be invested with an awesome, even
> terrifying, elemental force.  I've felt myself dissolved, become a single
> swarming cell within the greater being, catalyzed by the power and
> intensity of the performance.  Really, there are no words.  It's just WAY
> OUT.

Too far out for most places, unfortunately.  Last I heard they were in 
Brazil or some such, having run out of places to play in the US.  A friend
read an interview with them where they said they basically demanded half
their guarantee in advance knowing it was all they'd ever get...

Seriously, Anarch is right on.  If you really want to get in touch with 
the Beast, jump on in and let the sound dissolve your superego.  The demons
of your preconscious mind aren't nearly as evil as you've been led to 
believe.  Generally a few minutes of hard sweaty bump-and-grind with your
partially clothed neighbor will chase away any violent impulses you 
may have had.  Although given the nature of disease transmittal these 
days, you may have to restrain yourself from getting down and doing the
nasty with a stranger right there on the floor.  Seriously, it can 
be that sensual -- one particular CW show at the Square counts as the only
time I've ever deep-kissed someone I didn't already know very well.  And for 
those of you that know me, yes, that is _way_ out of character, but 
certainly not unpleasant for anyone involved >%^)

I guess one reason that those events make such a big impression on me
is that raves seem almost asexual in contrast.  I don't advocate a
meat-market atmosphere; I don't think I've ever "hit on" anyone in my
life.  I guess it's that despite being intensely physical, people seem
more into being wacky than sensual.  And before JSLee gets on me, yes,
I think many bodies look much better fully clothed, but I can
certainly appreciate the sight of healthy and fit humans gettin' down.
Sure, sometimes you're off in trance-land, your eyes are closed and
you're orbiting Jupiter and you're not interested in thinking about
your physical body, but sometimes it's kind of creepy seeing almost
everyone in the room off on their own world and not really seeing
what's around them.

For me, fast trance gets me the out-of-body experience, whereas the
more hiphop/breakbeat/two-and-four gets me down into my body.

// g

Crash Worship is one of the best live experiences around. They haven't
played in the Bay area for a few months, so they should be around soon. If
I hear about a date, I'll post, 'cause I think everyone would dig them
alot. Very tribal, very ecstatic experience.
Love
Tim
93/93

On Wed, 31 Jan 1996, Grigsbeast wrote:

> 
> I guess one reason that those events make such a big impression on me 
>is that raves seem almost asexual in contrast.  I don't advocate a 
>meat-market atmosphere; I don't think I've ever "hit on" anyone in my 
>life.  I guess it's that despite being intensely physical, people seem 
>more into being wacky than sensual.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
One of the first reasons I ever got involved with raves was precisely the
"anti-meatmarket" atmosphere.  I finally had found a place where my
personal space didn't get intruded on.  I could truly enjoy myself without
limitations.  I bonded with my friends and was able to explore feelings
and thoughts in a scene without seeing myself and others in a perpetual
mating game.  Raves really helped me see people outside of a sexual
perception.  However, I wouldn't say that raves are asexual.  They have a
lot of sexuality mixed up in them in different ways.  I find it to be very
positive and not in the least scary.  In fact, raves (along with many
other factors) caused me and some other friends to question our sexuality. 
This has enlightened my mind and is a part of me that I thoroughly
embrace. 

chau--kc

	erett circle is on the west side of santa cruz.
	a series of concentric circles, a weird neighborhood.
	take mission/hwy1 to bay.  take bay toward the ocean
	(away from ucsc) and you will see california on your
	right.  take california, it will end at the center
	of these circles, where there is a church.  wander
	around there until you find errett.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 31 15:21:55 1996

	id AA823130974; Wed, 31 Jan 96 15:28:09 PST
Date: Wed, 31 Jan 1996 15:28:09 PST
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9600318231.AA823130974@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Cc: 74230.370@compuserve.com, wshartle@eos.ncsu.edu
Subject: Pacific Party and Spundae Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last Friday, I finally went out after an absence of dancing for a few 
weeks.  Got a chance to check out Pacific's party in an Oakland warehouse.  
I got there around 12-12:30 am and got a chance to meet some new sfravers.  
Thanks Wayne for introducing them to me.  (Hi, Rikki, Shawna and two other 
friendly people whose names I've already spaced out on! :}  

The stripped down warehouse was divided in half by black plastic and some 
cloth backdrops for visuals.  One side had the projector and porta potties, 
the other had the dance area, chill space, and concessions.  Both sides had 
tall ceilings and each space was retangular.

It took a while for the crowd to warm up and the vibe to build.  There were 
alot of people standing around the "perimeter" of the dance area trying to 
get into the mood.  Initially the music was just too trippy for me but 
after socializing a bit, I finally got in the mood and moved towards the 
dance floor.  It didn't seem like things picked up (for me at least) until 
John Howard took the decks.  He was starting to work the crowd as more 
people got motivated to dance.  

Around that time, a friend told me that the police were here and the music 
was turned down some.  I wasn't really paying attention but someone said 
there were two security guards standing in front of the decks and 
periodically spoke to the dj...perhaps there were noise complaints.  So 
around 4:30am, my friends and I decided to bail out rather than see this 
thing through and spin some records chillin' at their house.  Anyone stay 
beyond this time and can tell me what happened?  I haven't seen any reviews 
on this yet?  It mustn't of been good 'cause alot of people were just 
getting into things when we left.

Saturday and Sunday rolled into a blur w/the weather, a relaxing hot tub & 
sauna, walks, talks, and much surrealism as we flowed in synch w/our 
energies.  By the evening of Sunday, we were ready to finally get out and 
dance since we didn't really do so on Friday so Spundae was the choice.  On 
a roll, four of us walked in to an already groovin' crowd.  Both the 
Teknotika (sp?) room and the "house" room had the synergies going off.  It 
was nice to walk into it and contribute our vibe.  Saw lots of old friends 
who I haven't bumped into for a while and though I haven't been to 
Spundae's in a while, I felt there was a good number of people in 
attendance as well as a diverse mix.  (Perhaps by Sunday, most of the egos 
are dropped and we're more accessible?  Got into lots of great 
conversations re: spirituality in raving.)  I felt quite comfortable and 
danced/chilled all night.

All in all, it was a great weekend for me.  I hope the rest of you had a 
good time and again, I'm curious to hear what happened at Pacific's party.

See you around!
Diane

I would like to thank everyone for their help.  I am just overwhelmed 
with the responses I received, and so touched that I cannot find the 
words to express my gratitude. It's nice to know that I am in the company 
of many warm and caring people, and to see this new electronic medium 
used in such a positive way to help others.  I am happy to report that my 
friend is seeking help with a counselor in trying to deal with his addiction.
He made an appointment even before I got a chance to suggest it, which 
indicates to me that he realizes the magnitude of his problem.  Once again
, thank you all.

James

Precedence: bulk



Grigsby sez:

>For me, fast trance gets me the out-of-body experience, whereas the 
>more hiphop/breakbeat/two-and-four gets me down into my body.

// g

Yes!  A while back, I mentioned to the group that when I go off, I open up 
and work through my chakras while dancing.  At Spundae, I ran into a newbie 
to the area and he expressed the same thing independently (w/o me 
mentioning my theories about raves, house music, etc.).  We spoke about how 
the driving bass and funky groove lines get people to move their hips, 
shake their booties and open up their lower chakras.  For me, I believe 
that this helps us get into our bodies enabling us to get beyond it to a 
trance state so we're able to work through to our heart chakras and 
ultimately to our crowns.  Basically I like to initially dance to house and 
3-4 hours later, get into a trance OBE state only to later land back by 
falling into an ambient groove.

I'd be curious to hear other people's versions of what makes them go off 
and where it takes them.  Do others of you feel that you need to get into 
your body before going off?  And lastly, what music does what to you.

Luv,
Diane

>articulated the fact that if humanity does not correct its reckless and

>with respect to the biosphere that the future of all life on Earth looks
>horribly bleak.

>called to visualize the planet being surrounded and encircled by a brilliant
>rainbow and to pray for peace and world unity. This call has been sent out
>to every continent and to millions of people in thousands of cities

>toward an awakened sense of the sacred web of life that comprises the

>the bridge to hold the ceremony at noon an resonance with people all over
>the planet.

>begins a series of such gatherings that will occur every 13 days thereafter.
>February 2 is Red Crystal Serpent day in the Mayan Calendar and is also
>Candlemass in the pagan tradition, a day exactly at the midpoint between the
>Winter Solstice and the Spring Equinox. There will be a lot of information

>allegance to the living biosphere on a new (actually very ancient) 13 month

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 31 16:17:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA26162; Wed, 31 Jan 1996 16:17:17 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA26154; Wed, 31 Jan 1996 16:17:12 -0800
Received: from [128.32.205.228] (u2w59.ResHall.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.205.228]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA10505; Wed, 31 Jan 1996 16:17:05 -0800
Message-Id: <v02120d03ad35b3903cc1@[128.32.205.228]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora 2.1.2
Date: Wed, 31 Jan 1996 16:17:06 -0800
To: Tom Leichardt <djtom@svpal.org>
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Michal Migurski)
Subject: Re: law and order.
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>> A peaceful society needs to have explicit rules, and there needs to
>> be some means of enorcing those rules.
>>
>actually, there is probably a better way to do it. seems that centuries
>of government havent yet given us a way to live peacefully under "law and
>order"

But I think government has helped a great deal... There is no perfect
government, so you can't compare the US government with all the smiley
people at your average rave. But you can compare the current state of our
government to societies where government is weaker or even nonexistent...
those societies function perfectly when everyone knows everyone else and
people can keep each other in check based on societal expectations and
norms, but when you're dealing with society on a larger scale, for example
the city of San Jose (not to mention something as monstrous as the entire
USA!) then there's no way people can keep each other in check and you're
going to have all kinds of bad elements creeping out and pretty soon the
people will develop some kind of government / law enforcement out of pure
necessity.


>hovever, on a smaller scale, i have never seen security, or any laws and
>rules, at FnF. hmmm.

Thing is, FnF is a "self-chosen" community... i.e. the people who go there
are all intent on just having a fun happy time and there aren't any
problems. However, when you try to apply this to a larger scale, like a
nation for example, you have to take into account criminals and poverty and
arrogance and greed and everything, and the only way to duplicate the
"self-chosen" community (like FnF's) would be to choose your citizens based
on what you want in your country. There are two prominent historical
examples of this:

Nazi Germany, where they decided to get rid of undesired elements of society.

The Red Scare of the 50's where a few self-righteous senators and
congressmen decided to intimidate and deport members of society whom they
believed did not share their view of how a proper America should function.


>maybe theres a way to co exist that has to do with trust, intuition,
>respect and all the other feelings people gathered at FnF seem to indulge
>in. maybe when we as humans are less concerned with survival, which
>tecnology has somethin to do with, then we can live in peace because
>there wont be a rat race anymore, less fear, less me mentality....
> maybe were just learning, getting glimpses of the possibility, at these
>beautiful parties, because we come togheter to have a good time, and
>survival isnt an issue.

I would really love that, that would just tickle me pink, but I don't think
it's possible given the number of "bad apples" we have in our current
society... This world is just too overcrowded and it's causing all kinds of
problems and there's not much that can be done... the only country thus far
that has tried to deal with overcrowding is China, and they have taken the
authoritarian approach by limiting the number of babies a couple can have
to one!!

There's just so much to worry about in this world, it really makes me sad.
I'd like to see everyone live together peacefully, but I know deep down
that it'll never happen, so the best I (we) can do is to apply that kind of
joy to our immediate suroundings and being happy.

This conversation is really great... I love talking about this kind of
stuff... I think I'm going to post this to sfraves because I'm curious what
others on the list think about this topic.


-mikey.

Diane Tabellija wrote:

>Yes!  A while back, I mentioned to the group that when I go off, I open up 
>and work through my chakras while dancing.  ...
(SNIP)
> We spoke about how 
>the driving bass and funky groove lines get people to move their hips, 
>shake their booties and open up their lower chakras.

Enlighten me: what is a chakra?

>... so we're able to work through to our heart chakras and 
>ultimately to our crowns.

Huh?

I gotta tell you, when I dance, I'm not OB, I don't feel any chakras (or any 
other terms not part of the general public's vocabulary).  On the other 
hand, I enjoy the hell out of dancing.  I'm a bit of a show-off, so there's 
that, but with the right music -- usually something with tons of really 
heavy, driving, ancient, tribal bass -- there's a feeling of power, of 
energy coursing through me.  In my mind, it's as though the other elements 
of the music are simply counterpoints to that booming; and then it's like 
something ancient, something that speaks to something eternal within.  I 
feel the blood of ancestors long dead come to life within me, and we are 
one, dancing infinite, moving to that beat, the puissant thrum beyond 
hearing of the earth's timeless magma heart...

Whoa...was I getting deep?...Sorry...  58-)

At the Martin Luther King Jr. Spundae, I could have danced all night to some 
of the things that got spun, and it was because of that energy.  But OBE?  
No, can't say that I have.  I don't suppose this requires or is aided by 
chemical assistance?

S

Precedence: bulk

>One of the first reasons I ever got involved with raves was precisely the
>"anti-meatmarket" atmosphere.  I finally had found a place where my
>personal space didn't get intruded on.  I could truly enjoy myself without
>limitations.  ...  However, I wouldn't say that raves are asexual.

I would have to agree completely with KC.  As a guy, I really hated going to 
clubs, wanting to dance, only to sit around wishing I didn't have to ask a 
girl to dance with me.  Face it, in a "mainstream" club, a guy dancing by 
himself really stands out.  You have to play the game or sit in the corner 
with your beer.  I don't mind meeting people, but sometimes I just wanted to 
dance (really!), and  some of the women weren't real polite when they shot 
me down.  It sucked greatly.

With raves, I can dance 'til both butt cheeks fall clean off.  I can be 
myself.  The physical contact, ie. hugs, backrubs, handrubs, etc.,  that 
often occurs in chill rooms isn't sexual -- it's not asexual either 8-)  -- 
it's just *really* nice.  People are infinitely more approachable!

I went back to a mainstream club recently for a friend's birthday.  The 
whole time he was trying to talk me into asking someone to dance, knowing 
that in the past I always gauged how good a time I had by how much I got to 
dance.  I just smiled and told him I wasn't in the mood, then I'd turn the 
conversation to something else.  He's not into raves, and he just doesn't 
understand that I no longer see the need to stress myself out in the "old" 
scene when I can do all the dancing I want in the "new" scene.

Peas,

S


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 31 18:08:49 1996

Date: Wed, 31 Jan 1996 18:07:20 +73600 (PST)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9601311444.A21515-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu> from "KaySEE" at Jan 31, 96 02:58:15 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2441      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> One of the first reasons I ever got involved with raves was precisely the
> "anti-meatmarket" atmosphere.  I finally had found a place where my
> personal space didn't get intruded on.  I could truly enjoy myself without
> limitations.  I bonded with my friends and was able to explore feelings
> and thoughts in a scene without seeing myself and others in a perpetual
> mating game.

I totally agree that this is great; I can actually go and _talk_ to
people without this undercurrent of tension like "Does she think I'm 
hitting on her?" or "Is she hitting on me?" or whatever.  And since I 
like to talk, this is a big bonus.  I guess I'm verbally promiscuous >%^)

To me, it seems like the tough question is "Is it possible to be sensual 
without being obnoxious?"  Seems like the problem happens when people go
in looking for someone to take home and boink, pardon my directness, as 
opposed to just being part of the experience THEN AND THERE.  The first
is sensuality as advertisement: the second is for its own sake.  Sort of
the difference between walking around all day in one of those ripped muscle
T-shirts, and deciding that maybe the big floppy ski hat and long-sleeved 
sweatshirt are sub-optimal when it's 102+ degrees and the walls are 
dripping.  Coat checks are a _good_ thing.

> Raves really helped me see people outside of a sexual
> perception.  However, I wouldn't say that raves are asexual.  They have a
> lot of sexuality mixed up in them in different ways.  I find it to be very
> positive and not in the least scary.  In fact, raves (along with many
> other factors) caused me and some other friends to question our sexuality. 
> This has enlightened my mind and is a part of me that I thoroughly
> embrace. 

I guess it's a comparative thing for me.  Given the really blatant energy
at events like Burning Man and Crash Worship, it's hard to find anything
that comes close.  I think the closest was at one of the Komotion F&Fs,
where someone had brought that huge roll of fluorescent string, and everyone
was winding it around the roof, the couches, themselves, throwing clumps of
it at each other, snaring their friends...when I mean "sensual" I mean 
"something that involves the senses", including the much-neglected touch 
and taste.  Sexual energy is only a part of sensuality.  Trancing out is 
great, but for me it seems to be the opposite, a journey deep into the 
bizarreness of my own mind.

// g

> I would really love that, that would just tickle me pink, but I don't think
> it's possible given the number of "bad apples" we have in our current
> society... 

Every time I see this discussion go by, a similar point is made.  It's
never that _I_ would ever do anything bad, you see, it's all those
_other_ people...

Who are all these "other" people that we're so scared of?  And how come
none of us is one?  Just who are we demonizing here?  I mean, if it's
not me, and not you, and not anyone I know personally, and ... well, 
who's left?  Who's the big bad wolf?

Are we really scared of what's within our own selves?  Or are we just 
scared of change?  Given that the human race is currently facing 
ecological collapse and consequent worldwide famine through overpopulation 
and stupidity, I like the thought of exploring alternatives.

Call me wacky...

// g

Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu> wrote:
>I am really
>curious about them now and would love to attend one of their shows.  Does
>anyone know how often they tour and when the next tour is expected?
>How about a web page? Do they have one?

There is a web page, as someone noted, but at present there's no info there
about shows or tours.  That page has only been around a short while, and
the "upcoming performances" section has never been filled in at all.  They
used to play around the bay pretty frequently, every 3-4 months or so, but
the last local show I know of was this past May.  That was part of a tour
that finished midsummer, so hopefully they'll be back playing soon.  They
can be tough to keep track of...their shows go on with varying degrees of
underground-ness, so the level of advertising, promotion, etc can vary a
lot as well.  Assuming the web page gets updated regularly, it should be a
good source of info--it's run by their publisher, Charnel Music.  Asking on
rec.music.industrial can also get answers.

anarch@scruznet.com

Hi everyone!
	It has been a while since I have posted but I am still here! I 
just got some new albums I wanted to tell you about. skylab#1 on 
astralworks is the first new one I got and it is really nice clean and 
smooth ambient sounds, I put it up there as one of my favorite ambient 
albums since Global Chillage which is my all time favorite chill sounds.
Other new tunes are goldies timeless which is also an excellent work, Im 
not much of a junglist, and expected a rougher edge than this peice has 
but it has a pretty mellow groove and is nice to listen to. Other new 
works are U-ziq (In pine Effect) and Sven Vath (Accident in paradise) 
which I havent really had time to get to know so maybe I can say more 
about these later.

-Tony Rose

>> I would really love that, that would just tickle me pink, but I don't think
>> it's possible given the number of "bad apples" we have in our current
>> society...
>
>Every time I see this discussion go by, a similar point is made.  It's
>never that _I_ would ever do anything bad, you see, it's all those
>_other_ people...
>
>Who are all these "other" people that we're so scared of?  And how come
>none of us is one?  Just who are we demonizing here?  I mean, if it's
>not me, and not you, and not anyone I know personally, and ... well,
>who's left?  Who's the big bad wolf?
>
>Are we really scared of what's within our own selves?  Or are we just
>scared of change?  Given that the human race is currently facing
>ecological collapse and consequent worldwide famine through overpopulation
>and stupidity, I like the thought of exploring alternatives.
>
>Call me wacky...
>
>// g

Good point... I hadn't thought of that...

I guess my response would be this:

Everyone has a little bit (or a lottle bit, depending :) of "bad" in
them... anarchy and greed are natural tendencies, IMO. The degree to which
people supress their bad tendencies is what makes society run smoothly.
Everyone has the potential to be a bad apple (I know there are a lot of
laws and social conventions that I would break if given the chance), and if
there were no *real* consequences (i.e. imprisonment or other forms of
punishment imposed by a legal government) then I think a lot more people
would be coaxed or nudged into letting their anarchistic tendencies show.

Everyone's nice at a rave, but those only last a few hours and then
everyone gets tired and cranky and unpleasant.

I think I am cautious of what's deep within people (including myself)
because I believe that deep down, we're really (in the words of Kurt
Vonnegut) just apes who can read write and do a little math, and given the
chance to practice anarchy freely we'll do what the apes do: band together
in tight little groups (gangs, frats, etc. :) and fuck each other up over
food and territory. Contrary to what many people think, I believe that to
be charitable (like at a rave for example) is to supress one's selfish
instincts and to perform the hardest thing imaginable which is to let go of
aggression and greed and to spread a little love...

-mikey.

doug wrote-
>but its funny how mostly for me, events start off negative, and then turn 
>positive.  dont let that initial reaction scare you off !  it always 
>turns positive if you turn in, then turn out.  of course, the music has a 
>lot to do with it too !
>

i have the exact same experience at raves: i walk in, feel quite negative at
first, and it takes me an hour or 2 to get into it.  i guess my problem is
that it takes me a while to shed my cares and concerns of the daily grind,
but once i shed those concerns,  watch out ravers!  here come's matt, the
water bearer!

smiling, and glad to be an sfraver-

matt l.

Received: from jobe.shell.portal.com (jobe.shell.portal.com [156.151.3.4]) by nova.unix.portal.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA29148 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 31 Jan 1996 22:58:24 -0800

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 31 Jan 1996 22:58:22 +73600 (PST)
In-Reply-To: <v02120d03ad35fdb17d6f@[128.32.205.226]> from "Michal Migurski" at Jan 31, 96 09:33:17 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Everyone has a little bit (or a lottle bit, depending :) of "bad" in
> them... anarchy and greed are natural tendencies, IMO.

Actually, you just pushed one of my buttons, by referring to anarchy as
something intrinsically evil and bad, just like the 10 o'clock news or
any random newspaper always do.

What is anarchy, anyway?  A situation in which there is no government, 
i.e. no organization that coerces behavior by threat of force.  (This,
btw, is all a government is and all it can do.  Whether coercing some 
people is _good_ is the argument, not whether that is what a government
does.)

That's not really saying much, is it?  The real question is: what would
YOU do if there were no government?  You have more freedom, and with it
more responsibility.  No traffic tickets, but no traffic laws either.
Nono of your money is confiscated ("income tax"), but you get no 
government services either.  Your parties are never busted (!) but you
can't call the police if things get out of hand.  You can dig up the 
street and plant flowers, but your neighbors can physically restrain you
from doing so.  You can smoke all the dope you want, and it's cheap, 
but...hmm.  No downside there.  Chevron can pollute the bay all it
wants, and eco-guerrillas can blow up their offices.  The going gets
weird, and the weird turn pro.

> I think I am cautious of what's deep within people (including myself)
> because I believe that deep down, we're really (in the words of Kurt
> Vonnegut) just apes who can read write and do a little math, and given the
> chance to practice anarchy freely we'll do what the apes do: band together
> in tight little groups (gangs, frats, etc. :) and fuck each other up over
> food and territory.

As opposed to what we're doing now, which is band together in BIG groups and
fuck each other up over food and territory?

Ask any native North or South American, or Ainu, or Irian Jayan, or
Tainos (all dead -- oh, well), or Tibetans, or any other tribal people
about how well big governments treat you.  Or for government
vs. government, W.W. I and II, Korean War, Vietnam, Gulf War, Nazi
Germany, or Mexico (natives in the Yucatan), or Cambodians, or
Serbians, or the entire Middle East, ... the list goes on.  These are
_governments_ killing people.  "Civilized" nations, dig?  And there
are hundreds more wars going on right now, I'm just working off the
top of my head.

I'll take the danger from tight little groups over the danger of big
scary groups any day.

We might feel safe because we happen to live in a stable time in
American history, but check out our natural resources (rapidly
depleting), national debt (rapidly increasing), and population (still
growing).  Our government is about the _least_ scummy of those in
existence, and it's rapidly heading towards fascism (drug seizure
laws, anti-"porn" laws, etc.)

> Contrary to what many people think, I believe that to be charitable
> (like at a rave for example) is to supress one's selfish instincts
> and to perform the hardest thing imaginable which is to let go of
> aggression and greed and to spread a little love...

I don't think of it as being unselfish at all.  If I know that I will
be seeing people over and over, it is in my best interests to treat
them with love and respect unless and until they mess with me.  If I
am known as an open and honest person, I will be treated better than
if I am known as a liar or other undesirable.  The only reason
dishonesty works is because in a huge population you can keep moving
and not have to always face the people you've lied to.  I don't like
having to constantly worry about keeping my lies consistent, and all
the other worry that goes with maintaining fronts.  That takes my time
and energy.  Therefore, I choose the occasional problem of dealing
with someone who has messed with me over the constant problem of
maintaining my front.

So I'm nice for selfish reasons.  Sorry if that ruins it for anyone,
but I like to think that it's more genuine that way, since I'm basing
my attitude on sound judgement rather than faith in some religion or
principles.  Faith comes and goes, but reason will always be there for
you if you need it.

Someone tackle me!  I'm being way too talkative today.

// g

causes hatred, greed, fear...

and perhaps when were free to really be ourselves, without worrying about 
convention, who do i need to impress, how should i be acting,... 
and acting on intuition, then we may 
find positive ways to release our tendencies, like dancing our asses of, 
being creative, (maybe something about crash worship has something to do 
with it). but really letting go, and being free!
this society says that pure indulgement is sinful, or evil. and many may 
be forced to surpress such tendencies, not finding outlets for their 
anger or love, and all that what we try to surpress, this "dark side" 
will eventually manifest itself, positively or negatively.
perhaps were not ready yet to be so, but the day is coming. humanity wont 
put up with this stagnant rat race weve created for ourselves. we *must* 
evolve, it is our nature. if it wasnt, we wouldnt be here in virtual 
space discussing this. 
and maybe raving is 
this positive outlet, to indulge for a night, to feel free to let go.
i know how beautiful and carefree i feel after dancing all nite, or 
spinning a great set, or "whatever gets [me] off."

At 06:14 PM 1/31/96 +73600, you wrote:
>
>> I would really love that, that would just tickle me pink, but I don't think
>> it's possible given the number of "bad apples" we have in our current
>> society... 
>
>Every time I see this discussion go by, a similar point is made.  It's
>never that _I_ would ever do anything bad, you see, it's all those
>_other_ people...
>
>Who are all these "other" people that we're so scared of?  And how come
>none of us is one?  Just who are we demonizing here?  I mean, if it's
>not me, and not you, and not anyone I know personally, and ... well, 
>who's left?

I think you forgot that it isn't anyone who looks like us either.

The thing with it is, that where a definition for "bad apple" is applied,
there forms a separation from those segments of society that are thought to
be making things worse (the "us vs. them" mentality). As things get
progressively worse, more people are needed for the "them" category to
rationalize the "downward" trend, eventually swallowing everyone, while the
"us"'s intensify their identity (e.g. go "hardcore") as an equilibrium
maintaining reaction (see Newton's 2nd). This is a suicidal mindset whose
logical conclusion involves antisocial alienation and identity crisis, as
the idea that the self no longer belongs to the "good" side creeps into the
picture.

I am reminded of a quote:

"Few blame themselves until they have exhausted all other possibilities." 
-Anonymous

While the reasoning of this quote is weak where it seems to encourage low
self-esteem and the impracticality of pursuing _all_ possibilities, it
illustrates the concept that anyone can be responsible for the states of the
world and society. Whether and how you deal with this possibility is, of
course, up to you.

eh

p.s. Communes are selfish.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 31 23:30:11 1996

From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

>i find raving is everything but supression. its about leting go, going 

>off, being myself, and the spreading love thing kinda comes naturally
>when im at that state of consciousness (really in touch with myself - 
not 
>neccesarily substance induced, either). when im surpressing my "dark 
>side" i find it is scary and fearful - but when looking straight on 
into 
>it, acgnowleging it is there, it becomes nothing but harmless shadows. 


Thinking about it, I have to agree.  When I go to a really good rave, 
and I find myself on the dance floor dancing my ass off, or really 
connecting with a beautiful person, I realize while i'm in the middle 
of doing it that something is missing, and of course that something is 
all the stuff I've been taught all my life by society etc.  Worrying 
about what other people think, nameless fears, unhappiness with myself 
resulting from other people telling me what I should be, 
self-consciousness, angry bitter thoughts, & all that artificial junk 
that we just weren't born with, but was instilled in us as the years 
pass.  And I actually feel emptier when this happens, cause I just let 
it all go, and I feel a lot lighter!  So I think letting go is exactly 
what happens.  Leaves a lot more vacant space for the 
music/love/contentment/peace to fill!  And it makes just a little bit 
more of a better person after the fact, just a little closer to who I 
ultimately want to be.

Shawna

Hello 

I thought Pacific was pretty good, I really liked the space a lot.  To me
there was not many people though.  I liked the music but it wasn't that loud
most of the time.  I started dancing early and it seemed as more and more
young people showed up, I started noticing quite a few girls (with their
friends) just standing smack in the middle of the dance area, pretty much
oblivious to the music, having little chats, with bursts of laughs
occasionally.  That was kind of weird.  It was kind of an awkward feeling.
 At some points it was total dancing energy and at other times it turned into
a lot of people standing in the middle chatting.  I think that it probably
had to do with the music becoming more and more like background music.  That
is when I noticed myself taking lots of breaks sitting on the floor and then
had zero energy and left at about 3:30-4..ish.  
Saturday night, Acme wharehouse has a very good reputation for having a good
space.  I think the Pacific party had a better space.  I prefer one big space
with a few good DJ's then, a few broken up spaces that are not to big and
very crowded.  I was there to hear Garth and others on the 1st floor, but
because that was packed all the way to the door, I was forced to chill on the
2nd floor for most of the night listening to Pollywog, whom I thought was
good to chill out to, but I really wanted to get down to Jeno and Garth on
the 1st floor.  When I tried going down there a couple of times, I always
ended next to some muscle guy in a wife beater tank (no offense).  Which I
felt like if I wasn't watching the guys every move I was going to get a fat
elbow, smack in my face.  So back upstairs I went.  I left approx the same
time as the night before for basicly loosing my energy, chillin for too long.
 I am happy I have met one Sfraver so far, Leslie. I need to meet more of
you.  It doesn't seem to be that to many people are into wearing their
laminates, so maybe someone should think of something else.  Any suggestions?
 I think some people think laminates are corny and that is why you don't see
them out much.

Pam
